div.p: A DEFENCE Of the Doctrine touching the Spring and Weight Of the AIR, Propos'd by Mr. R. BOYLE in his New Phyico-Mechanical Experiments; Againt the Objections of FRANCISCVS LINVS.
Wherewith the Objector's FUNICULAR HYPOTHESIS is alo examin'd.

p.hi: By the Author of thoe Experiments.

div.p: LONDON: Printed by J. G. for Thomas Robinon Bookeller in Oxon, 1662.

div.head: The Publiher to the Reader.
div.p: YOu may posibly in this Volume have expected the Appendix which the Author heretofore promied, and has intended hall contain ome additional Experiments to thoe which were formerly publih'd, and are here now reprinted in this Second Edition. Thee following Anwers to Francicus Linus and Mr. Hobbes are preented in compenation of the delay, and for your forbearance of that Appendix, which ere long you may expect in kind. For the Author having hinted the Promie eems thereby to acknowledge the Debt, and to be content to continue the Obligation to ee it performed. And thee ought the rather to be his excue, becaue the writing thee Anwers, and publihing the Sceptical Chymit, and ome other Dicoures, have been the principal hindrances to that Piece; which is really o near a readines, that part of it has lyen at the Pres thee ix Moneths: But yet it being not all perfected, the Stationer was loth to delay any longer the Publication of thee, for which he has been o frequently call'd upon. And they (though a Latine Edition is intended) appear now the rather in Englih, that they may accompany the Second Edition of the Original Experiments, which were printed firt in that Language in Octavo; and that intead of the promied Appendix they may complete the bulk of the Quarto Volume.

As for that part of this Piece that concerns Mr. Hobbes, it might have been larger: but the information that the Author had that the
learned Dr. Wallis was writing againt ome paages in Mr. Hobbes his Dialogues (as well that concerning the Air as the ret) was the occaion why his H. would make no animadverion on ome paages therein, and thought it not fit to enlarge upon others. And for the Errata of the Pres I hope they will not be many: however the Author as to thee is to be excued, who never (in regard to his Eyes and Impediments on other occaions) gives himelf the trouble of Corrections and Revies; neither could the Publiher much attend the Pres, it being printed in a ditant place from his uual abode. If, as I wih, you hall find this jealouie of mine to have been caules, you will have reaon to give the Piece that is o kindly offered, and leads you uch rare and untrodden paths in the bet way of Natural Philoophy, the fairer entertainment and acceptance. Farewell.

div.head: THE AVTHOR's PREFACE AND DECLARATION.
div.p: THey that know how indipos'd I naturally am to Contentiounes, will, I preume, wonder to ee me publickly engaged in two Controveries at once. But that I am till as avere as ever from entering into Diputes that may handomly be declin'd, the way wherein I have managed the following Controveries will, I hope, evince. And the Inducements I now have to appear in publick are uch, that it would be hard for me to reit the being prevail'd on by them.

For, in the firt place, I was (by Name, as it were) challenged by a peron, who undertook to diprove not one or two of my Conjectures, but as much of the whole Body of my Treatie as concern'd the Spring of the Air, which mot of my Explications uppoe. And this being done by a Learned Man, who writes very confidently of the goodnes of his Hypotheis and Arguments, and his Book being oon after follow'd by another written by Mr. Hobbs, a man of Name in the World; there eem'd to be ome danger that o early an Oppoition might oppres the Doctrine I had propos'd, before it was well undertood and duly ponder'd. Wherefore I fear'd I might be wanting to the Truth and my elf, if I hould at uch a time be altogether ilent; epecially ince I might probably divert many who would otherwie be forward to appear againt us, by letting them ee how defenible our Doctrine is even againt uch Adveraries as
hoe I have reply'd to. And this coure I the rather choe, that in cae I hould henceforward comply with thoe who would have me forbear to write any further of thee Controveries, it might not be preently inferr'd from my ilence, that a good Caue cannot enable a Pen no better then mine to defend it.

But I carce doubt but that intelligent Readers, epecially thoe that are imbued with the Principles of the Corpucularian Philoophy, will be much more apt to think that I had reaon to write the following Dicoures, then to think that I had any to make them o prolix: And epecially ingenious men, that are accutomed to admit nothing that either is not intelligible, or is precarious, will think divers of the Objections I reply to needed no Anwers, or at leat no olemn ones. But to thee I have four things to repreent.

And Firt, That which not a little wells the bulk of the following Treaties, is the inerting thoe paages of my Adveraries that I examine in their own words: which being a Practice that I expect from any that hall think fit to animadvert upon any Opinion or Argument of mine; I thought it but equitable to do what I deir'd to have done to me, though oftentimes I could not do it in a little room.

Next, I was the more willing to proecute ome of Francicus Linus his Objections, becaue the fear of being reduc'd to grant a Vacuum has o prevail'd with many eminent perons bred up in the received Philoophy of the Schools, that though they diagree both with him and among themelves about the particular manner of olving the Phaenomena of the Torricellian Experiment; yet they agree in acribing them to ome extremely-rarefi'd ubtance that fills up the pace deerted by the Quickilver. So that this Opinion, as to the main, being approved by many eminent Schoalrs, epecially of that mot learned Order of the Jeuites, (to whom perhaps its Congruity to ome Articles of their Religion chiefly recommends it) I was willing to pay them that repect, as not to dient from perons, divers of whom
for their eminence in Mathematicks and other Learning I much eteem, without hewing that I do it not but upon Coniderations that I think weighty.

Thirdly, though the Examiners Hypotheis have but few, and not very coniderable, Arguments to countenance it; yet his Objections againt our Doctrine (the Reply to which takes up the firt Part of the following Treatie) are uch, as though they may be olidly anwered by any that throughly undertands our Hypotheis, yet they may chance puzzle uch Readers as do not, and thee poiblywill prove more then a few.

And, Latly, becaue that ometimes when the Argument objected did not perhaps deerve to be much inited on, the Argument treated of deerv'd to be conidered; I thought it not amis to make ue now and then of ome uch opportunities to illutrate the matter it elf under conideration: Which I the rather did for thee two Reaons;

Firt, becaue I find that, except by ome able Mathematicians and very few other contemplative men, the Doctrine of the Spring of the Air, at leat as I have propoed it, is not yet ufficiently apprehended, (and therefore needs to be inclucated.) Inomuch that through a great part of ome late Dicoures of men otherwie eminently learned, (written againt other Elaterits, not me) there eems to run o great and clear a mitake, perhaps for want of skill in the Hydrotaticks, that I can carce impute it to any thing, but to their not throughly undertanding the Hypotheis they would confute.

And, next, becaue I was willing to lay down in my Anwer to the Objections I examin'd, the grounds of anwering uch other Arguments as may be built upon the ame or the like Principles. And perhaps I may truly enough ay, that in the following Treatie I have already in effect anwered everal Dicoures, written ome before and ome ince mine, by learned men, about the Torricellian and other new Experiments relating to a Vacuum, though I forbore to mention the names or words of the Authors, becaue I found not that my Writings or Experiments
were as yet known to them. To thee things I may adde, that I thought the Dicoures of Linus the fitter to be inited on, becaue he eems to have more diligently then ome others, (who yet venture to dipute againt it) enquired into our Doctrine. And I hall not cruple to ay thus much of an Adverary, (and one to whom I gave no provocation to be o) that though I dare not peak in general of thoe that have written either about the Weight of the Air, or ele For or Againt a Vacuum, becaue (as I acknowledge in the firt Chapter following) I cannot yet procure the Books of divers learned men, epecially of thoe great Peronages, Robervall, Balianus and Caatus; yet among the Writers I have hitherto met with, who have recoure to the Aritotelean Rarefaction and Condenation in the Controveries under debate, carce any eems to have contrived his Hypotheis better then our Linus. Not that I think his Principle is either true, or (at leat to uch as I) intelligible; but that the Funiculus he aumes being allow'd him, he may, for a Reaon to be touch'd a little below, make out, though not all the Phaenomena of my Experiments, yet many more of them then mot other Plenits, that deny the Spring of the Air, can deduce from their Hypothees if granted. And in regard that, whereas we acribe to the Air a Motion of Retitution outwards, he attributes to it the like Motion inwards, it cannot but happen that, though the Principles cannot both be true, yet many of the Phaenomena may be explicable by which of them oever is granted: becaue of this, I ay, it is not o eaie as many ingenious Readers may be apt to think, to draw pertinent Objections from Experience againt the Adverary I have to deal with. Which Irepreent, let, as ome may think I have employ'd more Arguments then I needed, o others hould think I have omitted many; as indeed I have omitted ome, that I might pertinently have employ'd.

But there is another ort of Perons beides thoe I mention'd at the beginning of this Preface, to whom I mut addree the remaining part of it; namely, to thoe who eem troubled,
that I uffer my elf to be diverted either by Linus or Mr. Hobbs from perfecting thoe Experimental About the Hitory of Flame, of Heat, of Colours, of the Origine of Qualities and Forms, &c. Treaties that are lying by me, almot promis'd by the learned Publiher of the Latine Edition of my Eays; and from proecuting thoe wayes of enquiry into the Nature of things, wherein they are pleas'd to think I may be more erviceable to reall Learning and the Lovers of it. And I confes that thee Mens Reaons and Perwaions have o far prevailed with me, that after what I have done in the two following Treaties, to Vindicate my Writings from the Objections made againt them by two Learned men of very differing Hypothees, and thereby to hew in ome meaure that I am not altogether unacquainted with the way of defending oppos'd Truths, I have laid aide the thoughts of writing any more ditinct or entire Polemicall Treaties about the Subjects already diputed of. And to this I am invited by everal other Reaons (beides what I have newly intimated.)

For firt, as I elewhere declare, it was not my chief Deign to etablih Theories and Principles, but to devie Experiments, and to enrich the Hitory of Nature with Obervations faithfully made and deliver'd; that by thee, and the like Contributions made by others, men may in time be furnih'd with a ufficient tock of Experiments to ground Hypothees and Theorys on. And though in my Phyico-Mechanicall Epitle and my Specimens I have ventur'd ome Conjectures alo at the Caues of the Phaenomena I relate, let the Dicoure hould appear to inquiitive Readers too jejune; yet (as I formerly aid) I propos'd my Thoughts but as Conjectures deign'd (though not only, yet chiefly) to excite the Curioity of the Ingenious, and afford ome hints and aitance to the Diquiitions of the Speculative. And accordingly I have not forborn to mention divers things, which judicious Readers may eaily perceive I foreaw that many, would think unfavourable to the Opinions I inclin'd to. So that for me to leave Experimental for Controverial Studies,
were a coure unuitable to the principal cope of my Writings.

Next, though I have adventur'd to improve the Doctrine of the Spring and Weight of the Air by ome Supplements where I found it deficient, and to recommend it by ome new Illutrations and Arguments deduc'd from my Experiments: yet the Hypothees themelves (for the main) being the Opinions alo of far learneder Men then I, it might be thought injurious both to them and to our common Caue, if I hould needlely go about to hinder them from the Honour of Vindicating the Truths we agree in; epecially, ome of them being Excellent Mathematicians, and others Eminent Naturalits, whoe Concern to maintain the Hypothees againt Objections, if any hall arie, is equal to mine, and whoe leiure and abilities far exceed thoe of a Peron who both is ickly, and hath other employments enough, and who (if he were far better skil'd in Geometry then he pretends to be) hath uch a weaknes in his Eyes, as makes him both unwilling and unfit to engage in any Study where the convering with Mathematical Schemes is neceary.

Thirdly, nor do I ee much caue to doubt that the things I have deliver'd will notwithtanding my ilence be left undefended: The forwardnes I have already oberv'd in divers Virtuoi to Vindicate thoe Writings, which they are pleas'd to ay have convinc'd them, and to ave me the labour of penning the following Treaties, carce permitting me uch an Apprehenion. Epecially ince there are ome things that will much facilitate their Task, if not keep men from putting them upon it. For though Mr. Hobbs and Linus have examin'd my Writings upon Principles wherein they differ as much from each other as from me; yet neither have they een caue to deny any thing that I deliver as Experiment, nor have their Objections been coniderable, whether as to Number or to Weight, againt the Applications I have made of my Principles to olve the Phaenomena. So that uually without objecting any Incongruity to my particular Explications, they are fain to fall upon the Hypothees themelves: in whoe Defence I think I may with the more Reaon expect to
be econded, becaue not only I have endeavour'd, as I formerly noted, to lay the grounds of anwering uch Objections as I foreaw might arie; but I have alo, to prevent or eae their labour, written the two firt Parts of my Defence againt Linus, without being oblig'd to do o for the Vindicating of my Explications, which are particularly maintain'd in the third Part.

I know not whether I may venture to adde on this Occaion, That thoe who have taken notice of the uefulnes of Experiments to true Philoophy, and have oberv'd that neverthelee the Difficulty, Trouble, and Charge of making them is uch, that even in this Learned Age of ours there are very few Bacon's or Merennus's to be met with, and thoe who have either made themelves, or at leat een others make Experiments, even uch as thoe I have publih'd, with the care I am wont to think my elf oblig'd to employ on uch Occaions; will perhaps not only believe that they cot me far more time and pains then they that have not made or een uch tryals are apt to imagine, but will poibly think it enough for a Peron that is not by Profeion a Scholar, to make them carefully, and et them down faithfully, and will allow him to let others Vindicate the Truths he may have the good fortune to dicover, epecially, when there are o many fitter for it then he, who have (as well as his Adveraries) more leiure to write Diputations then opportunity to proecute Experiments; the latter of which to be perform'd as it ought to be, doth in many caes, beides ome Dexterity carce to be gain'd but by Practice, require ometimes more Diligence, and oftentimes too more Cot, then mot are willing, or then many are able, to betow upon them.

To be hort, though if any thing very worthy to be taken notice of by me be uggeted againt any of my chief Opinions or Explications, I may either take an occaion to ay omewhat to it elewhere, or at leat have an opportunity to conider it in a Review, wherein I may alter, mend, upply, vindicate or retract divers Paages of my other Writings: yet I would not have it expected that I hould exchange a Book with every one that is
at leiure to write one againt a Vacuum, or about the Air. Which Declaration I make, not that I think it will or ought to hinder any man from making ue of his liberty to expree a dient, if he ees caue; but for thee two Reaons.

The one, That my ilence might not injure either the Truth or my elf, by tempting men to think, that whatever I do not anwer, I cannot; but might give unbias'd and judicious Readers a Caution to allow as little of Advantage to the Writings of my adveraries upon the account of their being unanwer'd by me, as if I were no longer in the World. And the other, That I may not hinder thoe who would reply to uch Adveraries, by leaveing them an apprehenion that either I may prevent them, or they me. To conclude, I ee no caue to depair, that whether or no my Writings be protected, the Truths they hold forth will in time in pite of oppoition etablih themelves in the Minds of men, as the Circulation of the Bloud, and other formerly much conteted Truths have already done. My Humour has naturally made me too careful not to offend thoe I dient from, to make it neceary for any man to be my Adverary upon the account of Peronal Injuries or Provocations. And as for any whom either Judgment or Envy may invite to contend, that the things I have communicated to the World deerved not o much Applaue as they have had the luck to be entertain'd with; that hall make no Quarrel betwixt us: For perhaps I am my elf as much of that mind as he; and however I hall not cruple to proes my elf one of thoe who is more deirous to pend his time uefully, then to have the Glory of leaving nothing that was ever written againt him unanwer'd; and who is more ollicitous to purue the wayes of dicovering Truth, then to have it thought that he never was o much ubject to Humane Frailties as to mis it.

div.head: A DEFENCE Of Mr. R. BOYLE's EXPLICATIONS of his Phyico-mechanical EXPERIMENTS, againt FRANCISCUS LINUS.

argument.p: Wherein the Adveraries Objections againt the Elaterits are examined.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p:
A Newly publihed Treatie, De Corporum ineparabilitate, being brought to my Hands, I find everal Chapters of it employ'd to oppoe the Explications I ventur'd to give of ome of my new Experiments touching the Spring of the Air. Wherefore though I am very little delighted to be engag'd in Controveries, and though I be not at preent without Employments enough (of a private, and of a publick
Nature) to make it uneaonable for me, to be by a Work of this ort diverted from them; yet for the Reaons pecified in the Preface, I hold it not amis to examine briefly what is objected againt the thing I have delivered: and the rather, partly, becaue the Learned Author, whoever he be (for 'tis the Title-Page of his Book that firt acquainted me with the name of Francicus Linus) having forborne provoking Language in his Objections, allowes me in anwering them to comply with my Inclinations & Cutom of exerciing Civility, even where I mot dient in point of Judgement. Beides, the Author himelfe has omewhat facilitated my Reply to him, by directing me in the ninth Page to ome Books and Paages that I had not, when I publiht my Epitle, either een or taken notice of. As indeed there are beides ome of thee everal other Dicoures that treat of the Torrecellian Experiments, which though by the names of their Authors I gues to be learnedly written, I have not to this day had opportunity to perue, my tay in the remoter parts of Ireland (whither Philoophical Books were not, in that time of publick Confuion, brought) having kept me from hearing of divers of them, till they were all bought up. Which I here mention, to excue my elf if I have not taken notice of ome things or paages to be met with in thee Writings, which their Learned Authors or Inquiitive Readers might jutly perhaps expect I hould take ome notice of, in cae thoe Writings had fallen into my hands. But to digres no further.

'Tis true indeed, and it omewhat troubles me that it is o, that I can carce promie my elf to make my Adverary a Proelyte, ince he without cruple aumes thoe very things as Principles, that to me eem almot as great Inconveniences as I would deire to hew any Opinion I dilike, to be liable unto. But ince whatever Operation the following Dicoure may have upon the Peron that occaion'd it, I hope it may bring ome atisfaction to thoe Philoophers who can as little as I undertand the Aritotelean Rarefaction, and who will as well as I be backward to admit what they cannot undertand; it hall uffice me
to defend the Truths I have deliver'd, if I cannot be o happy as to convince my acute Adverary of them; and I hall not believe my labour lot, if this Dicoure can contribute to the Etablihment of ome Notions in Philoophy that I think not inconiderable, in the minds of thoe whoe clear Principles make me the mot repect their Judgements, and for whoe akes I principally write.

Now though I be not in trictnes oblig'd to defend any more then uch of my own Explications as the Examiner has thought fit to quetion, and thoe Particulars which I have added by way of Improvement to the two Hypothees of the Spring and Weight of the Air: yet that I may the more effectually proecute what I lately intimated I aim at in this Writing, and may as well illutrate my Doctrine as defend it, I hall divide the enuing Treatie into three Parts; whereof the firt is deign'd to anwer my Adveraries Objections againt our Principles; the econd hall examine the Funicular Hypotheis he would ubtitute in their tead; and the third hall contain particular Replyes to what he alledges againt ome of my particular Explications.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p: ALthough our Author confees in his econd Chapter, that the Air has a Spring as well as a Weight, yet he reolutely denies that Spring to be near great enough to perform thoe things which his Adveraries (whom for brevities ake we will venture to call Elaterits) acribe to it. And his whole fourth Chapter, as the Title declares, is imploy'd to prove that the Spring of the Air is unable in a cloe place to keep the Mercury upended in the Torrecellian Experiment. The proof of this Aertion he ayes is eaie: But alledges two or three Arguments for it, which I think will be more eaily anwer'd then his Aertion evinc'd.

In the Firt he ayes that thoe Experiments concerning the
Adheion of ones finger, &c. which he had mentioned in the foregoing Chapter, eodem modo e habent in loco clauo ac in aperto. But the anwering of this we hall upend till anon; partly, becaue it may then be more conveniently examin'd, and partly, becaue our Author eems not to build much upon it, his chief Argument being that which he propoes in thee words, Cum tota vis hujus Elaterii pendeat à refutato jam aëris aequipondio cum digitis 29½ argenti vivi, ita ut nec plus, nec Pag. 20. minus faciat hoc elaterium in loco occluo, quam fit per illud aequipondium in loco aperto; manifetum est, cum jam otenum it fictitium planè ee hujumodi aequipondium, fictitium quoque ee tale elaterium. Wherefore ince all the validity of his Objection againt the Spring of the Air depends upon his former Chapter, wherein he thinks he has diprov'd the Weight of the Air; it will behove us to look back into the former Chapter, and examine the four Arguments which he there propoes. But I mut crave leave to vary from his method, and conider the third in the firt place, becaue the removal of that Objection will facilitate and horten the anwer to the ret. His Third Argument therefore is thus et down. Nam i Tubus viginti tantum digitorum (quo ui umus in primo Argumento) non Pag. 16. totus impleatur argento, ut prius, ed patium aliquod inter digitum uperiorem & argentum relinquatur in quo fit olus aër; videbimus ubtracto inferiore digito uperiorem non olum deorum trahi; ut prius, ed etiam argentum jam decendere, idque notabiliter, quantum nimirum extendi potet exigua illa aëris particula à tali pondere decendente. Unde i loco illius aëris ponatur aqua, aliuve liquor qui non tam facilè extenditur, decenus nullus erit.

p.hi: Hinc, inquam, contra hanc ententiam formatur argumentum: nam i externus ille aër neque at velhos viginti digitos argenti à lapu utentare, uti jam vidimus, quomodo quaeo utentabit 29½? Certè haec nullatenus reconciliari pount.

div.p:
But to this Argument, which he thinks o irreconcilable with his Adveraries Hypotheis, he has himelf furniht them with an
Anwer in thee words, Dices forte ideo argentum in hoc cau decendere, quia deorum truditur ab aëre illo ee per uum Elaterium dilatante. Which Anwer I think ufficient for the Objection, notwithtanding the two exceptions he takes at it.

For firt, whereas he ayes, that ic deberet digitus potius à tubo repelli, quam eidem affigi, cum non minus urum quam deorum fiat hujumodi dilatatio: He coniders not, that though the endeavour of the included Air to expand it elfe be at firt every way alike, yet the expanion it elfe in our cae mut necearily be made downward, and not upward; becaue the Finger that tops the Tube being expos'd on the upper parts and the ides to the external Air, has the whole Weight and preure of the Atmophere upon it; and conequently cannot be thrut away but by a force capable to urmount that preure: whereas on the lower ide of the Included Air there is the Weight of the whole Mercurial Cylinder to ait the Spring of the Air, to urmount the Weight of the Atmophere that gravitates upon the retagnant Mercury. So that the Air included and endeavouring to expand it elfe, finding no aitance to expand it elf upward, and a coniderable one to expand it elfe downward, it is very natural that it hould expand it elfe that way whence it finds les reitance. As accordingly it will happen, till the Spring of the Air be o far debilitated by its Expanion, that its preure, together with the weight of the Mercury that remains upended, will but counter-balance, not overcome, the preure of the outward Air upon the retagnant Mercury. And this Explication may be confirm'd by this trial that I have purpoely made, namely, that if in tead of Quickilver you employ Water, and leave as before in the Tube an Inch of Air, and then inverting it, open it under Water, you will perceive the included Inch of Air not to dilate it elfe any thing near (for I need not here define the Proportion) halfe o far as it did when the Tube was almot fill'd with Mercury; becaue the Weight of o hort a Cylinder of Water does but equal that of between an Inch and an Inch and an halfe only of Quickilver, and conequently the inward Air is far les
aited to dilate it elf and urmount the preure of the outward Air by the Cylinder of Water then by that of Mercury. And as for what our Author ayes, that if intead of Air, Water or ome other Liquor be left at the top of the Tube, the Quick-ilver will not decend: the Elaterits can readily olve that Phaenomenon, by aying that Water has either no Spring at all, or but an exceeding weak one; and o carce prees but by its Weight, which in o hort a Cylinder is inconiderable. Now the ame olution we have given of our Examiners Objection, gives us alo an account why the Finger is o trongly fatned to the upper part of the Orifice of the Tube it tops; for the included Air being o far dilated that an Inch, for example, left at firt in the upper Part of the Tube, reaches twice or thrice as far as it did before the decent of the Quick-ilver, its pring mut be proportionably weakned. And conequently that part of the Finger that is within the Tube will have much les preure againt it from the dilated Air within, then the upper part of the ame Finger will have from the unrarefi'd Air without. By which means the Pulp of the Finger will be thrut in (which our Author is pleas'd to call uckt in) as we hall ere long have occaion to declare in our Anwer to his econd Argument.

And having aid thus much to our Authors firt exception againt the olution he foreaw we would give of his third Argument; we have not much to ay at preent to his econd. For whereas he ayes, Concipi non poe quomodo aër ille ic e dilatet, argentumque deorum trudat, nii occupando Pag. 17. majorem locum: Quod tamen hi Autores quam maxime refugiunt, aerentes rarefactionem non aliter fieri, quam per corpucula aut vacuitates: I wih he had more clearly expres'd himelf, ince as his words are couch'd I cannot eaily gues what he means, and much les eaily dicern how they make an Argument againt his Adveraries. For, ure he thinks them not o aburd, as to imagine that the Air can dilate it elf, and thrut down the Mercury, without in ome ene taking up more room then it did before: For the very word Dilatation, and the effect
they acribe to the included Air, clearly imply as much; o that I ee not why he hould ay that they are o avere from granting the Air to take up more Place then before, epecially ince he takes notice in the former Chapter, that we compare the Expanion of the Air to that of compres'd Wooll; and ince he here alo annexes that we explicate Rarefaction either by Corpucles or Vacuities. But this later Claue makes me upect his meaning to be, that the Elaterits do not admit that the ame Air may adequately fil more of Place at one time then at another; which I believe to be as true as that the elf-ame lock of compres'd Wooll has no more Hairs in it, nor does adequately fill more Place with them, when it is permitted to expand it elf, then whilet it remain'd compres'd. But againt this way of Rarefaction our Author here has not any Objection, unles it be intimated in thee words, Concipi non potet: Which if it be, I hall need only to mind him in this place, that whereas many of the chiefet Philoophers, both of Ancient and our own times, have profet they thought not the Aritotelean way of Rarefaction conceivable; and he acknowledges (as we hall ee anon) that it is not clear; what the ablet of his Party (the modern Plenits) are wont to object againt the way of Rarefaction he dilikes, is, that it is not true, not that it is not intelligible.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p:
OUr Authors Second Objection (for o I reckon it) is thus propos'd by him. Si umatur tubus utrinque apertus, ed longior, put a digitorum 40. Argentoque impleatur, eique Pag. 15. digitus upernè applicetur ut prius, videbimus ubtracto inferiore digito, argentum quidem decendere uque ad conuetam uam tationem; Digitum autem uperiorem fortiter intra tubum trahi, eique firmisime, ut prius, adhaerere. Ex quo rurum evidenter concluditur, argentum, in ua tatione contitutum, non ibidem utentari ab externo aëre, ed à funiculo quodam interno upendi, cujus
uperior éxtremitas, digito affixa, eum ic intra tubum trahit, eique affigit. But this Argument being much of the ame nature with that drawn from his third Experiment, the Anwer made to that and to his firt may be eaily apply'd, and will be ufficient for this alo; epecially becaue in our preent cae there is les Preure againt the Pulp of the Finger in the inide of the Tube then in the third Experiment (where ome air is included, though much expanded and weakned;) the Preure of the Atmophere being in the preent cae kept off from it by the ubjacent Mercury, whereas there is nothing of that Preure abated againt the other parts of the Finger that keep it off from the deerted Cavity of the Tube, ave only that from the Pulp that is contiguous to the Tube, there may be omewhat of that Preure taken off by the Weight of the Glas it elf. But as for that Part of the Finger which immediately covers the hole, whether or no there be any Spring in its own fibres, or other contituent ubtances, which finding no reitance in the place deerted by the Quick ilver, may contribute to its welling (for that we will not now examine) he that has duly conider'd the account already given of this Intruion of the Pulp into the Glas, will find no need of our Authors internal Funiculus, which to ome eems more difficult to conceive, then any of the Phaenomena in Controverie is to be explain'd without it.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p:
BY what we have already aid againt our Examiners Third Argument, we may be aited to anwer his Firt, though he propoe it as a very clear Demontration; and though it be indeed the principal thing in his Book. Sumatur (ayes he) tubus brevior digit is 29½ puta digitorum 20. non tamen Pag. 12. clauus altero extremo, (ut hactenus) ed utrinque apertus: Eic Tubus, immero ejus orificio Argento retagnanti, uppe • oque digito, n • effluat Argentum Tubo infundendum, impleatur
argento vivo: alius
que deinde digitus orificio quo
que applicetur, illud
que bene claudat. Quo facto, i ubtrahatur inferior digitus, entietur uperior vehementer trahi, ac ugi intra tubum, tam
que pertinaciter ei (vel argento potius, ut potea) adhaerere, ut ipum tubum cum toto argento incluo facilè elevet teneat
que in vae pendulum.

p.hi:
Ex quo ane experimento clarisimè refellitur haec ententia: Cum enim, juxta eam, Argentum in tubo hujumodi 20. tantum digitorum, urum trudatur à praeponderante ante aëre externo: nunquam profecto per eam explicabitur, quomodo digitus ille ic trahatur deorum, tubo
que tam vehementer adhareat; non enim à trudente urum potet ic deorum trahi.

div.p: Thus far our Authors objection, in anwer whereunto I have divers things to repreent, to hew, that a good account may be given of this Experiment in the Hypotheis of the Elaterists, which is ufficient to manifet how far the argument is from being o unanwerable as the propoer of it would perwade his Reader.

I deny then that the Finger is drawn downward, or made by uction to adhere to the Tube; but I explicate that which he calls the uction of the Finger, as I lately did in anwer to his third Argument, as we hall more particularly ee anon.

He ayes indeed, that the Air which thrut up the Quickilver cannot o trongly draw down the Finger. As if the Air were not a fluid body, but a ingle and entire pillar of ome olid matter. But to horten our reply to his objections, the bet way perhaps will be briefly to explicate the Phaenomenon thus:

When the Tube is fill'd with Quickilver, the Finger that tops the upper Orifice is almot equally pres'd above and at the ides by the contiguous Air; but when the lower Finger is remov'd, then the Cylinder of Mercury, which before gravitated upon the Finger, comes to gravitate upon the retagnant Mercury, and by its intervention to pres againt the outward Air: o that againt thoe parts of the Finger that are contiguous to the Air there is all the wonted preure of the outward Air; whereas againt that pulp that is contiguous to the Mercury there is not o much preure as againt the other parts of the Finger by
two thirds. I ay by two thirds, or thereabout, becaue the Mercurial Cylinder in this Experiment is uppos'd to be twenty Inches high; and if it were but a little more then thirty Inches high, (which is a third more) then the weight of the Quickilver would take off not two thirds onely, but the whole preure of the outward Air, from the above-mentioned pulp of the Finger. For in that cae the Quickilver would quite deert it, and ettle beneath it. Wherefore ince it has appeared by our Anwer to the Examiners third Argument, That the preure of the outward Air is taken off from the body that remains in the upper part of the Tube, according to the weight of the liquor upended in the Tube; and ince in our Hypotheis the preure of the outward Air is able to keep thirty Inches of Quickilver, or two or three and thirty foot of Water, upended in a Tube; it need be no great wonder, if a preure of the ambient Air, equal to the weight of a Cylinder of Water of near twenty two foot long, hould be able to thrut in the pulp of the Finger at the upper Orifice of the Tube, and make it tick cloely enough to the lip of it.

I know the Examiner affirms, That no thruting or preure from without can ever effect uch an adheion of the Finger to the Tube. But this hould be as well prov'd as aid. But, firt, though I am willing to think the Examiner would not knowingly relate any thing he is not perwaded of; yet as far as I and another peron very well vers'd in thee Experiments have purpoely tryed, I could not find the Adheion of the Finger to the Tube to be near o trong as our Author hath related. Secondly, if you carefully endeavour by preure and otherwie to thrut the pulp of your Finger into the Orifice of the Tube, you may through the Glas perceive it to be manifetly tumid in the cavity of the Pipe. And if by preing your Finger againt the Orifice of the Tube, you hould not make the pulp adhere quite o trongly to the Tube, nor well quite o much within it, as may happen in ome Mercurial Experiments; it is to be conider'd, that the Air being a fluid as well as a heavy body, it does not (as
groer Weights would) pres only againt the upper part of the Finger, but preing as much of the finger as is expos'd to it almot every where, and almot uniformly, as well as trongly, it does by its lateral preure on every ide thrut in the Pulp of the Finger into the hole where there is not any reitance at all, or at leat near o much preure againt the Pulp as that of the ambient Air againt the parts of the Finger contiguous to it.

By this it may appear that we need not borrow the Objection our Author offers to lend us; namely, that in the Experiment under conideration the Quickilver is pres'd downward by the Spring of ome Air lurking betwixt it and the Finger. (Though I am prone to think that unles the Experiment be made with a great deal of care, uch a thing may eaily happen, and contribute to the tronger Adheion of the Finger to the Tube.) This I ay may appear notwithtanding what our Author Objects, that the Air expanding it elf wil thrut away the Finger upwards, ince the contrary of that pretence we have lately manifeted in the Anwer to his Third Argument. And as for what he adds to confirm his Argumentation in thee Words, Quod vel inde confirmatur, Quia cum praponderans ille aër uccedat Pag. 14. (uti aeritur) loco ublati inferioris digiti, id et, eodem modo nunc utentet Argentum quo ante ab applicato digito inferiore utentabatur; manifetum et, non debere, juxta hanc ententiam, magis deorum trahi digitum uperiorem pot ublata¯ inferiorem quam ante. Cum it aque contrarium planè doceat experientia, atis liquet ententiam illam ee falam. We mut conider that the Tube being uppos'd perfectly full of Mercury, the Finger that tops the lower Orifice is wont to be kept trongly pres'd againt it, let any of that ponderous Liquor hould get out between the Tube and the Finger. So that although both the lower Finger do indeed keep up the Mercury in the Tube, and the preure of the outward Air would do o too; yet there is this difference, that the preure of the Atmophere depending upon its Weight, cannot be intended and weakned as we pleae, as can that of the undermot Finger. And therefore whereas the Atmopherical
Cylinder will not keep up a Cylinder of Quickilver of above thirty Inches high, thoe that make the Torricellian Experiment do often, upon one occaion or other, keep up with the, Finger a Mercurial Cylinder of perhaps forty or fifty Inches or far more: o that whereas in our Cae, before the removal of the undermot Finger, the Pulp of the uppermot mut have about the ame Preure againt it where it is contiguous to the Mercury, as there is againt the other part of the ame Finger; after the removal of the undermot Finger, there is as much of the Atmopherical Preure, if I may o peak, taken off from the newly-mention'd Pulp as counter-balances a Cylinder of Quickilver of twenty Inches long.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: THe Examiners Fourth and lat Experiment is thus propos'd. Quarto denique (ayes he) impugnatur: Quia ex eo equeretur, Argentum vivum per imilem Tubum è vaculo exugi poe eâdem prorus facilitate quâ ex eodem exugeretur Pag. 8. aqua: quod tamen experientiae repugnat, quâ docemur aquam in • s ugentis facillime attrahi; quo tamen Argentum vivum ne toto quidem adhibito conatu perduci queat, imo vix ad Tubi medietatem.

Sequelam autem ic otendo: Quia cum in hac ententia nihil aliud agendum it quam hoc, ut per Tubum ic acendat ubjectus Liquor, ive Aqua fuerit, ive Argentum, nii ut ugendo urum trahatur aër Tubo inclu s, quo ic attracto acendit illico ubjectus Liquor, protruus nimirum ab externo aëre jam praeponderante (uti docet Pecquetius in Diertatione Anatomica pag. 63.) manifetum et, eadem planè facilitate exugendum ic Argentum vivum qua exugitur Aqua: Quod quum Experientiae tam aperte repugnat, necee et ententiam ex qua equitur falam ee.

This Experiment I remember I made ome years ago, accordingly 'tis alledg'd in the Fourth Eay of the Treatie (I was
then writing) to prove againt the Vulgar Opinion, that Liquors do not to prevent a Vacuum pontaneouly acend, which I preume will be o far allow'd of by our Author, who would have Liquors uppos'd to be rais'd by Suction violently drawn up by the contraction of his Funiculus. But to examine this Experiment, as it concerns the preent Controverie, we may recal to mind that we formerly hew'd in the Anwer to our Authors Third Argument, That when the Mercurial Cylinder that leans upon the retagnant Mercury has at the other end of it Air, kept from any entercoure with the Atmophere, that included Air has o much of the Preure of the external Air taken off from it as counterpoies the Mercurial Cylinder. And the Finger that is expos'd to the whole Preure of the ambient Air in ome of its Parts, and in others but to the much fainter Preure of the included Air, endures an unuual Preure from the preponderating Power of the Atmophere.

We may conider alo that there is againt the Thorax and thoe Mucles of the Abdomen that are ubervient to Repiration the Preure of the whole ambient Air. Which Preure, notwithtanding the Mucles deign'd for the ue of Repiration, are able without any coniderable reitance to dilate the Thorax at pleaure; becaue, as fat as they open the Chet, and by dilating it weaken the Spring of that Air which is then within the Body, the external Air by flowing in, for want of finding the uual reitance there, keeps that within the Thorax in an Aequilibrium of force with that without. Thee things premied, 'tis not difficult in our Hypotheis to give an Anwer to the Examiners Experiment. For we ay when a Cylinder of Mercury is rais'd in the Tube to any coniderable height, the Preure of the Air in the Thorax is leen'd by the whole weight of that Mercurial Cylinder, and conequently the Repiratory Mucles are thereby diabled to dilate the Chet as freely as they were wont, by reaon of the Prevalency of the undiminih'd Preure of the external Air againt the weakned Preure of the internal: But if in tead of Mercury, you ubtitute Water, o hort a Cylinder
of that comparatively light Liquor takes off o little of the Preure of the included Air, that it comes into the Lungs with almot its uual Strength, and conequently with almot as much Force as the outward Air prees with againt the Thorax.

And on this occaion there occurrs to my thoughts a noble Experiment of the mot Ingenious Monieur Pachal, which clearly hews, that if we could free the upper Part of uch a Tube as we are now conidering from the Preure of all internal Air, it would follow, as the Examiner ayes it hould, that the Quickilver would by the Preure of the outward Air be impell'd up into the Tube as well as Water, till it had attain'd a height great enough to make its Weight not inferiour but equal to that of the Atmophere. The Experiment it elf being o pertinent and coniderable, we hall annex it in the ame words wherein it is related by his Country-man and Acquaintance, the Learned and Candid Gaendus. Neque hoc verò olum, ed inuper vitreo Diabete Clyteréve ea qua Ga. Phy. Sect. 1. Lib. 2. Pag. 204. De nupero Inanis Experimento. par fuerit longitudine confecto, & pot embolum ad orificium uque compulum, immio ad normam in ubjectum Hydrargyrum deprehendit, ubi embolum enim deinde educitur, conequi Hydrargyrum acendere
que ad eandem u
que duorum pedum & digitorum trium cum emie altitudinem. To which he immediately ubjoynes a Circumtance very coniderable to the preent Controverie in the following Claue. Ac ubi deinceps, adhibita licet non majore vi, Embolum altius educitur, conitere Hydrargyrum, ne
que amplius conequi, ac fieri interim Inane quod patium intercipitur ab ipo ad Embolum uque. Thus far he. So that as to the Examiners Experiment, we may well explicate it in our Hypotheis, by aying, that agreeably to it it happens, that in a more forcible Repiration the Mercurial Cylinder is raied higher then in a more languid; becaue, in the former Cae, the Chet being more dilated, the included Air is alo more expanded; whereby its debilitated Spring cannot as before enable the Mercurial Cylinder to counterpoie altogether
the Preure of the ambient Air. And that the Reaon why the Quickilver is not by Repiration rais'd as high as it is kept upended in the Torricellian Experiment, is not, that the Preure of the outward Air is unable to raie it o high, but becaue, as we have already declar'd, the free Dilatation of the Thorax is oppoed by the Preure of the ambient Air; which Preure being againt o great a Superficies, and being but imperfectly reited by the debilitated Preure of the Air within the Thorax, will be eaily imagined to be very coniderable by him who coniders that in our Engine, the Preure of the external Air againt the Sucker of les then three Inches Diameter was, as we relate in the 33. Experiment, able to thrut up a Weight of above a hundred pound. And here we may oberve upon the By in Confirmation of our former Doctrine, that when we trongly uck up Quickilver in a Glas Tube, though the Elevation of the Quickilver be according to our Author performed likewie by his Funiculus contracting it elfe every way, and though there be a Communication betwixt the internal Surface of the Lungs, and the Cavity of the Tube; yet we feel not in our Lungs any endeavour of the hrinking Funiculus to tear off that Membrane they are lin'd with.

And thus we have examin'd our Authors four Arguments, to prove that in the Torricellian Experiment the Quickilver cannot be kept upended by the counterpoie of the external Air: Againt which Opinion he tells us indeed, that other Arguments might be alledg'd, but as it is not probable that if he had thought them better then thoe he has Pag. 19. elected to init on, he would have omitted them; o 'tis not unlikely that Anwers might be as well found for them as for the others; epecially ince that which he ingles out for a Specimen is, that from his Adveraries Hypotheis it would follow, that the Quickilver would decend much more (I uppoe 'tis a mitake of the Pres, for much les) in cold Weather then in hot, becaue the Air is then thicker and heavier, and therefore ought to impel up the Quickilver higher. For beides that we hall in
its due place quetion the validity of our Authors Conequence; it will be here ufficient to Reply, that the Obervation on which he grounds it does not contantly hold, as his Objection uppoes: which may appear by that part of our 18. Experiment whence the matter of Fact is deum'd, as we hall have occaion-to take further notice of when we hall come to the Defence of that Experiment. So that what has been hitherto Dicours'd on both ides being duly conider'd, the Reader is left to judge what ground the Examiner had for the < in non-Latin alphabet > wherewith he is pleas'd to conclude his Third Chapter, Maneat igitur tot Argumentis comprobatum, quorum quodlibet e olo uf ficit, Argentum (facto Experimento in loco aperto) Pag. 19. 20. per externi aëris gravitatem à lapu minimè utentari.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p:
HIs fourth Chapter, wherein the Title promies that he will prove, Argentum in loco occluo non utentari à lapu per ipum aëris Elaterium, is very hort, and does not require that we hould dwell long upon it. For the proof he brings of his Aertion being this, Cum tota vis hujus Elaterii pendeat à refutato jam aëris aequipondio cum digitis 29½ Argenti vivi, Pag. 20. ita ut nec plus net minus faciat hoe elaterium in loco occluo quam fit-per illud aequipondium in loco aperto; manifetum et, cum jam oftenum it fictitium planè ee hujumodi aequipondium, fictitium quo
que ee tale elaterium: This being no new Argument, but an Inference from thoe he had et down in the former Chapter, by our Anwers to them it is become needles for us to make any ditinct Reply to this. We hal rather deire the Reader to take notice, that whereas our Author ayes that according to his Adveraries, Ncc plus nec minus faciat hoc Elaterium in loco occluo quam fit per illud Aequipondium in loco aperto; whatever others may have written, we for our part allow of this Opinion but in ome Caes; for in others we have perform'd much more by the Spring of
the Air, which we can within certain limits increae at pleaure, then can be perform'd by the bare weight, which for ought we know remains alwayes omewhat near the ame. And of this advantage that the Spring of the Air may have in point of force above the weight of it, we have formerly given an Intance in our 17. Experiment, (where, by compreing the Air in the Receiver, we impell'd the Mercurial Cylinder higher then the tation at which the Counterpoie of the Air is wont to utain it) and hall hereafter have occaion to give yet more coniderable proofs. To the lately recited words our Examiner ubjoyns thee; Adde, cum allata jam capite praecedente experimenta de adhaeione digiti, &c. eodem modo e habent in Pag. 21. loco clauo ac in aperto, necearium ee facta ex eis argumenta contra aquipondium, eadem quo
que contra elaterium vim habere. But though he propoe this as a new Argument, yet ince 'tis built but upon the adheion of the Finger (of which we have already given an account in our Hypotheis) I ee not how it requires any new and particular Anwer. And whereas he ayes, that the Experiments he had mentioned concerning the adheion of ones Finger, &c. eodem modo e habent in loco clauo ac in aperto; I could wih he had added what way he took to make the Tryals. For he gives no intimation that he did them any other wayes then in ordinary rooms. And in uch there carce ever wants a communication betwixt the inward and outward Air, either at the Chimney, or Window, or Door not exactly hut, or at ome hole or crevice or other, by means of which the weight of the Atmophere has its operation within the room.

To his econd Argument our Author adds not a third, unles we take that for an Argument which he immediately annexes to his lat recited words: Et profectò (ayes he) i ecum expenderent hi Authores, quanta it difficultas explicandi hujumodi Pag. 21. aëris elaterium, nii idem aër e olo occupet majorem locum (ut paulo ante) credo eos ententiam facilè mutaturos. But this being aid gratis, does not exact an Anwer; and he mut make it more intelligible then any man that I know of has yet done,
how the ame Air can adequately fill more pace at one time then at another, before he perwade me to change my opinion about the Spring of the Air: Epecially ince he himelf allowes that the Air has a Spring, whereby it Pag. 11. is able, when it has been violently compres'd, to recover its due extenion; the manner whereof if he will intelligibly explicate, his Adveraries will have no great difficulty to make out the Spring of the Air. But whether his Hypotheis, or ours, be the more intelligible, will be more properly conidered in the econd part of our Dicoure, to which we will therefore now proceed.

argument.p: Wherein the Adveraries Funicular Hypotheis is examin'd.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: What is alledged to prove the Funiculus is conider'd; and ome Difficulties are propos'd againt the Hypotheis.

div.p: THe Hypotheis that the Examiner would, as a better, ubtitute in the place of ours, is, if I mitake it not, briefly this; That the things we acribe to the weight or pring of the Air are really perform'd by neither, but by a certain Funiculus, or extremely thin ubtance, provided in uch caes by Nature, ne detur vacuum, which being exceedingly rarefied by a forcible ditenion, does perpetually and trongly endeavour to contract it elf into dimenions more agreeable to the nature of the ditended body; and conequently does violently attract all the bodies whereunto it is contiguous, if they be not too heavy to be remov'd by it.

But this Hypotheis of our Authors does to me, I confes, appear liable to uch Exceptions, that though I dilik'd that of his Adveraries, yet I hould not imbrace his, but rather wait till
time and further Speculations or tryals hould ugget ome other Theory, fitter to be acquiec'd in then this; which eems to be partly precarious, partly unintelligible, and partly inufficient, and beides needles: though it will not be o convenient to prove each of thee apart, becaue divers of my Objections tend to prove the Doctrine, againt which they are alledged, obnoxious to more then one of the imputed Imperfections.

Firt, then, the Arguments by which our Author endeavours to evince his Funiculus, are incompetent for that end. The Arguments which he propoes in his ixth Chapter (where he undertakes to make good his Aertion) I there find to be three.

The firt he ets down in thee words, Contat hoc primò ex jam dictis Capite praecedente: nequit enim argentum decendens ic digitum deorum trahere, tubo
que affigere, nii à tali Pag. 24. Funiculo upendatur, eum
que uo pondere vehementer extendat, ut per e patet. But to this proof anwer has been made already in the former Part of this Dicoure: onely whereas the Author eems to refer us to the foregoing Chapter, we will look back to it, and take notice of what I find there againt the Vacuits. For though I neither am bound, nor intend, in this Dicoure to declare my elfe for, or againt, a Vacuum; yet ince I am now writing againt the Funicular Hypotheis. it will much conduce to hew that it is not firmly grounded, if I examine what he here alledges againt the Aertors of a Vacuum.

In the next place therefore I conider that, according to the Examiner, there can be no Vacuum; and that he makes to be the main reaon why Nature in the Torricellian and our Experiments does act after o extraordinary a manner, as is requiite to the production of his Funiculus. For in the 47. Page, having in his Adveraries name demanded what need there is at the decent of the Quickilver, that before it falls a uperficies hould be eparated from it, and extended; Repondeo (ayes he) ideo hoc fieri, ne detur vacuum; cum nihil aliud ibi adit quod loco argenti decendentis posit uccedere. To which he immediately ubjoyns, (with what cogency I will not now examine:) At
que hinc plane
confirmatur commune. illud per tot jam elapa ecula uurpalum in Scholis axi ••• a viz. Naturam à vacuo, abhorrere. And though he eem to make his Funiculus the immediate caue of the Phaenomena occurring in the Torricellian and our Experiments: yet that, if you purue the inquiry a little higher; he reolves them into Natures abhorrency of a Vacuum, himelf plainly informs us in the next page; Namlicet (ayes he) immediata ratiocur aqua v. g. ex hydria hortulana uperne claua (quo exemplo. Pag. 48. utuntun) non decendat, non it metus vacui, ed ea quam modo diximus, nempe quod non detur ufficiens pondus ad olvendum illum nexum quo adhaer eat aqua clauae hydriae ummitati; ad eam tamen rationem tandem neceario veniendumet. But, though as well our Author's Fumiculus, as the other carce conceivable Hypothees that learned men have devied, to account for the upenion of the Quickilver otherwie then by the reitance of the external Air, eem to have been excogitated onely to hun the neceity of admitting a Vacuum: yet I ee not how our Examiner cogently proves, either that there can be none in rerum naturâ, or that Defacto there is none produc'd in thee Experiments. For in his fifth Chapter (where he profeedly undertakes that task) he has but thee two incompetent Arguments. The firt is drawn from the attraction, as he uppoes, of the Finger into the deerted cavity of the Tube in the Torricellian Experiment: Quaequidem (ayes he) tam vehemens tractio & adhaeio, cum non nii à reali aliquo corpore inter digitum Pag. 22. & argentum contitutum queat provenire, manifetum et patium illud vacuum non ee, ed verâ aliquâ ubtantiâ repletum. But to this Argument having already given an Anwer, let us (without taying to urge, that the Vacuits will perhaps object, that they ee not a Neceity, though they hould admit of Traction in the cae, that the internal ubtance mut therefore perfectly replenih the deerted Cavity; without preing this, I ay, let us) conider his other, which he draws from the Diaphaneity of the deerted part of the Tube, which pace (he ayes) were it empty, would appear like a little black Pillar, Eo quod nullaepecies viuales
ne
que ab eo ne
que per illud pount ad oculum perventre. But (not to engage our elves in Optical Speculations and Controveries) if we grant him ome what more then perhaps he can prove; yet as the Experiment will not demontrate that there is nothing of body in any part of the pace deerted by the Mercury, o neither will the Argument conclude (as the Propoer of it does twice in this Chapter) That pace verâ aliquâ ubtantiâ repleri. For according to the Hypotheis of the Epicureans and other Atomits, who make Light to be a corporeal Effluvium from lucid bodies, and to conit of Atoms o minute, as freely to get in at the narrow Pores of Glas, there will be no caue to deny interpers'd Vacuities in the upper part of the Tube. For the Corpucles of Light that permeate that pace may be o numerous, as to leave no enible part of it un-inlightned; and yet may have o many little empty Intervals betwixt them, that, if all that is corporeal in the pace we peak of were united into one lump, it would not perhaps adequately fill the one half (not to ay the tenth, or even the hundredth part) of the whole pace: According to what we have noted in the 17. Experiment, that a Room may appear full of the moke of a Perfume, though if all the Corpucles that compoe that moke were re-united, they would again make up but a mall Patil. To which purpoe I remember I have taken Camphire, of which a little will fill a Room with its odour, and having in well-clos'd ditillatory Glaes caught the umes driven over by hear, I thereby reduc'd them to re conjoyn into true Camphire, whoe bulk is very inconiderable in comparion of the pace it fills as to ene, when the odorous Corpucles are cattered through the free Air.

To which I might adde, that the Torricellian Experiment being made in a dark night, or in a Room perfectly darken'd, if it ucceed (as there is little caue to upect it will not) it may well be doubted whether our Authors Argument will there take place. For if he endeavour to prove that the place in quetion was full in the dark, becaue upon the letting in of the Day, or the bringing in of a Candle, the light appears within it; the Vacuits may
reply according to their Hypotheis, That that light is a new one, flowing from the lucid body that darts its corporeal beams quite through the Glas and Space we dipute about, which for want of uch Corpucles were not jut before viible.

And uppoing light not to be made by a trajection of Atoms through Diaphanous bodies, but a propagation of the impule of lucid bodies through them; yet it will not thence necearily follow, that the deerted part of the Tube mut be full: As in our 27. Experiment (though many of thoe gros Aerial Particles that appear'd neceary to convey a languid ound were drawn out of our Receiver at the firt and econd Exuction; yet there remain'd o many of the like Corpucles, that thoe that were wanting were not mis'd by the ene, though afterwards, when a far greater number was drawn out, they were) o there may be matter enough remaining to tranmit the impule of light; though betwixt the Particles of that matter there hould be tore of vacuities intercepted. Whereas our Author pretends to prove, not onely that there is no coacervate Vacuity in the pace o often mentioned, but abolutely that there is none. For 'tis in this lat ene, as well as the other, that the Schools and our Author, who defends their Opinion, deny a Vacuum.

But notwithtanding what we have now dicours'd, as in our 17. Experiment we declin'd determining whether there be a Vacuum or no; o now what we have aid to the Examiners Argument, has not been to declare our whole ene of the Controverie, but onely to hew, that though his Hypotheis uppoes there is no Vacuum, yet his Arguments do not ufficiently prove it: which may help to hew his Doctrine to be precarious; for otherwie the Carteians, though Plenits, may plauibly enough (whether truly or no I now dipute not) decline the neceity of admitting a Vacuum in the deerted pace of the Tube, by uppoing it fill'd with their econd and firt Element, whoe Particles they imagine to be minute enough freely to pas in and out through the Pores of Glas. But then they mut allow the preure of the outward Air to be the caue of the upenion of the
Quickilver: for though the materia coeletis may readily fill the paces the Mercury deerts; yet that within the Tube cannot binder o ponderous a liquor from ubiding as low as the retagnant Mercury; ince all the parts of the Tube, as well the lowermot as the uppermot, being pervious to that ubtile matter, it may with like facility ucceed in whatever part of the Tube hall be for aken by the Quickilver.

The Examiners econd Argument in the ame place is, That ince the Mercurial Cylinder is not utain'd by the outward Air, it mut necearily be, that it be kept upended by his internal tring. But ince for the proof of this he is content to refer us to the third Chapter; our having already examin'd that, allows us to proceed to his third Argument, which is, That the Mercurial Cylinder, reting in its wonted tation, does not gravitate: as may appear by applying the Finger to the immers'd or lower Orifice of the Tube. Whence he infers, that it mut of neceity be upended from within the Tube. And indeed if you dexterouly apply your Finger to the open end of the Tube, when you have almot, but not quite, lifted it out of the retagnant Mercury, (which circumtance mut not be neglected, though our Author have omitted it) that o you may hut up no more Quickilver then the Mercurial Cylinder is wont to conit of, you will find the Experiment to ucceed well enough: (Which makes me omewhat wonder to find it affirm'd, that the learned Maignan denies it) not but that you will feel upon your Finger a gravitation or preure of the Glas-Tube, and the contained Mercury, as of one body; but that you will not feel any enible preure of the Mercury apart, as if it endeavoured to thrut away your Finger from the Tube. But the reaon of this is not hard to give in our Hypotheis; for according to that, the Mercurial Cylinder and the Air counterpoiing one another, the Finger utains not any enibly-differing preure from the ambient Air that prees againt the Nail and ides of it, and from the included Quickilver that prees againt the Pulp. But if the Mercurial Cylinder hould exceed the uual length, then the Finger would
feel ome preure from that urpluage of Quickilver, which the Air does not ait the Finger to utain. So that this pleaant Phaenomenon may be as well olv'd in our Hypotheis, as in the Examiners: in which if we had time to clear an Objection, which we fore-ee might be made, but might be anwer'd too; we would demand why, when the Mercury included in the Tube is but of a due altitude, it hould run out upon the removal of the Finger that tops it beneath, in cae it be utain'd onely by the internal Funiculus, and do, according to his Doctrine, when the Funiculus utains it, emulate a olid body, if the preure of the external Air has not (as our Author teaches it not to have) any thing to do in this matter.

And if ome inquiitive peron hall here object, That certainly the Finger mut feel much pain by being queez'd betwixt two uch preures, as that of a Pillar of thirty Inches of Quick-ilver on the one ide, and an equivalent preure from the Atmopherical Pillar on the other, it may readily be repreented, that in fluid bodies (uch as are thoe concern'd in our Difficulty) a olid body has no uch ene of preure from the ambient bodies as (unles Experience had otherwie intructed us) we hould perhaps imagine. For, not to mention that having inquired of a famous Diver, whether he found himelf enibly compreed by the water at the bottom of the Sea; he agreed with the generality of Divers in the Negative: I am inform'd that the learned Maignan did purpoely try, that his hand being thrut three or four Palmes deep into Quickilver, his fingers were not enible, either of any weight from the incumbent, or of any preure from the ambient, Quickilver. The reaon of which (whether that inquiitive man have given it or no) is not neceary in our preent Controverie to be lookt after.

To thee three Arguments the Examiner addes not a fourth, unles he deign to preent it us in this concluding paage: Huc etiam faciunt inignes librationes quibus argentum ubito decendens agitatur: Idem enim hic fit quod in aliis Pendulis Pag. 25. & ab alto demisis fieri olet. But of this Phaenomenon alo
'tis eaie to give an account in our Hypotheis by two everal wayes; whereof the Firt (which is proper chiefly when the Experiment is made in a cloe place, as our Receiver) is, That the Quickilver by its udden decent acquires an impetus uperadded to the preure it has upon the core of its wonted gravity; whereby it for a while falls below its tation, and thereby comprees the Air that leans upon the retagnant Mercury. Which Air by its own Spring again forcibly dilating it elf to recover its former extenion, and (as is uual in Springs) hatily flying open, expands it elf beyond it, and thereby impells up the Quickilver omewhat above its wonted tation, in its fall from whence it again acquires omewhat (though not o much as before) of impetus or power, to force the Corpucles of the Air to a Sub-ingreion; and this reciprocation of preure betwixt the Quickilver and the outward Air decreaing by degrees, does at length wholly ceae, when the Mercury has lot that uperadded preure, which it acquired by its falling from parts of the Tube higher then its due tation. But this firt way of explicating thee Vibrations is not neceary in the free Air: for if we conider the ambient Air onely as a weight, and remember what we have newly aid of the impetus acquir'd by decent; this Phaenomenon may be eaily enough explain'd, by taking notice of what happens in a Balance, when one of the equiponderant Scales chancing to be depres'd, they do not till after many Vibrations ettle in aequilibrio.

And on this occaion I hall adde this Experiment: I took a Glas Pipe, whoe two legs (very unequal in length) were parallel enough, and both perpendicular to that part of the Pipe that connected them, (uch a Syphon is decrib'd in our 36. Experiment, to find the proportion of the gravity of Mercury and Water) into this Quickilver was pour'd till 'twas ome Inches high, and equally high in both legs: then the Pipe being inclin'd till the mot part of the Quickilver was fallen into one of the legs, I topt the Orifice of the other leg with my Finger, and erecting again the Pipe, though the Quickilver were forc'd to acend a
little in that topt leg; yet by reaon my Finger kept the Air from getting away, the Quickilver was kept lower by a good deal in that topt leg then in the other; but if by uddenly removing my Finger I gave paage to the included and omewhat compret Air, the preponderant Quickilver in the other leg would with the Mercury in this untopt leg, make divers undulations before that liquor did in both legs come to ret in an aequilibrium. Of which the Reaon may be eaily deduc'd from what has been newly deliver'd; and yet in this cae there is no pretence to be made of a Funiculus of violently ditended Air to effect the Vibrations of the Mercury.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Divers other Difficulties are objected againt the Funicular Hypotheis.

div.p: THirdly, But though our Examiner have not ufficiently proved his Hypotheis, yet perhaps it may be in its own nature o like to be true, as to deerve to be imbrac'd as uch. Wherefore we will now take notice of ome of thoe many things that to our apprehenion render it very improbable.

And firt, whereas our Author acknowledges that Quickilver, Water, Wine, and other liquors, will, as well one as another, decend in Tubes exactly ealed at the top, in cae the Cylinder of liquor exceed the weight of a Mercurial Cylinder of 29½. Inches; and will ubide no longer then till it is come to equiponderate a Cylinder of Quickilver of that height; whereas, I ay, the Examiner is by the ingenious Monieur Pachall's, and other Experiments, induc'd to admit this; it cannot but eem trange that, whatever the liquor be, there hould be jut the ame weight or trength to extend them into a Funiculus: though Water, for intance, and Quickilver be near fourteen times as heavy one as the other, and be otherwie of very ditant
natures; and though divers other liquors, as Oyle and Water, be likewie of Textures very differing. And this may omewhat the more be wondred at, becaue our Author (in his Animadverions upon our 31. Experiment) is pleaed to make o great a difference betwixt the dipoition of bodies of various conitences, as fluid and firm, to be extenuated into a Funiculus, that he will not allow any humane force to be able to produce one, by the divulion of two flat Marbles, in cae the contact of their Surfaces were o exquiite as quite to exclude all Air; though in the ame place his Ratiocination plainly enough teaches (which Experience however does) that adhering Marbles, though with extraordinary difficulty, may be forcibly ever'd, and according to him the uperficial parts may be ditended into a Funiculus, that prevents a Vacuum.

But now the Hypotheis of his Adveraries is not at all incumbred with this difficulty. For the weight of the outward Air being that which keeps liquors upended in Tubes ealed at the top; it matters not of what nature or texture the upended liquor is, provided its weight be the ame with that of a Mercurial Cylinder equiponderant to the Aerial one: As if there be a pound of Lead in one Scale, it will not detroy the aequilibrium, whether what be put in the other be Gold, or Quickilver, or Wooll, or Feathers, provided its weight be jut a pound.

In the next place we may take notice, That the account our Examiner gives us of his Funiculus in the tenth Chapter, (where he takes upon him to explicate it) is much more trange then atisfactory, and not made out by any uch parallel operations of Nature, as his Adveraries will not (and may not well do it) dipute the truth of. Whereas the Weight and Spring of the Air may be inferr'd from uch unquetion'd Experiments as are not concern'd in our preent Controverie. For the gravity of the Air may be manifeted by a pair of Scales, & the Spring of it dicloes it elf o clearly in wind-guns and other Intruments, that our Adverary (as we have already had occaion to inculcate) does not deny it. But to conider his Explication of his Funiculus, he
would have us note two things: Firt, Argentum dum replet totum tubum, non mere tangere ejus ummitatem (ut Pag. 38. primo apectu videtur) ed eidem quo
que firmiter adhaerere. Patet hoc (ubjoyns he) experimento illo in primo argumento capit is tertii de tubo utrin
que aperto. But what is to be anwer'd to this proof may be eaily gathered from what we have replyed to that Argument. And to what our Author addes to prove, That the adheion of the Finger is to the ubjacent Mercury, not to the Tube; namely, That Licet illud tubi orificium oleo, aliâve materiâ adhaeionem impediente, inungatur, non minus tamen firmiter Pag. 38. adhaerebit digitus quàm priùs; an Anwer may be drawn from the ame place; nor perhaps will his reaoning much atisfie thoe who conider that bodies by truion may eaily enough be made tick together, as much as in our cae the Tube and Finger do, notwithtanding one of them is anoynted with Oyle, and that this Adheion of the Finger to the Tube is to be met with in caes where the Surface of the included Quickilver is not contiguous to the Finger, but many Inches below. As for what he addes concerning the reaon why Water, and Quickilver acend by uction, we have already taught what is to be anwered to it, by acribing that acenion to the preure of the external Air: without any need of having recoure to a Funiculus; or imagining with him in this place, That becaue nothing beides the Water or Quickilver can in uch caes ucceed, the Air, (which yet is not eaie to be prov'd in reference to a thin Aethereal ubtance) therefore, Partes ipius aëris (to ue his expreion) ic tubo incluae (quae aliàs tam facile eparantur) Pag. 40. nunc tam fortiter ibi invicem agglutinentur, ut validisimum (uti videmus) conficiunt catenam, qua non olum aqua, ed ponderoum illud argentum ic in altum trahatur. Which way of wreathing a little rarefied Air into o trong a rope, how probable it is, I will for a while leave the Reader to judge, and advance to our Author's econd Notandum, which he thus propoes:

Rarefactionem ive extenionem corporis ad occupandum majorem locum fieri non olo calore, ed etiam ditenione Pag. 40, 41.
eu vi divulivâ: icut è contra condenatio non olo frigore perficitur, ed etiam compresione, uti innumera pasim docent exempla. And 'tis true and obvious, that the Condenation of bodies, taking that word in a large ene, may be made as well by compreion as cold. But I wih he had more clearly expret what he means in this place by that Rarefaction, which he ayes is to be made by ditenion, or a vis divuliva, whereof he tells us there are innumerable intances. For, as far as may be gathered from the three Examples he ubjoyns, 'tis onely the Air that is capable of being o extended as his Hypotheis requires Quickilver and even Stones mut be. And I know not how it will be proved, that even Air may be thus extended o far, as in the Magdeburg Experiment, to fill a place more then two thouand times as big as that it fill'd before. For that the ame Air in this and his two foregoing Intances does adequately fill more pace at one time then another, he proves but by the ruhing in of water into the evacuated Glas, and filling it within a little quite full, which, he ayes, is done by the ditended Air that contracting it elf draws up the water with it. Which Explication how much les likely it is, then that the water is in uch caes impell'd up by the preure of the Atmophere, we hall anon (when we come to dicus his way of Rarefaction and Condenation) have occaion to examine. In the mean time let us conider with him the Explication which, after having premis'd the two above recited Obervations, he gives us of his Funiculus; Cum per primum Notandum argentum ita adhaereat tubi vertici, & per ecundum, rarefactio fiat per meram Pag. 41. corporis ditenionem, ita rem e habere, ut argentum decendens à vertice tubi affixam ei relinquat uperficiem uam extimam ive upremam, eam
que eou
que uo pondere extendat extenuetque, donec facilius it aliam uperficiem imiliter relinquere quam priorem illam ulterius extendere: Secundam igitur relinquit, eam
que eodem modo decendendo extendit, donec facilius it tertiam adhuc eparari quam illam ecundam extendere ulterius: & ic deinceps, donec tandem vires amplius non habeat uperficies ic eparandi & extendendi; nempe
donec perveniat ad altitudinem digitorum duntaxat 29½, ubi quiecit, ut capite primo dictum est. Thus far our Examiners Explication: By which 'tis eaie to dicern, that he is fain to aigne his Funiculus a way of being produc'd trange and unparallell'd enough. For, not to repeat our Animadverions upon the firt of the two Notandum's, on which the Explication is grounded, I mut demand by what force, upon the bare eparation of the Quickilver and the top of the Tube, the new body he mentions comes to be produc'd; or at leat how it appears that the Mercury leaves any uch thing as he peaks of behind it. For the ene perceives no uch matter at the top of the Tube, nor is it neceary to explicate the Phaenomena as we have formerly een. It may alo be marvell'd at, that the bare weight of the decending Mercury hould be able to extend a Surface into a Body. And beides, it eems precariouly affirm'd, that there is uch a ucceive leaving behind of one Surface after another as is here imagin'd: Nor does it at all appear how, though ome of the Quickilver were turn'd into a thin ubtile ubtance, yet that ubtance comes to be contriv'd into a Funiculus of o trange a nature, that carce any weight (for ought appears by his Doctrine) can be able to break it; that contrary to all other trings it may be tr •••• ed without being made more lender; and that it has other very odde properties, ome of which we hall anon have occaion to mention. As for what our Author ubjoynes in thee words, Eodem ita
que fere modo eparari videntur hae uperficies ab argento decendente, & Pag. 43, 44. in tenuisimum quendam per decendens pondus extendi, quo per calorem in accena candela eparantur hujumodi uperficies à ubjecta cera aut evo, & in ubtilisimam flammam extenuantur. Ubi not atu dignum, quemadmodum flamma illa pluquam millies ine dubio majus patium occupat, quàm antea occupaverat pars illa cerae ex qua conficitur; ita prorus & his exitimandum Funiculum illum pluquam millies majus patium occupare quàm prius occupaverat illa argenti particula ex qua it exortus: Uti etiam ine dubio contingit, quando talis particula à ubjecto igne in vaporem convertitur.
Though it be the onely Example whereby he endeavours to illutrate the generation of his Funiculus, yet (I preume) he carce expects we hould think it an appoite one. For, beides that there here intervenes a conpicuous and powerful Agent, namely, an actual Fire to ever and agitate the parts of the Candle; and beides that there is a manifet wating of the Wax or Tallow turn'd into flame; beides thee things, I ay, we mut not admit, that the Fuel when turn'd into a flame does really fill (I ay not, with our Author) more then a thouand times, but o much as twice more of genuine pace then the Wax 'twas made of. For it may be aid that the flame is little or nothing ele then an aggregate of thoe Corpucles which before lay upon the upper uperficies of the Candle, and by the violent heat were divided into minuter particles, vehemently agitated and brought from lying as it were upon a flat to beat off one another, and make up about the Wiek uch a figure as is uual in the flame of Candles burning in the free Air. Nor will it necearily follow, that the pace which the flame eems to take up hould contain neither Air nor Aether, nor any thing ele, ave the parts of that flame, becaue the eye cannot dicern any other body there: For even the moke acending from the nuff of a newly-extinguih'd Candle appears a dark pillar, which to the eye at ome ditance eems to conit of moke; whenas yet there are o many Aerial and other inviible Corpucles mingled with it, as if all thoe parts of moke that make a great how in the Air were collected and contiguous, they would not perhaps amount to the bignes of a Pins head: as may appear by the great quantity of teams that in Chymical Veels are wont to go to the making up of one drop of Spirit.
