And therefore it does not ill fall out for our turn, that the Examiner, to inforce his former Example, alledges the turning of a particle of Quickilver into vapour, by putting fire under it: for if uch be the Rarefaction of Mercury, 'tis not at all like to make uch a Funiculus as he talks of, ince thoe Mercurial Fumes appear by divers Experiments, to be Mercury divided and thrown abroad into minute parts, whereby
though the body obtain more of Surface then it had before, yet it really fills no more of true and genuine pace, ince if all the particular little paces fill'd by thee catter'd Corpucles were reduc'd into one, (as the Corpucles themelves often are in Chymical Operations) they would amount but to one total pace, equal to that of the whole Mercury before rarefaction. But thee Objections againt this Explication are not all that I have to ay againt our Adveraries Funiculus it elf.

For I farther demand how the Funiculus comes by uch hooks or graple-irons, or parts of the like hape, to take fat hold of all contiguous bodies, and even the moothet, uch as Glas, and the calm urfaces of Quickilver, Water, Oyle, and other fluids: And how thee lender and inviible hooks cannot onely in the teret bodies find an innumerable company of ears or loops to take hold on, but hold o trongly that they are able not alone to lift up a tall Cylinder of that very ponderous metall of Quickilver, but to draw inwards the ides of trong Glaes o forcibly, as to break them all to pieces. And 'tis alo omewhat trange, that Water and other fluid bodies (whoe parts are wont to be o eaily eparable) hould, when the Funiculus once layes hold on the uperficial Corpucles, preently emulate the nature of conitent bodies, and be drawn up like Maes each of them of an intire piece; though even in the exhauted Receiver they appear by their undulation (when they are tir'd by Bubbles that pas freely through them) and many other igns to continue fluid bodies.

It eems alo very difficult to conceive how this extenuated ubtance hould acquire o trong a pring inward as the Examiner all along his book acribes to it. Nor will it erve his turn to require of us in exchange an Explication of the Airs pring outward, ince he acknowledges, as well as we, that it has uch a pring. I know, that by calling this extenuated ubtance a Funiculus, he eems plainly to intimate that it has its pring inward, upon the ame account that Lute-trings and Ropes forcibly tretch'd have theirs. But there is no mall diparity betwixt
them: for whereas in trings there is requir'd either wreathing, or ome peculiar and artificial texture of the component parts; a rarefaction of Air (were it granted) does not include or infer any uch contrivance of parts as is requiite to make bodies Elatical. And if the Carteian Notion of the caue of Springines be admitted, then our extenuated ubtance having no Pores to be pervaded by the materia ubtilis (to which beides our Author alo makes Glas impervious) will be detitute of Springines. And however, ince Lute-trings, Ropes, &c. mut, when they hrink inwards, either fill up or leen their Pores, and increae in thicknes as they diminih in length; our Examiners Funiculus mut differ very much from them, ince it has no Pores to receive the hrinking parts, and contracts it elf as to length, without increaing its thicknes. Nor can it well be pretended that this elf-contraction is done ob fugam vacui, ince though it hould not be made, a Vacuum would not enue. And if it be aid that it is made that the preternaturally tretch'd body might retore it elf to its natural dimenions: I anwer, That I am not very forward to allow acting for ends to bodies inanimate, and conequently devoid of knowledge; and therefore hould gladly ee ome unquetionable Examples produc'd of Operations of that nature. And however to me, who in Phyical enquiries of this nature look for efficient rather then final caues, 'tis not eaie to conceive how Air by being expanded (in which cae its force (like that of other rarify'd bodies) eems principally to tend outwards, as we ee in fired Gun-powder, in Aeolipiles, in warm'd Weather-glaes, &c.) hould acquire o prodigious a force of moving contiguous bodies inwards. Nor does it to me eem very probable, that, when for intance part of a polih'd Marble is extended into a Funiculus, that Funiculus does o trongly apire to turn into Marble again. I might likewie wih our Author had more clearly explicated, how it comes to pas (which he all along takes for granted) that the acces of the outward Air does o much and o uddenly relax the tenion of his Funiculus; ince that being (according to him) a real and
Poreles body, 'tis not o obvious how the preence of another can o eaily and to o trange a degree make it hrink. But I will rather oberve, that 'tis very unlikely that the pace which our Adverary would have replenih'd with his Funicular ubtance, hould be full of little highly-tretcht trings, that lay fat hold of the Surfaces of all contiguous bodies, and alwayes violently endeavour to pull them inwards. For we have related in our 26. Experiment, that a Pendulum being et a moving in our exhauted Receiver, did wing to and fro as freely, and with the tring tretch'd as treight, as for ought we could perceive it would have done in the common Air. Nay, the Balance of a Watch did there move freely and nimbly to and fro; which 'tis hard to conceive thoe bodies could do, if they were to break through a medium coniting of innumerable exceedinglytretch'd trings. On which occaion we might adde, that 'tis omewhat trange that thee trings, thus cut or broken by the paage of thee bodies through them, could o readily have their parts re-united, and without any more ado be made intire again. And we might alo take notice of this as another trange peculiarity in our Authors Funiculus, That in this cae the two divided parts of each mall tring that is broken do not, like thoe of other broken trings, hrink and fly back from one another; but (as we jut now aid) immediately redintegrate themelves: Whereas, when in the Torricellian Experiment the Tube and contain'd Mercury is uddenly lifted up out of the retagnant Quickilver into the Air, the Funiculus does o trangely contract it elf, that it quite vanihes; inomuch that the acending Mercury may rie to the very top of the Tube. Thee, I ay, and divers other difficulties might on this occaion be inited on; but that, uppoing our elves to have mentioned enough of them for once, we think it now more eaonable to proceed to the remaining Part of our Dicoure.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: The Aritotelean Rarefaction (propoed by the Adverary) examin'd.

div.p: BUt this is not all that renders the Examiners Hypotheis improbable: For, beides thoe already mentioned particulars, upon whoe core it is very difficult to be undertood; it necearily uppoes uch a Rarefaction and Condenation, as is, I confes, to me, as well as to many other conidering perons, unintelligible.

For the better dicernment of the force of this Objection we mut briefly premie, That a body is commonly aid to be rarefi'd or dilated, (for I take the word in a larger ene then, I know, many others do, for a reaon that will quickly appear) when it acquires greater dimenions then the ame body had before; and to be condens'd, when it is reduc'd into les dimenions, that is, into a leer pace then it contain'd before: (as when a dry Spunge being firt dipp'd in water wells to a far greater bulk, and then being trongly queez'd and held compreed, is not onely reduced into les room then it had before it was queezed, but into les then it had even before it was wetted.) And I mut further premie, That Rarefaction (as alo Condenation) being amongt the mot obvious Phaenomena of Nature, there are three (and for ought we know but three) wayes of explicating it: For, either we mut ay with the Atomits and Vacuits, that the Corpucles whereof the rarefied body conits do o depart from each other, that no other ubtance comes in between them to fill up the deerted paces that come to be left betwixt the incontiguous Corpucles; or ele we mut ay with divers of the ancient Philoophers, and many of the moderns, epecially the Carteians, that thee new Intervals produced betwixt the Particles of the rarefied body are but dilated Pores, replenihed,
in like manner as thoe of the tumid Spunge are by the imbibed water, by ome ubtile Aethereal ubtance, that ininuates it elf betwixt the disjoyned Particles: or, latly, we mut imagine with Aritotle and mot of his followers, that the elf-ame body does not onely obtain a greater pace in Rarefaction, and a leer in Condenation, but adequately and exactly fill it, and o when rarefied acquires larger dimenions without either leaving any vacuities betwixt its component Corpucles, or admitting between them any new or extraneous ubtance whatoever.

Now 'tis to this lat (and, as ome call it, rigorous) way of Rarefaction that our Adverary has recoure in his Hypotheis: Though this, I confes, appear to me o difficult to be conceived, that I make a doubt whether any Phaenomenon can be explained by it; ince to explain a thing is to deduce it from omething or other in Nature more known then it elf.

He that would meet with full Dicuions of this Aritotelean Rarefaction, may reort to the learned writings of Gaendus, Carteius and Maignan, who have accued it of divers great aburdities: But for my part, I hall at preent content my elf to make ue to my purpoe of two or three paages that I meet with (though not together) in our Author himelf.

Let us then uppoe, that in the Magdeburg Experiment he o often (though I think caulely enough) urges to prove his Hypotheis; let us (I ay) for eaier coniderations ake uppoe, that the undilated Air, which (as he tells us) poeed about half an Inch of pace, conited of a hundred Corpucles, Pag. 42. or (if that name be in this cae diliked) a hundred parts; (for it matters not what number we pitch upon) and 'twill not be denyed, but that as the whole parcel of Air, or the Aggregate of this hundred Corpucles, is adequate to the whole pace it fills, o each of the hundred parts, that make it up, is likewie adequately commenurate to its peculiar pace, which we here uppoe to be a hundredth part of the whole pace. This premied, our Author having elewhere this paage, Corpore occupante locum verbi gratia duplo majorem, necee et Pag. 160.
ut quaelibet ejus pars locum quo
que duplo majorem occupet; prompts us to ubjoyn, that in the whole capacity of the Globe (which according to him was two thouand times as great as the room poeed by the unexpanded Air) there mut likewie be two hundred thouand parts of pace commenurate each of them to one of the fore-mentioned hundredth parts of Air; and conequently, when he affirms that that half Inch of Air poeed the whole cavity of the Globe, if we will not admit (as he does not) either Vacuities or ome intervening ubtile ubtance in the Interval of the Aeriall parts, he mut give us leave to conclude, that each part of Air does adequately fill two thouand parts of pace. Now that this hould be reolutely taught to be not onely naturally posible, (for we dipute not here of what the Divine Omnipotence can do) but to be really and regularly done in this Magdeburg Experiment, will quetionles appear very aburd to the Carteians and thoe other Philoophers, who take Extenion to be but notionally different from Body, and conequently impoible to be acquir'd or lot without the addition or detraction of Matter; and will, I doubt not, appear trange to thoe other Readers, who conider how generally Naturalits have looked upon Extenion as ineparable, and as immediately flowing from matter; & upon Bodies, as having neceary relation to a commenurate pace. Nor do I ee, if one portion of Air may o eaily be brought exactly to fill up a pace two thouand times as big as that which it did but fill before without the addition of any new ubtance; I ee not (I ay) why the matter contained in every of thee two thouand parts of pace may not be further brought to fill two thouand more, and o onwards, ince each of thee newly-replen hed paces is preumed to be exactly filled with Body, and no pace, nor conequently that which the unrarefied Air replenihed, can be more then adequately full. And ince, according to our Adverary, not onely fluid bodies, as Air and Quickilver, but even olid and hard ones, as Marble, are capable of uch a Ditenion as we peak of, why may not the World be made I know not how many thouand times bigger
then it is, without either admitting any thing of Vacuity betwixt its parts, or being increaed with the addition of one Atome of new matter? Which to me is o difficult to conceive, that I have ometimes doubted, whether in cae it could be proved, that in the exhauted Globe we peak of there were no Vacuities within, nor any ubtile matter permitted to enter from without, it were not more intelligible to uppoe that God had created a new matter to joyn with the Air in filling up the Cavity, then that the elf-ame Air hould adequately fill two thouand paces, whereof one was exactly commenurate to it even when it was uncompreed. For divers eminent Naturalits, both ancient and modern, believing upon a Phyical account the Souls of men to be created and infued, will admit it as intelligible that God does frequently create ubtances on certain emergent occaions. But I know that many of them will not likewie think it conceivable, that without his immediate interpoition an acceion of new, real Dimenions hould be had without either vacuities or acceion of matter.

And indeed when I conidered thee difficulties and others, that attend the Rarefaction our Examiner throughout his whole book uppoes, and when I found that ever and anon he remits us to what he teaches concerning Rarefaction; I could not but with ome greedines reort to the Chapters he addreed me to. But when I had perued them, I found the Difficulties remained uch till, and that 'twas very hard even for a witty man to make more of a ubject then the nature of it does bear. Which I ay, that by profeing my elf unatisfied with what he writes, I may not be thought to find fault with a man for not doing what perhaps is not to be done, and for not making uch abtrue Notions plain, as are carcely (if at all) o much as intelligible. And indeed as he has handled this ubject modetly enough, o in ome places his Expreions are to me omewhat dark; which I mention, not to impute it as a Crime in him, that he wrote in a diffident and doubtful train of o difficult a matter, but to excue my elf if I have not alwayes gueed aright at his meaning.

The things he alledges in favour of the Rarefaction he would perwade are two: The one, That the Phaenomena of Rarefaction cannot be explicated either by Vacuities or the ubingreion of an Aethereal ubtance; and the other, That there are two wayes of explicating the rigorous Rarefaction he contends for.

His Objections againt the Epicurean and Carteian wayes of making out Rarefaction are ome of them more plauible then mot of thoe that are wont to be urged againt them; yet not uch as are not capable enough of Anwers. But whilet ome of the paages appeared eaie to be replyed to by the Favourers of the Hypotheis they oppoe, before I had fully examined the ret, chancing to mention thee Chapters to an ingenious Man, hereafter to be further mentioned in this Treatie; he told me he had o far conidered them more then the ret of the book, that he had thought upon ome Hypothees, whereby the Phaenomena of Rarefaction might be made out either according to the Vacuits, or according to the Carteians, adding, that he had alo examined the Intance our Adverary pretends to be afforded him of his Rarefaction by what happens in the Rota Aristotelica. Wherefore being ufficiently ditreed by Avocations of everal orts, and being willing to reerve the Declaration of my own thoughts concerning the manner of Rarefaction and Condenation for another Treatie, I hall refer the Reader to the ingenious Conjectures about this ubject, which the writer of them intends to annex to the preent Dicoure; and onely adde in general, That whereas the Examiners Argument on this occaion is, That his way of Rarefaction mut be admitted, becaue neither of the other two can be well made out, his Adveraries may with the ame reaon argue that one of theirs is to be allowed, ince his is incumbred with uch manifet difficulties. And they may enforce what they ay by repreenting, that the inconveniences that attend his Hypotheis about Rarefaction are inuperable, ariing from the unintelligible nature of the thing itelf; whereas thoe to which the other wayes are obnoxious, may eem to pring but from mens not having yet dicovered
what kind of Figures and Motions of the mall Particles may bet qualifie them to make the body that conits of them capable of a competent expanion.

After our Authors Objections againt the two wayes of Rarefaction propoed, the one by the Vacuits, and the other by the Carteians and others, that admit the olidet bodies, and even Glas itelf, to be pervious to an Aethereal or ubtile matter; he attempts to explicate the manner by which that rigorous Rarefaction he teaches is perform'd: and having premied, that the Explication of the way how each part of the rarefy'd body becomes extended, depends upon the quality of the parts into which the body is ultimately reolv'd; and having truly oberv'd, that they mut necearily be either really indiviible, or till endlely diviible; he endeavours to explicate the Aristotelean Rarefaction according to thoe two Hypothees. But, though he thus propoe two wayes of making out his Rarefaction; yet beides that they are irreconcilable, he peaks of them o darkly and doubtfully, that it eems les eaie to dicern which of the two he would be content to tick to, then that he himelf carce acquieces in either of them.

And, firt, having told us how Rarefaction may be explain'd, in cae we admit bodies to be diviible in infinitum, he does himelf make uch an Objection againt the infinity of parts in a continuum, as he is fain to give o obcure an Anwer to, that I confes I do not undertand it; and preume, that not onely the mot part of unprejudiced Readers will as little acquiece in the Anwer as I do; but even the Author himelf will not marvel at my confeion, ince in the ame place he acknowledges the Anwer to be omewhat obcure, and endeavours to excue its being o, becaue in that Hypotheis it can carce be otherwie.

Wherefore I hall onely adde on this occaion, that 'tis not clear to me, that even uch a diviibility of a continuum as is here uppoed would make out the Rarefaction he contends for. For, let the integrant parts of a continuum be more or les finite or
infinite in number, yet till each part, being a corporeal ubtance, mut have ome Particle of pace commenurate to it; and if the whole body be rarefied, for intance, to twice its former bignes, then will each part be likewie extended to double its former dimenions, and fill both the place it took up before, and another equal to it, and o two places.

The econd Argument alledged to recommend the hithertomentioned way of explicating Rarefaction is, That many learned men, amongt whom he names two, Aquinas and Suarez, have taught that the ame corporeal thing may naturally be, and de facto often is, in the ouls of Brutes really indiviible and virtually extended. But, though I pay thoe two Authors a jut repect for their great skill in Scholatical and Metaphyical learning; yet the Examiner cannot ignore, that I could make a long Catalogue of Writers, both ancient and modern, at leat as well vers'd in natural Philoophy as St. Thomas and Suarez, who have ome of them in expres words denyed this to be naturally poible; and others have declared themelves of the ame judgment by etablihing principles, with which this Conceit of the virtual extenion of the indiviible Corpucles is abolutely inconitent. And though no Author had hitherto oppoed it, yet I, that dipute not what this or that man thought, but what 'tis rational to think, hould nevertheles not cruple to reject it now; and hould not doubt to find tore of the bet Naturalits of the ame opinion with me, and perhaps among them the Examiner himelf, who (however this acknowledgment may agree with the three following Chapters of his book) tells us, (pag. 160.) that Juxia probabiliorem ententiam hujumodi virtualis extenio rei corporea concedenda non et, ut pote oli rei pirituali propria.

But to conclude at length this tedious Enquiry into the Aritotelean way of Rarefaction, (which is of o obcure a nature that it can carce be either propoed or examined in few words) I will not take upon me reolutely to affirm which of the two wayes of explicating it (by Atomes or by Parts infinitely diviible) our Author declares himelf for. But which of them oever it be,
I think I have hown that he has not intelligibly made it out : And I make the les cruple to do o, becaue he himelf is o ingenuous as (at the cloe of his dicoure of the two wayes) to peak thus of the Opinion he prefers; Praetat communi & receptae hactenus in Scholis ententiae initere, quae licet Pag. 169. difficultates quidem non clarè olvat, its tamen aperte non uccumbit. So that in this dicoure of Rarefaction, to which our Author has o often in the fore-going part of the Book referred us, as that which hould make good what there eemed the mot improbable; he has but intead of a probable Hypotheis needlely rejected, ubtituted a Doctrine which himelf dares not pretend capable of being well freed from the difficulties with which it may be charged; though I doubt not but other Readers, epecially Naturalits, will think he has been very civil to this obcure Doctrine, in aying that Difficultatibus non aperte uccumbit.

As for the other way of explicating Rarefaction, namely, by uppoing that a body is made up of parts indiviible; he will not, I preume, deny, but that the Objections we formerly made againt it are weighty. For according to this Hypotheis (which one would think he prefers, ince he makes ue of it in the three or four lat Chapters of his Book) Neceariò fatendum et (ayes he) unam eandem
que partem poni in duplici Pag. 163. loco adaequate: Cum enim indiviibilis it, locum
que occupet majorem quam prius, necee et ut tota it in quolibet puncto totius loci, ive ut per totum illud patium virtualiter extendatur. So that when he in the very next page affirms, that by this virtual extenion of the parts, the Difficulties that have for o many Ages troubled Philoophers may be eaily olved, he mut give me leave (who love to peak intelligibly, and not to admit what I cannot undertand) to deire he would explain to me what this extenio virtualis is, and how it will remove the Difficulties that I formerly charged upon the Aritotelean Rarefaction. For the eaier conideration of this matter, let us reume what we lately uppoed, namely, that in the Magdeburgick Experiment the half Inch of undilated Air conited of a hundred Corpucles; I demand how
the indiviibility of thee Corpucles will qualifie them to make out uch a Rarefaction as the Author imagines. For what does their being indiviible do in this cae, but make it the les intelligible how they can fill above a hundred parts of pace? 'Tis eaie to fore-ee he will anwer, That they are virtually extended. But not here to quetion how their indiviibility makes them capable of being o; I demand, whether by an Atoms being virtually extended, its corporeal ubtance do really (I mean adequately) fill more pace then it did before, or whether it do not: (for one of the two is neceary.) If it do, then 'tis a true and real, and not barely a virtual extenion. And that uch an extenion will not erve the turn, what we have formerly argued againt the Peripatetick Rarefaction will evince; and our Adverary eems to confes as much, by deviing this virtual extenion to avoid the inconveniences to which he aw his Doctrine of Rarefaction would otherwie plainly appear expos'd. But if it be aid, That when an Atome is virtually extended, its corporeal ubtance fills no more pace then before: This is but a Verbal hift, that may perhaps amue an unwary Reader, but it will carce atisfie a conidering one. For I demand how that which is not a ubtance can fill place; and how this improper and but Metaphorical Extenion will alve the Phaenomena of Rarefaction: as how the half Inch of Air at the top of the fore-mentioned Globe hall without a corporeal extenion fill the whole Globe of two thouand times its bignes when the water is uck'd out of it, and act at the lower part of the Globe. Which lat Claue I therefore adde, becaue not onely our Author teaches (pag. 91. & 92.) that the whole Globe was filled with a certain thin ubtance, which by its contraction violently natch'd up the water into which the neck of the Glas was immers'd; but in a parallel cae he makes it his grand Argument to prove, that there is no Vacuum in the deerted part of the Tube in the Torricellian Experiment, That the attraction of the Finger cannot be performed but by ome Chap. 5. real body. Wherefore till the Examiner do intelligibly explain
how a virtual Extenion, as it is oppoed to a corporeal, can make an Atome fill twice, nay, two thouand times more pace then it did before; I uppoe this device of virtual Extenion will appear to unbias'd Naturalits but a very unatisfactory evaion.

Two Arguments indeed there are which our Adverary offers as proofs of what he teaches. The firt is, That they commonly teach in the Schools, that at leat divinitus (as he peakes) uch a thing as is pleaded for may be done, and that conequently it is not repugnant to the nature of a body. But, though they that either know me, or have read what I have written about matters Theological, will, I hope, readily believe, that none is more willing to acknowledge and venerate Divine Omnipotence; yet in ome famous Schools they teach, that it is contrary to the nature of the thing. And that men who think o, and conequently look not upon it as an object of Divine Omnipotence, may (whatever he here ay) without impiety be of a differing mind from him about the poibility of uch a Rarefaction as he would here have, our Author may perchance think fit to grant, if he remember that he himelf ayes a few Pages after, Cum tempus it Ens eentialiter uccesivum, it a ut ne divinitus Pag. 175 • . quidem posint duae ejus partes imul existere, &c. But, not now to dipute of a power that I am more willing to adore then quetion, I ay, that our Controverie is not what God can do, but about what can be done by Natural Agents, not elevated above the phere of Nature. For though God can both create and annihilate, yet Nature can do neither: and in the judgment of true Philoophers I uppoe our Hypotheis would need no other advantage to make it be preferred before our Adveraries, then that in ours things are explicated by the ordinary coure of Nature, whereas in the other recoure mut be had to miracles.

But though our Authors way of explicating Rarefaction be thus improbable, yet I mut not here omit to take notice, that his Funiculus uppoes a Condenation that to me appears incumbred
with no les manifet difficulties. For, ince he teaches that a body may be condens'd without either having any vacuities for the compret parts to retire into, or having Pores filled with any ubtile and yielding matter that may be queez'd out of them; it will follow, that the parts of the body to be condens'd do immediately touch each other: which uppoed, I demand how bodies that are already contiguous can be brought to farther Approximations without penetrating each other, at leat in ome of their parts. So that I ee not how the Examiners Condenation can be perform'd without penetration of dimenions. A thing that Philoophers of all Ages have looked upon as by no means to be admitted in Nature. And our Author himelf peaks omewhere at the ame rate, where to the Quetion, Why the walls that incloe fired Gun-powder mut be blown aunder? Repondeo (ayes he) haec omnia inde accidere, quod pulvis ille ic accenus & in flammam converus, Pag. 159. longe majus patium nunc occupet quàm prius. Unde fit, ut cum totum cubiculum antea fuerit plenisimum, dirumpantur ic parietes, ne detur corporum penetratio. In the Magdeburgick Experiment he tells us (as we have heard already) that the whole capacity of the Globe is filled with an extremely thin body. But not now to examine how properly he calls that a rare body, which according to him intercepts neither Pores nor any heterogeneous ubtance, the greater or leer abence of which makes men call a body more or les dene; not to init on this, I ay, let us conider, that before the admiion of water into the exhauted Globe there was, according to him, two thouand half Inches of a ubtance, which, however it was produc'd or got thither, was a true and real body; and that after the admiion of the water there remained in the ame Globe, beides the water that came in, no more then one half Inch of body. Since then our Author does not pretend (which if he did, might be eaily diproved) that the one thouand nine hundred ninety nine half Inches of Matter, that now appear no more, travered the body of Water; ince he will not allow that it gets away through the Pores of the
Glas, I demand, what becomes of o great a quantity of Matter? For that 'tis annihilated I uppoe he is too rational a man to pretend, (nor, if he hould, would it be at all believ'd) and to ay, that a thouand and o many hundred parts of Matter hould be retir'd into that one part of pace that contains the one half Inch of Air, is little les incredible: For that pace was uppos'd perfectly full of body before, and how a thing can be more then perfectly full, who can conceive? To dipatch: According to our Authors way of Condenation, two, or perhaps two thouand, bodles may be crouded into a pace that is adequately fill'd by one of them apart. And if this be not Penetration of Dimenions, I deire to be informed what is o; and till then I hall leave it to any unprepoes'd Naturalit to judge, whether an Hypotheis that needs uppoe a thing o generally concluded to be impoible to Nature, be probable or not; and whether to tell us that the very ame parcel of Air, that is now without violence contain'd in half an Inch of pace, hall by and by fill two thouand times as much room, and preently after hrink again into the two thouandth part of the pace it hewly poes'd, be not to turn a Body into a Spirit, and, confounding their Notions, attribute to the former the dicriminating and leat eaily conceivable properties of the later. And this Argument is, I confes, with me of that weight, that this alone would keep me from admitting the Examiners Hypotheis: yet if any happier Contemplator hall prove o harp-ighted, as to devie and clearly propoe a way of making the Rarefaction and Condenation hither to argued againt, intelligible to me, he is not like to find me obtinate. Nor indeed is there ufficient caue why his ucceeding in that attempt hould make our Adveraries Hypotheis preferrable to ours, ince that would not prove it either neceary, or o much as ufficient, but onely anwer ome of the Arguments that tend to prove 'tis not intelligible. And that we have other Arguments on our ide then thoe that relate to Rarefaction and Condenation, may appear partly by what has been dicours'd already, and partly by what we have now to ubjoyn.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: A Conideration (pertinent to the preent Controverie) of what happens in trying the Torricellian and other Experiments, at the tops and feet of Hills.

div.p: THere remain then yet a couple of Coniderations to be oppos'd againt the Examiners Hypotheis, which, though the pat Dicoure may make them be look'd upon as needles, we mut not pretermit, becaue they contain uch Arguments as may not onely be imployed againt our Adveraries Doctrine, but will very much tend to the confirmation of ours.

I conider then further, that the Hypotheis I am oppoing, being but a kind of Inverion of ours, and uppoing the pring or motion of Retitution in the Air to tend inwards, as according to us it tends outwards; it cannot be, that if the uppoition it elf were (what I think I have prov'd it is not) true, many of the Phaenomena would be plauibly enough explicable by it: the ame motions in an intermediate body being in many caes producible alike, whether we uppoe it to be thrut or drawn; provided both the endeavours tend the ame way. But then we may be atisfied whether the effect be to be acribed to Pulion or to Traction, (as they commonly peak, though indeed the later eems reducible to the former) if we can find out an Experiment wherein there is reaon uch an effect hould follow, in cae Pulion be the caue inquired after, and not in cae it be Traction. And uch an Experimentum Crucis (to peak with our Illutrious Verulam) is afforded us by that noble Obervation of Monieur Pachall, mentioned by the famous Pecquet, and out of him by our Author: namely, that the Torricellian Pag. 66. Experiment being made at the foot and in divers places of a very high Mountain, (of the altitude of five hundred fathom or three thouand foot) he found, that after he had acended a hundred
and fifty Fathom, the Quickilver was fallen two Inches and a quarter below its tation at the Mountains foot; and that at the very top of the Hill it had decended above three Inches below the ame wonted tation. Whence it appears that the Quickilver being carried up towards the top of the Atmophere, falls down the lower, the higher the place is wherin the obervation is made: of which the reaon is plain in our Hypotheis, namely, that the nearer we come to the top of the Atmophere, the horter and lighter is the Cylinder of Air incumbent upon the retagnant Mercury; and conequently the les weight of Cylindrical Mercury will that Air be able to counter-poie and keep upended. And ince this notable Phaenomenon does thus clearly follow upon ours, and not upon our Adveraries Hypotheis; this Experiment eems to determine the Controverie betwixt them: becaue in this cae the Examiner cannot pretend, as he does in the eventeenth and divers other of our Experiments, that the Decent of the Quickilver in the Tube is caus'd, not by the Diminution of the external Airs preure, but from the preternatural Rarefaction or Ditenion of that external Air (in the Receiver) when by eeking to retore it elf, it endeavours to draw up the retagnant Mercury: For in our preent cae there appears no uch forcible Dilatation of that Air, as in many of the Phaenomena of our Engine he is pleas'd to imagine.

It need therefore be no great wonder, if his Adveraries do, as he oberves, make a great account of this Experiment, to prove that the Mercury is kept up in the Tube by the reitance of the external Aire. Nor do I think his Anwers to the Argument drawn from hence will keep them from thinking it cogent. For to an Objection upon which he takes notice that they lay o much tres, he replyes but two things; which neither ingly nor together will near amount to a atisfactory Anwer.

And, Firt, he quetions the truth of the Obervation it elf; becaue having made tryal in a low Hill, the event did no wayes anwer his Expectation. But though, in tead of diapproving,
I am willing to commend his Curioity, to make the Experiment himelf, and epecially ince 'twas both new and important; and though alo I like his Modety, in rather upecting ome mitake in the manner of the Obervation, then that the Experimenters did not incerely deliver it: yet, ince there mut be an Error omewhere, I mut rather charge it upon the Examiners obervation (I ay his Obervation, not his want of incerity) then upon Monieur Pachals. For beides the commendations that the learned Gaendus, who relates the Experiment, gives to that ingenious Gentleman (Monieur Pachal) by whoe direction he uppoes it to have been try'd: the ame Gaendus relates, that the like Obervation was five times repeated, partim intra acellum, partim aëre libero, & Gaendus Tomo 1. pag. 211. nunc quidem flante, nunc ilente vento. Which circumtances ufficiently argue the Diligence wherewith the Experiment was try'd in Auvergne. Epecially ince I can confirm thee Obervations by two more made on ditant Hills in England: the one of which I procur'd from that known Virtuoo Mr. J. Ball, whom I deir'd to make the Experiment at a Mountain in Devonhire, on the ide whereof he dwelt; and the other made in Lancahire by that ingenious Gentleman Mr. Rich. Townley. Both which Obervations, ince I have mention'd them at large in the Appendix to the Phyico Mechanical Treatie, hall not now repeat; contenting my elf to oberve to our preent purpoe, that however the proportion of the Decent of the Quickilver may vary, according to the differing conitence and other Accidents of the neighbouring Air, in the particular places and times of the Experiments being made, yet all Obervations agree in this, That nearer the top of the Atmophere the Quickilver falls lower then it does further from it. To all this I hall adde two things that will very much confirm our Hypotheis. The one is, that the frehly-nam'd Mr. Townley, and divers ingenious Perons that aited at the Tryal, bethought themelves of o making the Torricellian Experiment at the top of the Hill, as to leave a determinate quantity of Air in the
Tube, before the mouth of it was open'd under the veell'd Mercury; and taking notice how low uch a quantity of that Air depreed the Mercurial Cylinder, they likewie oberv'd, that at the Mountains foot the included Air was not able to depres the Quickilver o much. Whence we inferre, that the Cylinder of Air at the top of the Hill being horter and lighter, did not o trongly pres againt the included Air, as did the ambient Air at the bottom of the Hill, where the Aereal Cylinder was longer and heavier.

But becaue that though Experiments made in very elevated places are noble ones, and of great importance in the Controveries about the Air, yet there are but very few of thoe that are qualified to make Experiments of that Nature, who have the opportunity of making them upon high Mountains; we did with the aitance of an ingenious man attempt a Tryal, wherein we hoped to find a enibly-differing Weight of the Atmopere, in a far les height then that of an ordinary Hill. But in tead of a common Tube we made ue of a kind of Weather-glas, that the included Air might help to make the event notable, for a reaon to be mentioned ere long; and in tead of Quickilver we employ'd common Water in the Pipe belonging to the Weather-glas, that mall changes in the Weight or reitance of the Atmophere in oppoit on of the included Air might be the more dicernable. The Intrument we made ue of conited only of a Glas with a broad Foot and a narrow Neck (A B) and a lender Glas-Pipe (C D) open at both ends: which Pipe was o placed, that the bottom of it did almot, but not quite, reach to the bottom of the bigger Glas (A B) within whoe Neck (A) it was fatned with a cloe cement, that both kept the Pipe in its place, and hindred all communication betwixt the inward (I I) and outward (K K) Air, ave by the cavity of the Pipe (C D). Now we choe this Glas (A B) more then ordinarily capacious, that the effect of the dilatation of the included Air (I I) might be the more conpicuous. Then conveying a convenient quantity of Water (H H) into this Glas,
we carried it to the Leads of the lofty Abby-Church at Wetminter, and there blew in a little Air to raie the Water to the upper part of the Pipe, that being above the Veel (A B) we might more preciely mark the everal tations of the Water then otherwie we could. Afterward having uffered the Glas to ret a pretty while upon the Lead, that the Air (I I) within might be reduc'd to the ame tate, both as to coldnes and as to preure, with (K K) that without, having marked the tation of the Water (F), we gently let down the Veel by a long tring to the foot of the Wall, where one attended to receive it; who having uffer'd it to ret upon the ground, cry'd to us that it was ubided about an Inch below the mark (F) we had put: whereupon having order'd him to put a mark at this econd tation of it (E), we drew up the Veel again; and uffering it to ret a while, we oberv'd the Water to be re-acended to or near the firt mark (F), which was indeed about an Inch above (E) the other. And this we did that Evening a econd time with almot a like ucces: though two or three dayes after, the wind blowing trongly upon the Leads, we found not the Experiment to ucceed quite o regularly as before; yet the Water alwayes manifetly fell lower at the foot of the Wall then it was at the top: which I ee no caue to acribe barely to the differing temperature of the Air above and below, as to Heat and Cold, ince according to the general etimate, the more elevated Region of the Air is, caeteris paribus, colder then that below, which would rather check the greater expanion of the included Air at the top of the Leads then promote it. But the better to avoid mitakes and prevent Objections, we thought fit to try the Experiment within the Church, and got into a Gallery of the ame height with the Leads: but the upper part of the Pipe being caually broken off, we thought fit to order the matter o, that the urface (G) of the remaining Water in the Pipe hould be about an Inch higher then the urface of the Water in the Veel. And then my above-mentioned Correpondent letting down the Glas, almot as oon as it was etled upon the
pavement, kneeling down to ee how far it was ubided, I found that not only it was fallen as low as the other Water, but that the outward Air depret it o far, as whilet I was looking on, to break in beneath the bottom of the Pipe, and acend through the Water in bubbles: after which the Glas being drawn up again, my Correpondent affirm'd, that the Water was very manifetly re-acended. But becaue by the unlucky breaking of a Glas, we were hindred to oberve, as we deigned, what would happen as well in a Weather-glas, o contriv'd that the weight or preure of the Atmophere hould make no change in it, as in another whoe included Air was at the top, (whereas in that we imploy'd the included Air was in the lower part,) and becaue there happened in our Tryals a Circumtance or two that eem'd not o devoid of difficulties, but that we think it may require further examination, we deign to et down a more particular account of this Experiment, (as how it ucceeds with Quickilver intead of Water, together with the capacity of the Veel (A B) and the bore of the Pipe (C D) with ome other variety of Circumtances) together with the event of the curioity we had (which eemed very uccesful) to try the Torricellian Experiment upon the above-mentioned Leads, and then let down the Tube together with the retagnant Mercury to the ground, to oberve the increaing altitude of the Quickilver, in the formerly-mentioned Appendix to the Epitle we have been defending. And it hall uffice us in the mean time that the Tryals already mentioned eem to make it evident enough that the Atmophere gravitates more, caeteris paribus, neer the urface of the Earth, then in the more elevated parts of the Air. For the Leads on which we made our Tryals were found by meaure to be in perpendicular height but threecore and fifteen Foot from the ground. To which we hall only add this at preent, that once being deirous to oberve what we could touching the proportions of the ubidence of the Water to the height of its everal tations from the ground, purpoely carrying down the Veel o as not coniderably to heat it, from the Leads down
the taires to a little window that we guet to be almot half way to the bottom, we there perceived the water to have already ubided about a Barley-Corns length, notwithtanding that probably in pight of our care, the veel were a little warmed by the heat of his body that carried it, ince by that time we were come to the foot of the Wall, the Water tood almot at the highet mark; but after the Veel was uffered to ret a while, it relaped by degrees to the lowet. And thus much for the firt of the things I had to repreent in favour of our Doctrine.

The other Particular I hall mention for confirmation of our Hypotheis, is that Experiment (which, though it be needles, eems yet more cogent and proper to prevent Evaions) made by the ame Monieur Pachal, of carrying a weakly-blown Foot-ball from the bottom to the top of an high Mountain. For that Foot-ball well'd more and more, the higher it was carried, o that it appeared as if it were full blown at the top of the Mountain, and gradually growing lank again, as it was carried; downwards; o that at the foot of the Hill it was flaccid as before. This, I ay, having thus happened, we have here an Experiment to prove our Hypotheis, wherein recoure cannot be had to any forcibly and preternaturally ditended Body, uch as that is pretended to be which remaines in the deerted pace of the Tube in the Torricellian Experiment.

The other thing which the Examiner alledges againt our Argument from Monieur Pachals Tryals, is, that uppoing it to be true, yet it cannot thence be inferr'd, that the ubidence of the Mercury at the top of the Hill proceeded from the Atmopherical Cylinder's being there lighter and les able to utain the Quickilver. Sed dici potet (ayes he) ideo ic in vertice Montis magis decendie, quod ibidem eet Pag 68. Aura frigidior, aut ex alio Temperamento hujumodi decenum cauante. But this olution will not erve the turn: For the coldnes of the ambient Air (which yet the Experimenters take not notice of) would rather contract the rarefied ubtance within the
Tube, and o draw up the Mercury higher, as our Author himelf teaches us, that 'tis from the hrinking of the Funiculus occaion'd by the cold that the Water in Thermometers Pag. 50. acends in cold weather. And whereas the only proof he adds of o improbable an Explication is taken from our eighteenth Experiment, wherein we relate, that ometimes the Quickilver did enibly fall lower in colder then in far les cold weather: I anwer, that this eighteenth Experiment will carce make more for him then againt him: For, as I there take notice that the Quickilver decended in cold weather, o it ometimes decended likewie in hot weather, and roe in cold. And 'tis very trange, that in all the Obervations made, in differing Countries and at differing times, it hould till o happen that the Mercurial Cylinder hould be horter near the top of the Atmophere then further from it; if the reitance of the outward Air have nothing to do with the keeping it upended. And 'tis yet more trange, that the Foot-ball hould in like manner grow turgid and flaccid, according as it is carried into places where it has a horter or longer Pillar of Air incumbent on it.

I was going to proceed to what remains of this Second Part of our Treatie, but that ince I begun this Chapter caually meeting with an Experiment lately ent in a Letter to a very Ingenious Mr. Croon one of the learned Profeors of Greham Colledge. Acquaintance of his and mine by a very Indutrious Phyician Dr. Hen. Power. (who is aid to have had the curioity to try over again many of the Experiments of our Engine) and finding it very proper to confirm our newly related Experiment made at Wetminter, and to be of uch a nature as we have not in this part of England the opportunity to try the like, for want of Hills high enough, I hall (according to the permiion given me) inert it in this place. And the rather, that as the Mountains have by the Trials made on them of the Torricellian Experiment, afforded us a noble proof of the weight of the Air; o they may afford us one of its Spring: wherein I hope the Phaenomenon of the Waters decent will not be acribed
to any attraction made of the Water by the violently-ditended outward Air. And becaue the Experiment was not made by us, but by another, we will et it down in his words, which are thee: This fifteenth of October 1661. we took a Weather-glas A B, of about two foot in length, and carrying it See the econd Figure. to the bottom of Hallifax Hill, the Water tood in the hank at thirteen Inches above the Water in the Veel: Thence carrying it thus fill'd, with the whole frame, immediately to the top of the aid Hill, the Water fell down to the point D, viz. an Inch and a quarter lower then it was at the bottom of the aid Hill; which (as he rightly inferrs) proves the Elaticity of the Air: for the internal Air A C, which was of the ame power and extenion with the external at the bottom of the Hill, did manifet a greater Elaticity then the Mountain-Air there Probably thee or the like words, did manifet Preure, are here omitted, for the Mountaine-Aire there eems to have acted rather by its Weight then Elaticity., and o extended it elf further by C D.

The like Experiment, I hear, the ame Ingenious Doctor has very lately repeated, and found the decent of the Water to be greater then before. And though ome Virtuoi have thought it trange, that in an Hill far inferiour to the Alps and Appennines, o hort a Cylinder of o light al quor as Water hould fall o much; yet I ee not any reaon to ditrut upon this ground either His Experiment or Ours (lately mention'd to have been made at Wetminter;) but rather to wonder the Water fell not more (if the Hill be coniderably high:) for their upicion eems grounded upon a mitake, as if becaue the Quick-ilver in the Torricellian Experiment made without purpoely leaving any Air in the Tube, would not, at the top of the mention'd Hill, have ubided above an Inch, if o much, the Water, that is near fourteen times lighter, hould not fall above a fourteenth part of that pace; whereas in the Torricellian Experiment, the upper and deerted pace of the Tube has little or no Air left in it, but the Correpondent part of the Weather-glas was furnih'd with Air, whoe preure was little les then that of the Atmophere at the bottom of the Hill;
and conequently mut be much greater then the preure of the ame Atmophere at the top of the Hill, where the Atmopherical Cylinder's gravity (upon whoe account it prees) mut be much diminih'd by its being made much horter, and by its coniting of an Air les compret. And thus much for the firt of the two Coniderations wherewith I promied to conclude this econd part of the preent Tract. Onely before I proceed I mut in a word deire the Reader to take notice, that though I have here ingled out but one of the nine Experiments which the Examiner in the 11. and 12. Chapters reckons up as urg'd by his Adveraries; yet I do not thereby declare my acquiecing in his Explications of thoe Phaenomena, but onely leave both them and ome other things he delivers about Siphons and the Magdeburg Experiments, to be dicours'd by thoe that are more concerned to examine them, contenting my elf to have ufficiently diproved the Funiculus which his Expoitions uppoe, and cleared the grounds of explicating uch Experiments aright.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Two new Experiments touching the meaure of the Force of the Spring of Air compres'd and dilated.

div.p: THe other thing that I would have conidered touching our Adveraries Hypotheis is, That it is needles. For whereas he denies not that the Air has ome Weight and Spring, but affirms that it is very inufficient to perform Page 11. uch great matters as the counterpoiing of a Mercurial Cylinder of 29. Inches, as we teach that it may: We hall now endeavour to manifet by Experiments purpoely made, that the Spring of the Air is capable of doing far more then 'tis neceary for us to acribe to it, to alve the Phaenomena of the Torricellian Experiment.

We took then a long Glas-Tube, which by a dexterous hand and the help of Lamp was in uch a manner crooked at the bottom, that the part turned up was almot parallel to the ret of the Tube, and the Orifice of this horter leg of the Siphon (if I may o call the whole Intrument) being Hermetically eal'd, the length of it was divided into Inches, (each of which was ubdivided into eight parts) by a traight lit of paper, which containing thoe Diviions was carefully pated all along it: then putting in as much Quickilver as erved to fill the Arch or bended part of the Siphon, that the Mercury tanding in a level might reach in the one leg to the bottom of the divided paper, and jut to the ame height or Horizontal line in the other; we took care, by frequently inclining the Tube, o that the Air might freely pasfrom one leg into the other by the ides of the Mercury, (we took (I ay) care) that the Air at lat included in the horter Cylinder hould be of the ame laxity with the ret of the Air about it. This done, we began to pour Quickilver into the longer leg of the Siphon, which by its weight preing up that in the horter leg, did by degrees treighten the included Air: and continuing this pouring in of Quickilver till the Air in the horter leg was by condenation reduced to take up but half the pace it poes'd (I ay, poes'd, not fill'd) before; we cat our eyes upon the longer leg of the Glas, on which was likewie pated a lit of Paper carefully divided into Inches and parts, and we oberved, not without delight and atisfaction, that the Quickilver in that longer part of the Tube was 29. Inches higher then the other. Now that this Obervation does both very well agree with and confirm our Hypotheis, will be eaily dicerned by him that takes notice that we teach, and Monieur Pachall and our Englih friends Experiments prove, that the greater the weight is that leans upon the Air, the more forcible is its endeavour of Dilatation, and conequently its power of reitance, (as other Springs are tronger when bent by greater weights.) For this being conidered, it wil appear to agree rarely-well with the Hypotheis, that as according to it the Air in that degree of denity
and correpondent meaure of reitance to which the weight of the incumbent Atmophere had brought it, was able to counter-balance and reit the preure of a Mercurial Cylinder of about 29. Inches, as we are taught by the Torricellian Experiment; o here the ame Air being brought to a degree of denity about twice as great as that it had before, obtains a Spring twice as trong as formerly. As may appear by its being able to utain or reit a Cylinder of 29. Inches in the longer Tube, together with the weight of the Atmopherical Cylinder, that lean'd upon thoe 29. Inches of Mercury; and, as we jut now inferr'd from the Torricellian Experiment, was equivalent to them.

We were hindered from proecuting the tryal at that time by the caual breaking of the Tube. But becaue an accurate Experiment of this nature would be of great importance to the Doctrine of the Spring of the Air, and has not yet been made (that I know) by any man; and becaue alo it is more uneaie to be made then one would think, in regard of the difficulty as well of procuring crooked Tubes fit for the purpoe, as of making a jut etimate of the true place of the Protuberant Mercury's urface; I uppoe it will not be unwelcome to the Reader, to be informed that after ome other tryals, one of which we made in a Tube whoe longer leg was perpendicular, and the other, that contained the Air, parallel to the Horizon, we at lat procured a Tube of the Figure expret in the Scheme; which Tube, though of a pretty bignes, was o long, that the See the 5. Figure. Cylinder whereof the horter leg of it conited admitted a lit of Paper, which had before been divided into 12. Inches and their quarters, and the longer leg admitted another lit of Paper of divers foot in length, and divided after the ame manner: then Quickilver being poured in to fill up the bended part of the Glas, that the urface of it in either leg might ret in the ame Horizontal line, as we lately taught, there was more and more Quickilver poured into the longer Tube; and notice being watchfully taken how far the Mercury was rien in that longer Tube, when it appeared to have acended to any of the
diviions in the horter Tube, the everal Obervations that were thus ucceively made, and as they were made et down, afforded us the enuing Table.

table.head: A Table of the Condenation of the Air.

div.p: A A. The number of equal paces in the horter leg, that contained the ame parcel of Air diverly extended.
B. The height of the Mercurial Cylinder in the longer leg, that compres'd the Air into thoe dimenions.
C. The height of a Mercurial Cylinder that counterbalanc'd the preure of the Atmophere.
D. The Aggregate of the two lat Columns B and C, exhibiting the preure utained by the included Air.
E. What that preure hould be according to the Hypotheis, that uppoes the preures and expanions to be in reciprocal proportion.
For the better undertanding of this Experiment it may not be amis to take notice of the following particulars:

1. That the Tube being o tall that we could not conveniently make ue of it in a Chamber, we were fain to ue it on a pair of Stairs, which yet were very lightom, the Tube being for preervations
ake by trings o upended, that it did carce touch the Box preently to be mentioned.

2. The lower and crooked part of the Pipe was placed in a quare wooden Box, of a good largnes and depth, to prevent the los of the Quickilver that might fall aide in the transfuion from the Veel into the Pipe, and to receive the whole Quickilver in cae the Tube hould break.

3. That we were two to make the obervation together, the one to take notice at the bottom how the Quickilver roe in the horter Cylinder, and the other to pour in at the top of the longer, it being very hard and troubleome for one man alone to do both accurately.

4. That the Quickilver was poured in but by little and little, according to the direction of him that oberved below, it being far eaier to pour in more, then to take out any in cae too much at once had been poured in.

5. That at the beginning of the Operation, that we might the more truly dicern where the Quickilver reted from time to time, we made ue of a mall Looking-glas, held in a convenient poture to reflect to the eye what we deired to dicern.

6. That when the Air was o compres'd, as to be crouded into les then a quarter of the pace it poes'd before, we tryed whether the cold of a Linen Cloth dipp'd in water would then condene it. And it ometimes eemed a little to hrink, but not o manifetly as that we dare build any thing upon it. We then tryed likewie whether heat would notwithtanding o forcible a compreure dilate it, and approching the flame of a Candle to that part where the Air was pent up, the heat had a more enible operation then the cold had before; o that we carce doubted but that the expanion of the Air would notwithtanding the weight that oppret it have been made conpicuous, if the fear of uneaonably breaking the Glas had not kept us from increaing the heat.

Now although we deny not but that in our Table ome particulars do not o exactly anwer to what our formerly intimated
Hypotheis might perchance invite the Reader to expect; yet the Variations are not o coniderable, but that they may probably enough be acribed to ome uch want of exactnes as in uch nice Experiments is carce avoidable. But for all that, till further tryal hath more clearly informed me, I hall not venture to determine whether or no the intimated Theory will hold univerally and preciely, either in Condenation of Air, or Rarefaction: all that I hall now urge being, That however, the tryal already made ufficiently proves the main thing for which I here alledge it; ince by it 'tis evident, that as common Air when reduc'd to half its wonted extent, obtained near about twice as forcible a Spring as it had before; o this thus-compret Air being further thrut into half this narrow room, obtained thereby a Spring about as trong again as that it lat had, and conequently four times as trong as that of the common Air. And there is no caue to doubt, that if we had been here furniht with a greater quantity of Quickilver and a very trong Tube, we might by a further compreion of the included Air have made it counter-balance the preure of a far taller and heavier Cylinder of Mercury. For no man perhaps yet knows how near to an infinite compreion the Air may be capable of, if the compreing force be competently increat. So that here our Adverary may plainly ee that the Spring of the Air, which he makes o light of, may not onely be able to reit the weight of 29. Inches, but in ome caes of above an hundred Inches of Quickilver, and that without the aitance of his Funiculus, which in our preent cae has nothing to do. And to let you ee that we did not (a little above) inconiderately mention the weight of the incumbent Atmopherical Cylinder as a part of the weight reited by the imprioned Air, we will here annex, that we took care, when the Mercurial Cylinder in the longer leg of the Pipe was about an hundred Inches high, to caue one to uck at the open Orifice; whereupon (as we expected) the Mercury in the Tube did notably acend. Which coniderable Phaenomenon cannot be acribed to our Examiners Funiculus, ince by his own confeion
that cannot pull up the Mercury, if the Mercurial Cylinder be above 29. or 30. Inches of Mercury. And therefore we hall render this reaon of it, That the preure of the incumbent Air being in part taken off by its expanding it elf into the Suckers dilated chet; the imprion'd Air was thereby enabled to dilate it elf manifetly, and repel the Mercury that compret it, till there was an equality of force betwixt the trong Spring of that compret Air on the one part, and the tall Mercurial Cylinder, together with the contiguous dilated Air, on the other part.

Now, if to what we have thus delivered concerning the compreion of Air we adde ome Obervations concerning its pontaneous Expanion, it will the better appear how much the Phaenomena of thee Mercurial Experiments depend upon the differing meaures of trength to be met with in the Airs Spring, according to its various degrees of Compreion and Laxity. But, before I enter upon this ubject, I hall readily acknowledge that I had not reduc'd the tryals I had made about meauring the Expanion of the Air to any certain Hypotheis, when that ingenious Gentleman Mr. Richard Townely was pleaed to inform me, that having by the perual of my Phyico-Mechanical Experiments been atisfied that the Spring of the Air was the caue of it, he had endeavoured (and I wih in uch attempts other ingenious men would follow his example) to upply what I had omitted concerning the reducing to a precie etimate how much Air dilated of it elf loes of its Elatical force, according to the meaures of its Dilatation. He added, that he had begun to et down what occurred to him to this purpoe in a hort Dicoure, whereof he afterwards did me the favour to hew me the beginning, which gives me a jut Curioity to ee it perfected. But, becaue I neither know, nor (by reaon of the great ditance betwixt our places of reidence) have at preent the opportunity to enquire, whether he will think fit to annex his Dicoure to our Appendix, or to publih it by it elf, or at all; and becaue he hath not yet, for ought I know, met with fit Glaes to make an any-thing-accurate Table of the Decrement of the force of dilated
Air; our preent deign invites us to preent the Reader with that which follows, wherein I had the aitance of the ame peron that I took notice of in the former Chapter, as having written omething about Rarefaction: whom I the rather make mention of on this occaion, becaue when he firt heard me peak of Mr. Townley's uppoitions about the proportion wherein Air loes of its Spring by Dilatation, he told me he had the year before (and not long after the publication of my Pneumatical Treatie) made Obervations to the ame purpoe, which he acknowledged to agree well enough with Mr. Townley's Theory: And o did (as their Author was pleaed to tell me) ome Tryals made about the ame time by that Noble Virtuoo and eminent Mathematician the Lord Brouncker, from whoe further Enquiries into this matter, if his occaions will allow him to make them, the Curious may well hope for omething very accurate.

table.head: A Table of the Rarefaction of the Air.

div.p: A. The number of equal paces at the top of the Tube, that contained the ame parcel of Air.
B. The height of the Mercurial Cylinder, that together with the Spring of the included Air counterbalanced the preure of the Atmophere.
C. The preure of the Atmophere.
D. The Complement of B to C, exhibiting the preure utained by the included Air.
E. What that preure hould be according to the Hypotheis.

To make the Experiment of the debilitated force of expanded Air the plainer, 'twill not be amis to note ome particulars, epecially touching the manner of making the Tryal; which (for the reaons lately mention'd) we made on a lightome pair of tairs, and with a Box alo lin'd with Paper to receive the Mercury that might be pilt. And in regard it would require a vat and in few places procurable quantity of Quickilver, to employ veels of uch kind as are ordinary in the Torriccllian Experiment, we made ue of a Glas-Tube of about ix foot long, for that being Hermetically ealed at one end, erv'd our turn as well as if we could have made the Experiment in a Tub or Pond of eventy Inches deep.
Secondly, We alo provided a lender Glas-Pipe of about the bignes of a Swans Quill, and open at both ends: all along which was pated a narrow lit of Paper divided into Inches and half quarters.

Thirdly, This lender Pipe being thrut down into the greater Tube almot fill'd with Quickilver, the Glas helpt to make it well to the top of the Tube, and the Quickilver getting in at the lower orifice of the Pipe, fill'd it up till the Mercury included in that was near about a level with the urface of the urrounding Mercury in the Tube.

Fourthly, There being, as near as we could gues, little more then an Inch of the lender Pipe left above the urface of the retagnant Mercury, and conequently unfill'd therewith, the prominent orifice was carefully clos'd with ealing Wax melted; after which the Pipe was let alone for a while, that the Air dilated a little by the heat of the Wax, might upon refrigeration be reduc'd to its wonted denity. And then we oberv'd by the help of the above-mentioned lit of Paper, whether we had not included omewhat more or omewhat les then an Inch of Air, and in either cae we were fain to rectifie the error by a mall hole made (with an heated Pin) in the Wax, and afterwards clos'd up again.

Fifthly, Having thus included a jut Inch of Air, we lited
up the lender Pipe by degrees, till the Air was dilated to an Inch, an Inch and an half, two Inches, &c. and oberved in Inches and Eighths, the length of the Mercurial Cylinder, which at each degree of the Airs expanion was impell'd above the urface of the retagnant Mercury in the Tube.

Sixthly, The Obervations being ended, we preently made the Torricellian Experiment with the above-mention'd great Tube of ix foot long, that we might know the height of the Mercurial Cylinder, for that particular day and hour; which height we found to be 29 ¾ Inches.

Seventhly, Our Obervations made after this manner furnih'd us with the preceding Table, in which there would not probably have been found the difference here et down betwixt the force of the Air when expanded to double its former dimenions, and what that force hould have been preciely according to the Theory, but that the included Inch of Air receiv'd ome little acceion during the Tryal; which this newly-mention'd difference making us upect, we found by replunging the Pipe into the Quickilver, that the included Air had gain'd about half an eighth, which we guet to have come from ome little aerial bubbles in the Quickilver, contain'd in the Pipe (o eaie is it in uch nice Experiments to mis of exactnes.) We try'd alo with 12. Inches of Air hut up to be dilated; but being then hindred by ome unwelcome avocations to proecure thoe Experiments, we hall elewhere, out of other Notes and Tryals (God permitting) et down ome other accurate Tables concerning this matter. By which poibly we may be aited to reolve whether the Atmophere hould be look'd upon (as it uually is) as a limited and bounded Portion of the Air; or whether we hould in a tricter ene then we did before, ue the Atmophere and Aereal part of the World for almot equivalent terms; or ele whether we hould allow the word Atmophere ome other notion in relation to its Extent and Limits; (for as to its Spring and Weight, thee Experiments do not quetion, but evince them.) But we are willing, as we aid, to referre thee matters to our Appendix, and
till then to retain our wonted manner of peaking of the Air and Atmophere. In the mean time (to return to our lat-mention'd Experiments) beides that o little a variation may be in great part imputed to the difficulty of making Experiments of this nature exactly, and perhaps a good part of it to omething of inequality in the Cavity of the Pipe, or even in the thicknes of the Glas; beides this, I ay, the proportion betwixt the everal preures of the included Air undilated and expanded, epecially when the Dilatation was great (for when the Air well'd but to four times its firt extent, the Mercurial Cylinder, though of near 23. Inches, differ'd not a quarter of an Inch from what it hould have been according to Mathematical exactnes) the proportion, I ay, was utable enough to what might be expected, to allow us to make this reflection upon the whole, That whether or no the intimated Theory will hold exactly, (for about that, as I aid above, I dare determine nothing reolutely till I have further conidered the matter) yet ince the Inch of Air when it was firt included was hut up with no other preure then that which it had from the weight of the incumbent Air, and was no more compret then the ret of the Air we breathed and moved in; and ince alo this Inch of Air, when expanded to twice its former dimenions, was able with the help of a Mercurial Cylinder of about 15. Inches to counterpoie the weight of the Atmophere, which the weight of the external Air gravitating upon the retagnant Mercury was able to impell up into the Pipe, and utain above twenty eight Inches of Mercury when the internal Air by its great expanion had its Spring too far debilitated to make any coniderable (I ay coniderable, for it was not yet o dilated as not to make ome) reitance: ince, I ay, thee things are o, the free Air here below appears to be almot as trongly compret by the weight of the incumbent Air as it would be by the Weight of a Mercurial Cylinder of twenty eight or thirty Inches; and conequently is not in uch a tate of laxity and freedom as men are wont to imagine; and acts like ome mechanical Agent, the decreement of whoe force holds a
tricter proportion to its increae of dimenion, then has been hitherto taken notice of.

I mut not now tand to propoe the everal reflections that may be made upon the foregoing Obervations touching the Compreion and Expanion of Air; partly becaue we could carce avoid making the Hitorical part omewhat prolix; and partly becaue I uppoe we have already aid enough to hew what was intended, namely, that to olve the Phaenomena there is not of our Adveraries Hypotheis any need: the evincing of which will appear to be of no mall moment in our preent Controverie, to him that coniders, that the two maine things that induced the Learned Examiner to reject our Hypotheis are, that Nature abhors a Vacuum, and that though the Air have ome Weight & Spring, yet thee are inufficient to make out the known Phaenomena; for which we mut therefore have recoure to his Funiculus. Now as we have formerly een, that he has not o atisfactorily diproved as reolutely rejected a Vacuum, o we have now manifeted that the Spring of the Air may uffice to perform greater things then what our Explication of the Torricellian Experiments and thoe of our Engine obliges us to acribe to it. Wherefore ince beides the everal difficulties that incumber the Hypotheis we oppoe, and epecially its being carce, if at all, intelligible, we can adde that it is unneceary; we dare expect that uch Readers as are not byas'd by their reverence for Aritotle or the Peripatetick Schools, will hardly reject an Hypotheis which, beides that it is very intelligible, is now prov'd to be ufficient, only to imbrace a Doctrine that uppoes uch a rarefaction and condenation, as many famous Naturalits rejected for its not being comprehenible, even when they knew of no other way (that was probable) of olving the Phaenomena wont to be explicated by it.

div.head: The III. Part.

argument.p: Wherein what is objected againt Mr. Boyle's Explications of particular Experiments, is anwered.

div.p:
AND now we are come to the third and lat Part of our Defence; wherein we are to conider what our Examiner is pleas'd to object againt ome paages of our Phyicho-Mechanical Treatie. But though this may eem the only part wherein I am particularly concern'd; yet perhaps we hall find it, if not the hortet, at leat the eaiet, part of our Task. Partly, becaue our Author takes no exceptions at the Experiments themelves, as we have recorded them (which from an Adverary, who in ome places peaks of them as an eye-witnes, is no contemptible tetimony that the matters of fact have been rightly delivered:) and partly, becaue there are divers Experiments which, together with their Explications, the Examiner has thought fit to leave untoucht, and thereby allows us to do o too: and partly alo, becaue that (as to divers of thoe Experiments upon which he animadverts) he does not pretend to hew that our Explications are ill deduc'd or incongruous to our principles; but only that the Phaenomena may be explain'd either better or as well by his Hypotheis, whereof
he uppoes himelf to have demontrated the truth, together with the erroneounes of ours, in the other parts of his book, epecially the third, fourth and fifth Chapters. So that after what we have aid to vindicate the Hypotheis we maintain, and take away our Authors imaginary Funiculus; it will not be requiite for us on uch occaions to examine his particular Aertions and Explications. Which Advertiement we hope the Reader will be pleaed to bear in mind, and thereby ave himelf and us the trouble of a great deal of unneceary repetition. Wherefore preuming he will do o, we hall not tay to examine the firt and econd Corollaries, which in his 17. Chapter he annexes to the manner of emptying our Receiver by our Pump. Neither hould we ay any thing as to his third and lat Corollary, but that we think fit to deire the Reader to take notice, that according to what he teaches in that place, the more the Air is rarefied, the more forcibly it is able to contract it elf.

div.head: A defence of our 1. and 2. Experiments.
div.p:
And to proceed now to his 18 Chapter, which he intitles De Experiment is Boyleanis, we hall find according to what we lately noted, that againt the Firt Experiment he objects nothing ave that, if one of the Fingers be applied to the Orifice of the Valve when the Pump is freed from Air, the Experimenter hall feel to his pain that the Sucker is not thrut inward by the external Air, but, as the Finger, drawn inward by the internal. But this Phaenomenon of the intruion of the Finger into a Cavity, where it finds no reitance, having been formerly accounted for according to our Hypotheis, we hall not need to repeat our Explication of it; though this mitaken Phaenomenon upplies our Adverary with divers of his following Animadverions, and indeed with a great part of his book. And accordingly his Objection againt our Second Experiment being of the ame nature with that againt the firt, requires but the ame Anwer: For it will not alter the cae that he adds upon this Experiment, Hoc ee dicrimen
manifetum inter presionem & uctionem, quod uctio efficiat hujumodi adhaeionem, presio autem minimè; ince to ay o is but to affirme, not to prove.

div.head: The 3. Experiment.
div.p:
What our Author would except againt the 3. Experiment he ought to have more intelligibly expret: For whereas of a Dicoure wherein I deliver everal particulars, he onely ayes that Nullatenus atisfacit, ut legenti constabit; I would not do the Reader the injury to upect him of taking this proofles Aertion for a rational Confutation; epecially ince upon the review of that third Experiment I find nothing that agrees not with my Hypotheis, however it may diagree with the Examiners. But, to conider the Explication he ubtitutes in the room of our Doctrine, which he rejects, he gives it us in thee words; Hoc quo
que Experimentum principiis notris optimè convenit: Cum enim per illam Emboli depresionem aër in cavitate brachii incluus eparetur ab eodem brachio, decendat
que imul cum Embolo (uti de aqua imul cum argento vivo decendente capite decimo tertio vidimus) fit ut in tota illa depresione, novae emper ab aëre illo deoendente upericies diripiantur imul & extendantur, ut ibidem de aqua et explicatum: cum ita
que aeque facile diripiantur & extendantur hujumodi uperficies in fine depresionis ac initio, mirum non et quod eadem utrobi
que entiatur deprimendi difficultas.

By which though he eems to intend an Oppoition to that part of the third Experiment which I oppos'd not againt his Opinion, but that of ome learned Vacuits: yet (not to mention that he eems to have omewhat mitaken my ene) he offers nothing at all to invalidate my inference againt them; but intead of that propoes a defence of his own Opinion, which uppoes the truth of his diproved Hypotheis, and is either unatisfactory even according to that, or ele diagrees with what himelf hath taught us but a little before. For 'tis evident that the more the Sucker is depres'd, the more the Cylinder is exhauted of Air.
And in his third Corollary (which we lately deired the Reader to oberve) peaking of the Air in the Receiver (and the cae is the ame with the Air in the Cylinder) he affirms more then once, Eo magis extendi ac rarefieri aërem relictum, quo plus inde exhauritur, majoremque proinde acquirere vim ee contrahendi. Whereas here he would have us believe, that the little internal Air that was in the Cavity of the hank of the Stop cock, does as trongly retract the Sucker, or, which in our cae is all one, refit its depreion, when the Sucker is yet near the top of the Cylinder, (and conequently when the included Air is but a little dilated) as when the ame Sucker being forced down to the lower part of the Cylinder, the ame portion of remaining Air mut be exceedingly more ditended.

div.head: The 4. Experiment.
div.p: In the Fourth Experiment, touching the welling of a Bladder upon the removal of the ambient Air; and proportionably to that removal our Author objects nothing againt the Explication we give of it by the Spring of the Air included in the Bladder, and ditending it according as the preure of the ambient Air is weakned. But he endeavours alo to explicate it his way, to which he ayes this circumtance does excellently agree, that upon the regres of the external Air into the Receiver, the tumid Bladder immediately hrinks, becaue (aith he) by uch ingres of the external Air, the Air in the Receiver, which drew the ides of the Bladder outward from the middle of it, is relax'd. Which Explication whether it be more natural then ours (that acribes the hrinking of the Bladder to the preure of the Air that is let into the Receiver) let the Reader judge, who has conidered what we have formerly objected againt the Examiners Funiculus, and the Relaxation of it upon the admiion of Air.

As for the reaon likewie he adds, why a perforated Bladder does not alo well, namely, that by the hole, how little oever,
