the included Air is uck'd out by the rarefi'd ambient, we leave it to the impartial Reader to conider whether is the more genuine Explication, either ours (againt which he has nothing to object) or his, which to make clearly out he ought (according to what we formerly noted diputing againt his Funiculus) to hew us what kind of trings they are; which though, according to him, trongly fatned to the inide of the Receiver and the uperficies of the Bladder, mut draw jut as forcibly one as another, how long oever they be without the Bladder in comparion of thoe that within the Bladder draw o as to hinder the diduction of its ides. For Experience hews, that in a perforated Bladder the wrinkles continue as if there were no drawing at all.

And though he could decribe how uch a tring may be context, yet our Explication will have this advantage in point of probability above his, That whereas he denies not that the Air has Spring and Weight, as we deny his Funiculus to have any other then an imaginary exitence; and whereas he acknowledges that by the Intrument the Air about the Bladder is exhauted; to hew that there needs no more then that, and conequently no Funiculus, to draw aunder the ides of the Bladder, we can confirm our Explication by the formerly mentioned Experiment of the ingenious Pachall, who carrying a flaccid Foot-ball from the bottom to the top of a high Mountain, found it to well proportionably as he acended, and as the weight and preure of the ambient Air decreaed, and likewie to hrink again as he decended. And yet in this cae there is no recoure to be had to a Funiculus of violently-rarefi'd Air to draw aunder every way the ides of the Foot-ball. But however the Examiner will be able to defend his Explication, it may uffice us that he has objected nothing againt ours.

div.head: The 5. Experiment.
div.p:
Againt the caue we aign of the fifth Experiment he likewie objects nothing, but onely acribes the breaking of the Bladder
to the elf-contraction of the rarefi'd Air in the Receiver. And therefore referring the Reader to what we have newly aid about the lat Experiment, we will with our Author pas over the ixth and eventh, to which he has no quarrel, and proceed to the eighth.

div.head: The 8. Experiment.
div.p:
This is that wherein we mention our having broke a Glas-Receiver, which was not globular, by the exhaution of mot of the inward Air, whereby its debilitated preure became unable to reit the unweakned preure of the outward Air. But this Explication the Examiner confidently rejects in thee words, At profecto non videtur credibile, mollisimum hunc aërem tam vehementer vitrum (tantae praeertim crasitudin is quantae ibidem dicitur) undi
que ic comprimere ut illud perfring at: as if it were more credible that the little Air within (which, according to him, is o much thinner then common Air) hould be able to act more powerfully upon the Glas then the Air without, which himelf confees to be a heavy body, and which not onely reaches from the urface of the Earth to the top of the highet Mountains, but which (as may not improbably be argued from what we have elewhere delivered) may, for ought we know to the contrary, be heaped upon the Receiver to the height of ome hundreds of Miles, nay, to I know not how many thouands, in cae the Atmophere be not a bounded port on of the Air, See Part 2. C 5. but reach as high as It.

As for the Explication he ubtitutes in thee words, Verius ita
que repondetur, ideo ic fractum ee illud vitrum, quia per exhautionem illam latera ejus vehementius introrum int attracta, quam ut ob figuram illam reitendo minus idoneam reitere potuerunt. Cum enim incluus aër lateribus vitri firmisimè adhaereat, nihil aliud erit aërem illum ic exhaurire, quam atagere latera vitri introrum flectere: By what we have already dicoured about the Funiculus, the Reader may eaily dicern what is to be anwered. Nor does our Author here hew us any way by which his imaginary
trings hould take uch fat hold of the ides of the Glas, as to be able to draw them together notwithtanding the reitance they find from the cloe texture of the Body to be broken.

div.head: The 9. Experiment.
div.p:
Our Explication of the ninth Experiment he handles very everely: for having briefly recited it, he propoes his Objection againt it thus, Sed profecto nimis longè videtur hoc à veritate recedere: potet
que vel inde olum atis refutari; quia i tanta it preura aeris ic per tubum illum in phialam decendent is, ut ipam phialam perfringat, deberet profecto incluam aquam, cui immergitur ille tubus, valde quo
que ante fractionem phialae commovere, bullula
que in eadem excitaro, &c. ut constat, iquis, inufflando per illum tubulum, aquam vel mediocriter ic premat. At certum et aquam, antequam frangatur it phiala, nec tantillum moveri: ut experienti contabit.

But, I do confes, I do for all this think our Explication more true, then well conidered by our Author. For the putting of water into the Vial that was broken, was done (as is clearly intimated in the beginning of our Narrative) upon a particular deign (as indeed we tryed divers other things with our Engine, not o much with immediate reference to the Spring of the Air, as to make ue of uch Tryals in ome other of our Writings.) And accordingly in the econd Tryal mentioned in the ame Experiment the water was omitted. But, notwithtanding this water, the ides of the Glas being expoed to the preure of the Atmophere, had that whole preure againt them before the exhaution of the Receiver; o that there needed no uch blowing in of the Air afreh as our Author imagines, to effect the breaking of the Vial, it being ufficient for that purpoe, that the preure againt the convex uperficies of it was taken off by the exhaution of the Receiver, the preure againt the concave uperficies remaining as great as ever. And therefore we need not altogether deny what the Examiner ayes, that Licet clauus uperne fuiet tubulus ille, codem tamen modo fracta ine dubio, fuiet
phiala. For, ince in uch caes the Air (as we have often taught) is hut up with the whole preure of the Atmophere upon it, it may almot as eaily break the Glas as if it were untopt. And accordingly we mention in the 36. Experiment the breaking of a thin Glas Hermetically eal'd upon the reces of the ambient Air. But, how confidently oever our Author peaks, I thought fit to adde the word almot, becaue we oberved in the 39. Experiment, that uch thin Vials (and thick ones will not break) are ubject upon the withdrawing of the ambient Air to retch a little, whereby the Spring of the Air within the Vial might in ome caes (I ay, in ome) be o far weakned as not to be able to break it, unles aited by the preure of the Atmophere wherewith it communicates, and which leans upon it. And when the Vial does actually begin to break, then the puruing preure of the outward Air upon the yielding Air within the Vial may help to throw the parts of the Glas more forcibly aunder.
All the Experiments from the 9. to the 17. excluively our Examiner leaving uncenured, we may with him, advance to the conideration of the 17.

div.head: The 17. Experiment defended.
div.p:
In this we relate how, when we made the Torricellian Experiment, we hut up the retagnant Mercury together with the Tube and the upended Mercurial Cylinder (of about 29. Inches) in our Receiver, that by drawing off and letting in the Air at pleaure upon the retagnant Mercury, and conequently weakning and increaing its preure, we might make it more clearly appear then hither to had been done by Experiment, that the upenion of the Mercurial Cylinder, and the height of it, depended upon the greater or leer preure of the Air. But againt our Explication of this Experiment (which has had the good fortune to convince and atisfie many ingenious men) the Examiner objects nothing in particular, contenting himelf to have recoure
here alo to his Funiculus. Yet two obervations of ours he is pleaed to take notice of.

The firt is, that though the Quickilver were exactly hut up into our Receiver after the manner newly declared, yet the upended Quickilver did not decend: whence having aid that I argue, that it is now utained not by the Counterpoie of the Atmophere, but by the Spring of the Air hut up in the Receiver, he ubjoyns onely this, Sed rectius ane infertur, Cylindrum illum nihil ibidem antea praetitie. But whether this be not gratis dictum we leave the Reader to collect from what we have formerly dicourt in the econd Part of this Defence of the Spring of the Air; epecially from that Experiment; by which it appears, That Spring may utain a far higher Cylinder of Quick-ilver.

In the econd Obervation he mentions of ours, he ummarily recites our Explication of the decent and acent of the Mercury in the Tube, by the debilitated and trengthned Spring of the Air. But without finding fault with our application of that principle to the Phaenomena, he ayes that he has ufficiently refuted the principle it elf in the fourth Chapter, (which how well he has done we have already een) and therefore explicates the matter thus; Dico igitur (ayes he) argentum per illam exhautionem ic in tubo decendere, quod deorum traha • ur ab aëre qui incumbit argento retagnanti: iquidem incumbens ille aër jam per exhautionem valde rarefactus & extenus, ee vehementer contrahit, & contrahendo conatur etiam ubjectum ibi argentum retagnans è uo vaculo elevare, unde fit ut (argento illo retagnante minus jam gravitante in fundum ui vaculi) argentum quod et in tubo decendat; ut per e patet. Adeo
que mirum non et, quod, ingrediente potea aëre externo, rurum argentum acendat, cum per illum ingreum vis illa ic elevans argentum retagnans debilitetur. But this Explication uppoing uch a Funiculus as we have already hewn to be but fictitious, the Reader will eaily gather what is to be judged of it from what has been already delivered. Wherefore I hall onely ubioyn, that by this Explication, were it admitted, there is
onely an account given of that part of our eventeenth Experiment which relates to the decent of the Mercury below its wonted height, and its re-acent to it. But as for our having, by the forcing in ome more Air into the Receiver, impell'd the Quickilver to a coniderably-greater height then 'tis wont to be utain'd at in the Torricellian Experiment, I confes I undertand not how the Examiner gives an account of it in the following words, (which are immediately annex'd to thoe we lat recited of his, and which are all that he employes to explicate this notable Phaenomenon) At
que hinc etiam redditur ratio alterius quod ibidem quo
que notaîur, nempe quod per violentam intruionem aëris externt in Recipientem, acenderit argentum notabiliter upra digitos 29½. Nam icut per extractionem aëris argentum infra tationem detrahitur, ic etiam per intruionem novi upra eandem elevabitur. For in this paage I ee not how he himelf does not rather repeat the matter of fact, then give any account how it is perform'd. And if it be alledged on his behalf, That according to his principles it may be aid that, upon the preure of the adventitious Air upon the retagnant Mercury, the Funiculus in the Tube, that was not able before to draw it up above 29½. Inches, is now enabled to draw it up higher; I demand upon what account this new Air does thus pres againt the retagnant Mercury, and impell up and utain that in the Tube. It will not be aid that 'tis by its weight; for as much Mercury as may be thus impell'd up above the uual tation will weigh a great many times more then the Air forc'd into the Receiver. And therefore it remains that the additional Air counterpoies the additional Mercury by its Spring. And if we conider withall, that there's no reaon to doubt, (epecially conidering what we have formerly delivered upon tryal touching the power of compret Air to impell up Quickilver) but that, had we not been afraid of breaking our Veel, we might by forcing more Air into the Receiver have impell'd it up to the top of the Tube, and kept it there; we hall carce deny but that, uppoing there could be no uch Funiculus as our Examiner's in rerum natura, the preure of the incumbent Air
alone might uffice to keep a correpondent Cylinder of Mercury upended: and that without any attraction of the retagnant Mercury by a Funiculus of violently ditended Air in the Receiver, the Quickilver in the Tube may be made to ret at any height greater or leer, provided it exceed 30. Inches, onely becaue its weight is jut able to counterbalance the preure of the contiguous Air.

I know not whether I may not adde (to expres an unwillingnes to omit what ome may think proper to do my Adverary right) that it may be aid for the Examiner, that he in the 11. page acknowledging with us a power in the Air to recover its due extenion if it be crouded into les room then its dipoition requires; a man may from that principle olve the Phaenomena in quetion by aying, that the Air in the Receiver being forcibly compret by the intruion of freh Air into the ame veel, does by its endeavour to recover its due expanion pres upon the retagnant Mercury, and force up ome of it into the Tube. But this Explication, though it agree with what the Author teaches in a place very ditant from his Notes upon our 17. Experiment, now under debate; yet till 'tis not clear to me how, by what he ayes in thee Notes, the Phaenomenon is accounted for as the word Hinc imports it to be. But otherwie I need not quarrel with the Explication, ince without recurring to the Funiculus for the utaining of the additional Mercury, the olution of the Phaenomenon is given upon the ame principle that I employ.

div.head: The 18. Experiment.
div.p:
Our Examiner in his Animadverion upon the 18. Experiment, having recited my Conjecture at the caue why a Cylinder of Mercury did in Winter rie and fall in the Tube, ometimes as Water is wont to do in a Weather-glas, according to the laws of heat and cold, and ometimes quite contrary thereunto; adds, that this Experiment does trongly enough overthrow our Hypotheis of the Atmopherical Cylinder, and clearly hew that the
Quickilver is not utained by it: Nam (ayes he) i hic ab eo utentatum fuiet, debuiet potius frigidiore tempore acendere quam decendere, eo quod aër tunc multo denior eet & gravior. Ita
que non utentatur argentu¯ ab aër is aequipondio, ut aeritur. And by the ame Argument he concludes againt the Mercury's being utained by the Spring of the Air. But in his Animadverions upon this Experiment he eems to have been too forward to reprehend; for he neither well confutes my Conjecture, nor ubtitutes o much as a plauible one in the tead of it. And as to his Objection I anwer,

Firt, That it doth not conclude: becaue that as ometimes the Quickilver in the Tube did rie in warmer, and fall in colder, weather; o at other times it did rather emulate the acent and decent of water in a Weather-glas.

Secondly, Though it be true, that Cold is wont to condene this or that parcel of Air, and that a parcel of Air may be made heavier by Condenation; yet that is in regard of the ambient Air that retains its wonted laxity, in which the condened Air is weighed. But our Author has not yet proved, that in cae the cold of the Winter hould condene the whole incumbent Atmophere, it would then gravitate enibly more upon the retagnant Quickilver then before. As a Pound of Wooll will not enibly vary its weight, though the hairs whereof it is compoed be made to lye ometimes in a looer, ometimes in a cloer, order.

And, thirdly, this Objection does as little agree with his Doctrine as with my Conjecture: For in the 50. page, where he gives us an account according to his principles of the riing and falling of water in a Weather-glas, and compares it with the upenion of Quickilver, he tells us, Hinc fit quod, contracto hoc funiculo per frigus, aqua illa tempore frigido acendat, decendat autem tempore calido, eo quod per calorem funiculus ille dilatetur. So that, according to the Examiner himelf, the Quickilver ought to have acended in colder, and decended in warmer, weather. Now, although I propoed my thoughts of the difficult Phaenomenon
under conideration but as a Conjecture, and therefore hall be ready to alter them, either upon further dicovery, or better information; yet I ee not why it hould be pot-poed to the Examiner's, who, though he rejects our Explication, ubtitutes no other then what may be gathered from thee words, Ego certe non dubito quin dentur hujumodi occultae cauae, quibus funiculus ille ubtilis, quo in tubo upenditur argentum (ut dictum et capite decimo) modo producatur, modo abbrevietur, &c. ic
que argentum nunc demittat, nunc elevet. For, ince we have made it probable that the copious Fumes, ometimes uddenly acending into the Air, and rolling up and down in it, ometimes enibly altering (if good Authors may be credited) the refraction of it, and ince ome other caues, mentioned in our eighteenth Experiment, may alter the denity and gravity of the Air that leans upon the retagnant Mercury; I uppoe the Reader will think it more intelligible and probable, that alterations, other then thoe produced by heat and cold, may happen to the incumbent Atmophere, which freely communicates with the neighbouring Air, and may thereby become ometimes more tufft, and ometimes more detitute of adventitious Exhalations; then that uch changes hould happen to a Funiculus included in Glas, which according to our Author is impervious to the ubtilet teams that are, and concerning which he offers not o much as a Conjecture upon what other account it can happen to be ometimes contracted, and ometimes tretch'd.

div.head: The 19. Experiment.
div.p:
Upon this the Examiner has onely this hort Animadverion, In decimo nono otendit aquam eodem modo per exhautionem Recipient is decendere, quo in praecedente decendere otender at argentum vivum; cujus cum eadem it ratio, non et cur amplius ei initamus. In which words ince he offers nothing new or peculiar to hew any incongruity in our Explication to our principles, which agree very well with the new Phaenomena of the Experiment; we are
content to leave the Reader to judge of the Hypothees themelves, which of the two is the more probable, either ours, that onely requires that the Air in the Receiver hould equally reit a Cylinder of Water and of Quickilver, when their weight is but the ame, though their altitudes be not; or the Examiner's, which exacts that (according to what we formerly elewhere noted) Bodies of uch differing nature and texture as Quickilver and Water hould need but jut the ame weight or trength to rarefie them into a Funiculus.

div.head: The 20. Experiment.
div.p: In his Examen of this Experiment our Author makes me infer from the Phaenomena he repeats, that not onely the Air, but the Water alo has a Spring. But though I upect not that he does wilfully mitake my ene, yet by what I write in this and the following Experiments the Reader may well enough perceive, that I poke but very doubtfully of a Spring in the water; nay, and that I did in the 154. page exprely teach, That the intumecence of it might (at leat in great part) proceed from that of the mall parcels of Air, which I thought to be uually harboured in the body of that liquor.

But whereas I acribe the appearance of the Bubbles in the water to this, that upon the exhaution of ome of the Air incumbent on the water, the preure of what remains is much debilitated, whereby the little Particles of Air lurking in the Water are allowed to expand themelves into bubbles; he rejects this Explication as manifetly fale: Nam (ayes Sed contra manifetè. he) i it a ieret, deberent profecto hujumodi bullulae non è fundo vais ic acendere, (uti tam in hoc quam in equentibus experiment is in quibus de itis bullis agitur emper aeritur) ed è uperiore parte aquae, ubi minus premuntur, ut per e et manifetum. But why he hould be here o peremptory I confes I do not, for all this Objection, yet ee: For in the bottom of the next page he ayes, he will not deny but that Aerial Particles latitant in the other parts
of the water (he had before poken of the bottom of it) may be extended into bubbles by his way of Rarefaction. And that we particularly mentioned the riing of bubbles, even from the bottom of the water, was becaue that circumtance eem'd to deerve a peculiar note; and not (as he eems to imagine) as if the bubbles did not alo rie from the uperior parts of the liquor, ince we did take notice of it about the middle of the 149 page. And we often in this and See alo in the 43. Experim. thee paages,—And this Effervecence was o great in the upper part of the water, &c. As alo,—The Effervecence was confin'd to the upper part of the water, unles, &c. the following Experiments oberv'd, that the acending bubbles grew bigger the nearer they came to the top. Which agrees more clearly with our Hypotheis, wherein their conpicuous welling as they acend is attributed more to the leening of the preure of the incumbent Air then to the decrement of the weight of the incumbent water, (ince when the urface of this liquor is lean'd upon by the Atmophere, the acending bubbles carce enibly increae in Veels no deeper then ours) then with the Explication which the Examiner gives in thee words, Repondeo, aquam per illam aëris exhautionem non ponte ic acendere, ed urum violenter trahi, ac elevari à rarefacto illo aëre ee contrahente. Quemadmodum enim aqua aliqualem patitur compresionem (ut experientiâ contat) ita & aliqualem quo
que hic patitur, ditenionem. At
que hinc clarè patet, cur potius à fundo vais quam à parte aquae uperiore oriantur hujumodi bullae. Cum enim vehemens illa uctio conetur aquam à fundo phialae elevare, nacitur ibidem ubtilis quaedam materia quae in bullas convera ic acendit, uti capite decimo quinto in quarto Experimento dictum et. For, whatever he may think, it does not hence o clearly appear how the endeavour onely of the Funiculus to draw up the water from the bottom of the Vial, to which, that endeavour notwithtanding, it remains contiguous, hould generate in ome parts of the bottom of the Glas, and not in others, uch a ubtil matter as he tells us of. And I uppoe the Reader will, as well as I, wih he had more intelligibly declared how this trange generation of ubtil matter
comes to be effected. And I preume it will likewie be exected that he alo declare, why both in our cae and in the Torricellian Experiment the bubbles grow o much larger by being nearer the top of the liquor; if, as he rejects our Explication of this Circumtance, the effect of the fuction he peaks of be greater upon the lower part of the liquor then the upper, to which alone nevertheles his Funiculus, that is aid o to draw the liquor, is contiguous.
Our Author making no particular Objection againt the 10. following Experiments, we alo hall pas them by, and fall with him upon the conideration of the 31. Experiment.

div.head: The 31. Experiment.
div.p:
Upon this our Author having recited our Conjecture at the caue why two very flat and mooth Marbles tick o cloely together, that by lifting up the uppermot you may take up alo the lowermot, approves my way of examining that Conjecture. But whereas I ay that the reaon why, though the Marbles were kept together by the preure of the ambient Air, yet they did not fall aunder in our exhauted Receiver, no not though a weight of 4. Ounces were hung at the lower tone, might be, that by reaon of ome mall leak in the Receiver the Air could not be ufficiently drawn out: yet he tells us with his wonted confidence, Certum ee, ententiam illam vel hoc olo Experimento atis refelli. But poibly he would have poken les reolutely, if he had made all the tryals about the adheion of Marbles that we relate our elves to have made in the hort Hitory we have publih'd of Fluidity and Firmnes. For our Examiner peaks as if all that we acribe to the Air in uch Experiments were to utain the lower Marble with the weight perhaps of a few Ounces: Whereas in cae the Air be kept from getting in at all between the tones, it may (according to our Hypotheis) utain a Weight either altogether or well-nigh equal to that of a pillar of Air as broad as the Bais of the lower Marble, and as long as the Atmophere is
high, or to the weight of a pillar of Quickilver of the ame thicknes, and about 30. Inches long; thee two pillars appearing by the Torricellian Experiment to counterpoie each other. And therefore ince in the eventeenth Experiment, when we had exhauted our Receiver as far as we could, there remain'd Air enough to keep up in the Tube a Cylinder of about an Inch long of Quickilver; and ince the broader the contiguous Marbles are, the greater weight fatned to the lowermot may be utain'd by the reitance of the Air, (as is obvious to him that coniders the Hypotheis, and as we have proved by Experiment in the forementioned Tract) it need be no wonder that the Air remaining in the Receiver hould be able to upport the lowermot Marble, whoe Diameter was near two Inches, and a weight of four Ounces, thoe two Weights being inferior to that of a Mercurial Cylinder of that Diameter and an Inch in length. And though it were not, yet we are not ure that the Receiver was as well emptied when we made the 31. Experiment, as when we made the 17. And (if my Memory does not much mi-informe me) 'twas with the ame pair of Marbles that in the preence of an illutrious Aembly of Virtuoi (who were Spectators of the Experiment) the uppermot Marble drew up the lowermot, though that were clog'd with a weight of above 430. Ounces.

As for the account the Examiner ubtitutes of our Phaenomenon, I know not whether many Readers will acquiece in it: For, not to init upon the Objection which himelf takes notice of, that according to him the ditended Air in the Receiver hould draw aunder the adhering Marbles; his Explication uppoes that there cannot naturally be a Vacuum, whence he infers that, Necee er at ut lapis ille non aliter decenderet, quàm relinquendo pot e tenuem hujumodi ubtantiam, qualis ab argento vivo aut aquâ ic decendentibus relinqui olet. But whereas he adds, that the caue of the obtinate adheion we meet with in our cae is, that uch a ubtance is far more difficult to be eparated from Marble then from Quickilver or any other kind of body; that Aertion is precarious. And though I have tryed Experiments of
this nature with tones of everal izes, perhaps an hundred times, yet I never could find that by their coheion they would utain a weight greater then that of a Pillar of the Atmophere that pret againt the lowermot: Which is a coniderable Circumtance, that much better agrees with our Explication then our Adveraries. And whereas he further ayes, Unde exitimo planè, i perfectè complanata fuerint duo marmora ic conjuncta, it a ut nullus omnino aër inter utrum
que mediaret, non poe ea ullis humanis viribus ab invicem divelli: I hope I need not tell the Reader, that whether or no this agree with what he had immediately before taught of the eparablenes of a ubtil ubtance even from Marble, o bold and improbable an Aertion requires the being countenanc'd with a much better proof then the onely one he ubjoyns in thee words, Uti etiam confirmat exemplum quod ibidem adducit Author de lamina aenea, tabulae cuidam marmoreae ita adhaerente, ut à lacertoo juvene, de uis viribus gloriante, non potuerit per annulum centro ejus affixum inde elevari. For ure there is great odds betwixt the trength of a man unaited by any Engine, and the ut mot extent of Humane Power. And indeed according to our Hypotheis, and without having recoure to Natures dreading of a Vacuum, the cae is clear enough: For, uppoing the Plate to be of any coniderable breadth, the Pillar of the Atmophere that lean'd upon it, and mut at the intant of its deerting the uperficies of the Table all at once be lifted up with it, may well exceed the force of a ingle man, epecially in an inconvenient poture; ince by the coheion of a pair of Marbles of about three Inches Diameter, I did with my own hands take up above a thouand and three hundred Ounces.

div.head: The 32, and 33. Experiments.
div.p:
Againt our Explication of thee two, which our Author examines together, he objects nothing peculiar, but contents himelf to explicate them by his Funiculus: Wherefore neither hall we need to frame any peculiar defence for it, epecially if the
Reader will be pleaed to refer hither as much of what we oppos'd to his Animadverion on the third Experiment as is jutly applicable to our preent Controverie. Our Author indeed endeavours to prove his Explication by aying, that the ditended Air in the exhauted Cylinder draws up the Sucker with the annexed weight, Eodem fere modo quo videmus in cucurbitulis doro aegrotantis applicatis, in quibus, extincta jam flamma, rarefactus aër e contrahens carnem tam vehementer, uti videmus, elevat attrahit
que intra cucurbitulam. But that Phaenomenon is eaily enough explicable in our Hypotheis, by aying, that upon the vanihing of that heat which trengthned the preure of the included Air, the Spring of it grows too weak to reit any longer the preure of the ambient Air; which thereupon thruts the fleh and neighbouring bloud of the Patient into the Cupping-glas, almot after the ame manner as we formerly taught the Pulp of the Finger to be thrut into the deerted Cavity of the Glas-Tube in the Torricellian Experiment.

div.head: The 34, 35, and 36. Experiments.
div.p: To thee our Author aying nothing but this, In his tribus nihil peculiariter occurrit hic explicandum, cujus ratio ex jam dictis non facile pateat; we alo may be allow'd to pretermit them, and pas on to

div.head: The 37. Experiment.
div.p:
Of the appearance of Light or Whitenes, mentioned in this Experiment, the Examiner confees that we have aigned a caue probable enough, by referring it to the vehement and udden commotion of the included Air. And indeed though I do till look upon ome of the things that I heitantly propos'd about this difficult Phaenomenon but as meer Conjectures, and though he annexes his Explication of it; yet I ee not but that it is coincident with ours, or not better then it. For, to what I had aid of the Commotion of the parts of the Air, he adds onely
in two or three everal places their being violently ditended; which how it improves the Explication of the Phaenomenon I do not readily ee. And whereas he ubjoyns, Exitimo autem dicendum potius candorem illum ee lumen quoddam reflexum, quam innatum, eo quod (ut tetatur Author) in tenebris non appareat, ed olum de die aut accena candela: I preume the attentive Reader will eaily dicern that his Opinion is much-what the ame that I propos'd and grounded on the ame reaon. But the chief difficulty in this abtrue Phaenomenon, namely why we meet with it but ometimes, our Examiner's Explication leaves untouch'd.

div.head: The 38. and 39. Experiments.
div.p: Againt thee our Author makes no peculiar Objections.

div.head: The 40. and 41. Experiments.
div.p:
But in his Animadverions upon thee, having told the Reader that I eem to acribe the udden extinction of the included Animals to the exceive thinnes of the Air remaining in the Receiver, made by the reces of what was drawn out, unfit for Repiration; he adds reolutely enough, Verum imposibile videtur, ut hujumodi animalcula ob olum defectum crasioris aëris tam cito moriantur: but gives no other reaon then that they dye o oon, which is no more then what he aid in the newly-cited words, and beides is grounded upon omething of mitake. For the Creatures he mentions were a Bee, a Flye, and a Caterpillar, and thoe included too in a mall Receiver, which could be uddenly exhauted: and thee indeed became moveles within a Minute of an Hour; but that Minute was not (as the word is often us'd to ignifie in Englih) a Moment, but the Sixtieth part of an Hour. And though thee Inects did in o hort a time grow moveles, yet they were not o oon kill'd; as appears by the Narrative. The anguineous Animals that did indeed dye, were kill'd more lowly. And I remember that having purpoely
enquir'd of a man (us'd to go under water by the help of an Engine wherein he could carry Air with him to the bottom of the Sea) how long he could endure, before he was accutomed to dive, without breathing or the ue See more concerning this Objection in the Anwer to it as 'tis propos'd by Mr. Hobbes. of a Spunge; he told me, that at firt he could hold out about two or three Minutes at a time: Which made me think that Divers become able to continue under water o long, either by a peculiarly-convenient Contitution of body, or by a gradual exercie. And I am apt to think that he did, as men are wont to do, when he aid two or three Minutes, mean what is indeed a much horter time then that when exactly meaured amounts to. For, having purpoely made tryal upon a couple of Moles that were brought me together alive, one of them included in a mall, though not very mall, Receiver was between two and three Minutes in killing; whereas the other being immediately after detain'd under water did not there continue full a Minute and a quarter, before it finally ceas'd from giving any ign at all of life. By which tryal it may appear, that 'tis not impoible that the want of Repiration hould dipatch an Animal in as little time as is mentioned in the Experiment I am now defending. And indeed our Author either hould have proved that 'tis not poible for the want of Air to detroy Animals o oon, or hould have given us ome better account of the Phaenomenon. For whereas he teaches us, that according to his Doctrine the little Animals above-mentioned were o oon kill'd, qui a per rarefactum illum aërem ee contrahentem extractus it eorum halitus: I ee not that hereby, if he explicate the Phaenomenon otherwie then we, he explains it better; for he eems to peak as if he thought this halitus to be ome peculiar part of the Animal in which his life reides. And beides he eems not to conider, that whereas, according to me as well as according to him, the Air contained in the Lungs (uppoing thee Animalcula have any) mut in great part pas thence into the Receiver, (for whether that be done by the Spring of the Air it elf, that was harboured in the
Lungs, or the traction on of the more rarefi'd Air in the Receiver, is not material in our preent cae) the Examiner mut, as well as I, render a reaon why the extenuation or reces of the halitus hould caue the haty death of the included Animals; and condemning my Conjecture he ought to have ubtituted another reaon: and though he ubjoyns thee words, and concludes with them, At
que hinc quo
que ortae unt vehementes illae convuliones, quas ante mortem paas ee aviculas quadam memorat ibidem Author; yet I doubt not but the Reader will think it had not been amis that the Author had more intelligibly deduc'd thee Tragick Symptoms from his Aumption, for the ake of thoe that are not Anatomits and Phyicians enough to dicern how his Funiculus could produce thee effects.
For my part, as in the 41. Experiment I tender'd my thoughts concerning Repiration but doubtingly, o I am yet unwilling to determine reolvedly in a matter of that difficulty.

div.head: The 42, and 43. Experiments.
div.p: In his Examen of thee two lat of our Phyico-Mechanical Experiments, the Author contents himelf to endeavour to explicate the Phaenomena recited in them by the contraction of the rarefi'd Air; which, according to him, endeavours to draw up the ubjacent water out of the Vial, whereby it vehemently ditends the parts of that water, as he taught in the like cae upon the 20. Experiment. But ince we have already conider'd his Animadverion upon that, although this preumed ditenion of the water is not viible that we have oberv'd, when cold water, that has been firt freed from his interpers'd Air, is put into the Receiver, notwithtanding that the Funiculus hould in that cae alo ditend it; we are o afraid of tiring out the Readers patience by the frequent repetition of the ame things, that we will leave it to him to judge which of the two Explications, the Examiner's or ours, is to be preferred, without troubling him and our elves with defence of Accounts againt which our Adverary does not here make any peculiar Objections.

And thus have we by Gods aitance conidered what the Exam ner hath been pleaed to oppoe either againt our particular Explications, or againt the Hypothees that divers of them uppoe: Wherein I have been the more particular and prolix, becaue I would willingly excue my elf and others from the trouble of any more Diputes of this kind. I hope there is not in my Anwers any thing of Aperity to be met with; for I have no quarrel to the Peron of the Author, or his jut reputation; nor did I intend to ue any more freedom of Speech in the anwering his Objections, then his reolute way of propoing divers of them made it on thoe occaions needful for the Caution of thoe Readers who are not acquainted with our differing wayes of writing, and perhaps have not oberved that ome men are wont to conider as much what they propoe but with a Perhaps, or ome uch expreion of diffidence, as others do what they deliver far more reolutely. And though being very far from being wedded to my Opinions, I am till ready to exchange them for better, if they hall be duly made out to me, (which I think it poible enough they may hereafter be;) yet peradventure the Reader will think with me, that the Examiner has not given me caue to renounce any of them, ince the Objections he has propos'd againt me have been ufficiently anwered, and ince the Hypotheis he would ubtitute in the room of ours (beides that it is partly precarious) uppoes things which divers of the eminentet Wits of our Age (otherwie of differing Opinions) profes they cannot admit or o much as undertand: whereas the Weight and Spring of the Air are not denyed by our Author himelf, and are demontrable by Experiments that are not controverted betwixt us. Which things I repreent for the defence of what I think the Truth, and not to offend my learned Adverary, who hall have my free conent to be thought to have fail'd rather in the Choice then in the Management of the Controverie. Though ince This paes for his firt Book, and ince conequently he is not like to have been provoked, or engaged in point of Reputation, to challenge me or any of thoe far more eminent
Perons he has nam'd among his Adveraries, I am induc'd by the everity wherewith I have known eminent Virtuoi peak of his Attempts, and particularly of his Funiculus, to fear that ome of thoe he has needlely oppos'd, will be apt to apply to him that of St. Autin againt ome of his Adveraries, that had diputed againt him with much more Subtilty then Reaon, In mala caua non pount aliter, at malam cauam quis eos coegit habere? But this notwithtanding I am, as I was going to ay, content my Adverary hould be thought to have aid for his Principles as much as the Subject will bear; nor would I have it made his Diparagement, that I have declared that his whole Book has not made me depart from any of my Opinions or Explications, ince his Hypotheis and mine being inconitent, it may be looked upon as a ign rather that each of us have, then that either of us have not, reaon'd cloely to his own Principles, that the things we infer from our contrary Suppoitions do o generally diagree.

div.head: AN EXPLICATION OF RAREFACTION.
div.p:
THe chief Arguments of the Author of a certain Treatie De corporum ineparabilitate, whereby he endeavours to invalidate the Hypotheis of the Weight and Spring of the Air, and to et up and etablih intead thereof an unintelligible Hypotheis of Attraction, performed by I know not what trange imaginary Funiculus, are onely Five, two againt the former, and three for the later. The firt of which is, That the Weight and Spring of the Air are not ufficient to perform the Effects acribed to them: The econd, that could they be performed by that Hypotheis granted, yet the way of this trange Spring it elf is not intelligibly explained or explicable by the Defenders of it. Now the former of thee being little ele but a bare Affirmation, and the later bearing ome hew of Demontration, I hall endeavour to examine it as I find it et down in his 20, 21, 22, 23, and 24. Chapters, to which (epecially the 23.) he very often in his Book refers the Reader for atisfaction, pretending there to evince that Rarefaction cannot be made out any otherwie
then by uppoing a body to be in 2, 3, 4, 10, 100, 1000, 1000000 of places at the ame intant, and adequately to fill all and every one of thoe places.
Firt therefore, we will examine his Negative, and next his Affirmative, Arguments for this trange Hypotheis.
His Negative I find in the 20. Chapter, where he endeavours to confute the two wayes of explicating the Rarefaction and Spring of the Air, namely, that of the Vacuits and that of the Plenits.

Concerning the firt of thee we find him conclude it impoible, firt, becaue he had before proved that there can be no Vacuum, which being done by a Circle (viz. There is no Vacuum in the Tube becaue Nature abhors a Vacuum, and we ee Nature abhors a Vacuum becaue he will not uffer a Vacuum in the Tube above the Mercury, but to prevent it will continually pin the Quickilver into upe ficies, and never diminih the body of it) will uffer me to pas to his next, which is, That this way is fale, becaue in the Experiment of the Carps Bladder the Air is rarefi'd a 1000. times bigger; nay, in repect of the body of Gold it has 1000000. times les matter in equal paces. And this, ayes he, is a Phaenomenon that is impoible ever to be made out by interpers'd Vacuities. Now that the Vacuits cannot preently, by o bold an aertion as this, be made to forake their Principles, he may perceive by thee following Solutions which I hall give of all the Phaenomena he recites, flowing naturally from an Hypotheis that I hall for the preent aume. Let us uppoe then the Particles of Bodies, at leat thoe of the Air, to be of the form of a piece of Riband, that is, to be very long, lender, thin and flexible laminae, coyled or wound up together as a Cable, piece of Riband, Spring of a Watch, Hoop, or the like, are: we will uppoe thee to have all of them the ame length, but ome to have a tronger, others a weaker Spring: we will further uppoe each of thee o coyled up to have uch an innate circular motion, as that thereby they may decribe a Sphere equal in Diameter to their own, much after the manner that a Meridian turn'd about the Poles of a Globe will decribe
by its revolution a Sphere of the ame Diameter with its own in the Air. By this Circular motion the parts of the laminae endeavouring to recede from the Centre or Axis of their motion, acquire a Springines outward like that of a Watch-Spring, and would naturally flye abroad untill they were tretch'd out at length, but that being incompat with the like on every ide, they cannot do it without the removal of them, as not having room ufficient for uch a motion. And the fater this circular motion is, the more do the parts endeavour to recede from the Axis, and conequently the tronger is their Spring or endeavour outward. Thee pringy bodies thus hap'd and thus moved are ufficient to produce all the Phaenomena he names as impoible to be explicated. And, firt, for the buines of Expanion, it will very naturally be explained by it: As let us uppoe for intance the Diameter of thee mall coyled Particles of the Air (which being next the Earth are pres'd upon by all thoe numerous incumbent Particles that make up the Atmophere, and are thereby o crouded that they can but very little untwit themelves; let us uppoe, I ay, the Diameter of thee Particles) to be 1/1000000000000 of an Inch; and then to be much of the form of thoe repreented in the 4. Figure by A B C D: and that thee Particles, when a coniderable quantity of the preure of the ambient parts is taken away, will flye abroad into a Coyle or Zone ten times as big in Diameter as before; that is, they will now be 10/1000000000000 of an Inch in Diameter, and appear in the form of thoe in the Figure expret by E F G H: thee Zones whirl'd round as the former will decribe a Sphere a 1000. times as big in bulk, and thereby fence that pace from being entred by any of the like Zones: this it would do, uppoing thoe Spheres did immediately alwayes touch each other; but becaue of their circular motion, whenever they meet they mut necearily be beaten, and flye off from one another, and o require a yet greater pace to perform their motion in. This uppos'd, there are no Phaenomena of Rarefaction (which is enough at preent to anwer what he objects) but may be naturally and intelligibly
made out. As firt, for that of the welling of a Carps Bladder, if we uppoe ome mall parcels of the former compret laminae to lye latitant within the folds of it, and being much coyled up together carce to take any enible room, this Bladder in the Air will appear to contain very little or nothing within it; whereas when the preure of the Air is taken off in good part from the outides of it, then thoe formerly latitant Particles dicloe themelves by flying open into much bigger Zones, o as perhaps to be able to defend a thouand times bigger pace from being entred into by their like or any other gros Particles, uch as thoe of the Bladder. Now becaue the Pores of a Bladder are uch as are not eaily permeable by the Particles of Air, therefore thee lurking Particles o expanding themelves mut necearily plump out the ides of the Bladder, and o keep them turgid untill the preure of the Air that at firt coyled them be re-admitted to do the ame thing for them again.

Next, as for Rarefaction by heat, that will as naturally follow as the former from this Hypotheis. For the Atoms of fire flowing in in great numbers, and paing through with a very rapid motion, mut needs accelerate the motion of thee Particles, from which acceleration their Spring or endeavour outward will be augmented, that is, thoe Zones will have a trong nitency to flye wider open, (for we know that the wifter any body is moved circularly, the more do the parts of it endeavour to recede from the Centre of that motion) from whence if it has room will follow a Rarefaction. As for the conveyance of Light, that being according to Epicurus performed by the local motion of peculiar Atoms, their motions to and fro through this medium will be les impeded by the rarefi'd Air then by the condens'd; as indeed upon Experiment we hall really find them.

As for his third Objection drawn from his uppoed attractive virtue of the thus rarefi'd Air, that is quickly anwered, by denying it to have any power at all of attraction; and by hewing (which is already done) that what effects he would have to be performed by the attraction of the included, is really done by the preure of the ambient, Air.
And, latly, the Phaenomena of my Lord Bacons Experiment are ufficiently obvious and eaie to be deduc'd.

So then, by granting Epicurus his Principles, that the Atoms or Particles of bodies have an innate motion; and granting our Suppoition of the determinate motion and figure of the Aerial Particles, all the Phaenomena of Rarefaction and Condenation, of Light, Sound, Heat, &c. will naturally and necearily follow: and the Authors Objections againt this firt way of Rarefaction will ignifie very little.

As to the econd way of Rarefaction, by the intruion or intervention of ome ubtil matter of Aether into the paces deerted by the rareying Particles, which is that propos'd by the Aertors of a Plenum, this alo is by the Author condemned, and branded with Impoibility. And why? Firt, becaue 'tis (he ayes) impoible that the above-mentioned Phaenomena of the Carps Bladder can be explained by it. Secondly, becaue 'tis impoible to give a reaon from it of the impetuous acent of Water admitted into an exhauted Receiver. And, Thirdly, becaue 'tis impoible to explicate the Phaenomena of Gun-powder. His Reaons to confirm which three Impoibilities, becaue drawn from a meer mitake, or ignorance of thoe Hypothees which have been invented by the Aertors of that Opinion, I hall pas over, and content my elf to explain a way how thee Impoibilities may become Poibilities, if not Probabilities.

And the way that I hall take, hall be that of the mot acute Modern Philoopher Monieur Des Cartes, publihed in his Philoophical Works: Which is this, That the Air is a Body coniting of long, lender, flexible particles, agitated or whirl'd round by the rapid motion of the Globuli Coeletes, and the ubtile Matter of his firt Element, whereby they are each of them enabled to drive or force out of their Vortice all uch other agitated particles. Now the wifter thee Bodies are whirl'd round, the more do their flexible parts fly aunder and tretch themelves out; and the more forcibly do they reit the ingree of any other o
agitated particles into their Vortice, and conequently the lower their motion is, the les will be their reitance. And becaue there is a vat number of thee whirled particles lying one above another, and each particle having its peculiar gravity; it will necearily follow that the undermot (which to maintain their Vortice mut reit o great a preure) mut very much be hindred from expanding themelves o far as otherwie they would, were there none of thoe incompaing agitated Particles that lay in their way: and that thoe being by any means removed, or they themelves by a more rapid motion of the Particles of their Vehicles, the firt and econd Element, (which is according to that Hypotheis an effect of Heat) more wiftly and trongly whirled round, they preently begin to expand themelves, and maintain a bigger Vortice then before. Now to perform what I jut now promied, I hall endeavour to give a poible, if not a probable, caue of the objected Phaenomena. And, Firt, for that of the Carps Bladder, where the Air is rarefi'd (ayes the Author) 1000. times, it will eaily be explained by uppoing the few Particles of the Air, which (whilet they utain the preure of all the incumbent Atmophere) inconpicuouly luck within the Bladder, (each of them being able to maintain but a very mall Vortice) to be by the ubiding Mercury in the Torricellian Experiment freed from the preure of the Air, and their motion continuing the ame (by reaon that the Trancurion of their Vehicles is not at all or very little hindered either by the Glas or Bladder) their parts having room to expand themelves, will flye abroad to uch Extenions as may perhaps make a Vortice 1000. times as big in bulk as what they were not able jut before to exceed. Hence the Particles of the Air (being o gros as not eaily to pervade the Pores of the Bladder) mut necearily drive out the fides of the Bladder to its utmot extent, and erve to fill the Receiver in the Magdeburgick Experiment. Now, whereas thee Particles will by the ame preure of the Air be reduc'd to the ame tate they were in at firt, that is, to be thronged into a very little room, and
thereby be able to maintain a very mall Vortice; the Air let in in the Torrecellian Experiment reduces the Air in the Bladder to its former inconpicuounes; as the admiion of the Water in the Magdeburg Experiment does that Receiver full of rarefi'd Air into the bignes of a Hazel Nut. Now the Water in this lat-mention'd Experiment enters with a great impetuoity, becaue driven on with the whole preure of the Atmophere, and reited onely by the mall force of the o-far-rarefi'd Air.

As for the Authors Objection againt this way of Rarefaction drawn from the Phaenomena of Gun powder, I hall endeavour to anwer it by hewing them poibly explicable by a Carteian Hypotheis. For uppoing thoe Terretrial parts of the Gun powder to be firt at ret, and afterwards agitated by the rapid motion of his firt Element, there will be ufficient difference of the former and later condition in repect of Extenion; and uppoing the particular contitution of Gun-powder (ariing partly from the Specifick forms of the Particles of its ingredients; Nitre, Sulphure and Char-coal, and partly from their proportionate commition) to be uch as will readily yield to the motion of his Materia ubtilis, o oon as an ingres is admitted to it by the fireing of any particular parcel of it, the Expanion will be peedy enough.

So then let us uppoe a Barrel of Gun-powder placed in ome cloe room, to ome grains of which we will uppoe ome actual fire to be applied, by which actual fire (the Texture of the Powder being uch) thoe grains are uddenly fired, that is, many Millions of parts, which before lay till and at ret, are by the action of the burning Coals hatter'd, as it were, and put into a poture ready to be agitated by the rapid motion of the Materia ubtilis: into which poture they are no ooner put, then agitated and whirled ufficiently by it; whence follows a vat Expanion of that part of Gun-powder o fired. For each of its parts being thus whirl'd and hurried round, expell and beat off with great violence all the contiguous Particles, o as that each Particle takes up now 1000. times as much Elbow-room (if I
may o peak) as jut before erv'd its turn, and conequently thoe that are outermot take every one their way directly from the parcel or Corn they had lain quiet in, being hurried away by the udden Expanion of the Particles that lay next within them; o that whatever grain or parcel of Gun-powder they chance to meet with, before they have lot their motion, they preently hiver and put into uch a motion as makes them fit to receive the action of the Materia ubtilis. Which ubtil Matter being every where preent, and nothing low in performing its office, immediately agitates thoe alo like the former; o that in a trice the Particles of the whole Barrel of Gun-powder are thus diordered, and by the motion the Materia ubtilis mut needs be hurried away with o great an impetuoity on all ides, as not onely to break in pieces its light wooden prion, and remove the lighter Particles of the ambient Air, but huge Beams, nay, vat accumulated Maes of the mot compacted Structures of Stone, and even hake the very Earth it elf, or whatever ele tands in its way, whoe Texture is o cloe as not to give its Particles free paage through its Pores. This undertood, I ee not, firt, what the Authors three Arguments brought to prove his Objection ignifie, for there are no more Corpucles in the room before the Gun-powder is fired then after, nor is there any more matter or ubtance before the ides of the room by yielding give place for the external fluid bodies to ucceed, and the onely change is this, that the Globuli ecundi Elementi (as he calls them) are expell'd out of the room, and the Materia primi Elementi ucceeds in the place of it. Nor do I ee, econdly, what great reaon he had for his grand Concluion, Haec abundè demontrant, rarefactionem per hujumodi corpucula nullatenus poe explicari.

Having thus examined the Authors firt Arguments, that Rarefaction cannot be made out by any other way then his; we hall find his other, which he brings to etablih his own Hypotheis, much of the ame kind. As, Firt, that his way of Rarefaction implies no Contradiction: For if the affirming a body to be
really and totally in this place, and at the ame time to be really and wholly in another, that is, to be in this place, and not to be in this place, be not a Contradiction, I know not what is. Next, that ome learned School-men have thought o; to which I anwer, more learned men have thought otherwie. And, latly, that there are very plain Examples of the like nature to be found in other things; of which he onely brings one, viz. that of the Rota Aritotelica, which upon examination we hall find to make as little to the purpoe as any of the other.

div.head: An Explication of the Rota Aritotelica.
div.p:
THe great Problem of the Rota Aritotelica, by his explication of which he pretends not onely to olve all the difficulties concerning Local motion, quae Philoophoru¯ ingenia hactenus valde exercuerant, but to give an intance for the confirmation of his unintelligible Hypotheis of Rarefaction, wherein there is extenio eu correpondentia ejudem rei ad locum nunc majorem, nunc minorem; we may upon examination find to be either a Paralogime, or ele nothing but what thoe Philoophers aid whom he accounts gravel'd with it. Of this Subject he begins in his 25. Chapter, where after he has et down a decription of it, he makes an intance in a Cart-wheel; Rem ante oculos ponit rota alicujus currus, eju
que umbo eu lignum illud craum & rotundum cui infiguntur radii; iquidem dum progrediente curru ipa rota circumducta decribit in ubjecta terra orbitam ibi aequalem, umbo ille decribit in ubjecto aëre orbitam. (I uppoe both here and before he means Lineam) e multo longiorem, utpote aequalem orbitae totius rotae, licet ipe non nii emel quo
que fuerit circumvolutus. (As for what he ayes, that the Nave mut be uppos'd to pas through the Air, and not to touch a olid Plain, I do not yet undertand the force of his Reaon, nor why he ets it down, making nothing to his preent purpoe, unles it were becaue he did not
well undertand the thing) In which, ayes he, the great difficulty is to explain how the Nave hould be o turned about its Axis, ut partes uas uccesivè applicet lineae duplo plures partes habenti, id
que motu perpetuo ac uniformi nè vel ad oculum intar interrupto. Which how true, and what great occaion he had to wonder at the olution of that Problem by the Example of a man tanding till and another walking, we hall find by and by, when we come to explain the Problem: but firt I hall examine his Hypoth is and Explication. And Firt, he uppoes Time to conit of a determinate number of Indiviibles, (that is, uch as have neither prius nor poterius included in them) which he calls Intants. And next he uppoes the praeentiam localem eu ubicationem cujulibet part is indiviibilis & virtualiter extenae ee quo
que indiviibilem & virtualiter extenam: Which uppoition o trangely expret is no more then this, that the extenion or pace of his Indiviibles is alo indiviible. But as for his Virtual Extenion, I cones I undertand as little what it is as I verily believe he did; and therefore I will proceed to his following uppoition. His Third therefore is, That by how much more rare a body is, by o much the more are its Indiviibles virtually extended. Hence his Fourth is, That though thee Indiviibles be really indiviible, yet they are virtually in quotvis partes diviibiles. Whence he deduces his Fifth Principle, That ince thee Indiviibles are really indiviible and virtually extended, they mut necearily be moved after the ame manner that other indiviible and virtually-extended things are. His Intances are in the motions of an Angel and an indiviible piece of wood, which, he ayes, are both of the ame kind. As for that of Angels, having no immediate Revelation, and a Spirit and its actions not falling under ene, and not having any third way by which to be inform'd, I hall leave him there to enjoy his fancies. But as for that of his piece of wood, we hall find it ufficiently full of aburdities and contradictions. And firt, he calls it indiviible, but why I know not, for 'tis neither really nor yet mentally o: not mentally o by his fourth Principle, where he ayes that 'tis
virtualiter in quotvis partes diviibiles, by which word virtualiter he means the ame thing with mentaliter, or nothing. Nor, econdly, is it really o: for then (according to the main buines of his Book, as may be gathered from the firt words of his Title-Page, Tractatus de Corporum Ineparabilitate) it would be impoible that any thing in the world hould be diviible; for he making an ineparable continuity, and that bodies will rather be (I can't tell how) tretcht beyond their own dimenion in infinitum, then part from one another; a body may as oon pas through the dimenions of any one Indiviible, as pas between two. Next, he grants in the trange tretching or rarefaction of thee Indiviibles a temporary motion of the condens'd Dimenion; whence there will follow that there mut be ditinct places or Ubi's, it mut be terminus à quo, terminus ad quem, & medium. And next, it were impoible to divide a line into two parts, uppoing it conited of an unequal number of Indiviibles; as if 101. Indiviibles of exceedingly-rarefi'd Air hould be extended in length an Inch, it were impoible to divide that Inch into two equal parts. I might run over many more, but it would be too tedious to be here recited. As for his indiviible parts of Time, thoe alo mut necearily be in quotvis partes diviibiles; for ele the ame body or Indiviible mut necearily be in divers places at the ame intant. But becaue he can wallow, nay confidently affirm, this and many other uch like contradictions and aburdities, I am not willing to mention them; and I think it would have made more for the Authors reputation if he had done o too. As for his lat Chapter, where he applies thee Principles to the Explication of the Rota Aritotelica, I have not here time to et down all the aburdities that any one that has but a mattering in the Mathematicks may oberve: as, ometimes half an indiviible part of a Circumference may touch an indiviible of a Line; ometimes one may touch half, a quarter, a hundredth part, a whole one, two, ten, a hundred, &c. at the ame intant; nay, an indiviible of a Circle may be all of it in a thouand places together, and the like. And this he brings as a
great Argument to etablih his Hypotheis of Rarefaction, pretending it to comprie many Aenigma's and very great difficulties; whereas the thing is very plain and eaie, and contains no uch obcurities. For if, for example, we uppoe a Wheel ABCD to be moved in a direct motion from AIC to KLM, every point of it retaining the ame poition to that line that they had at the beginning of their motion, each of the points AEIGC will on a Plain, or in the Medium it pervades, pas through or decribe a line equal to the line IL, and not onely all the points lying in the line AIC, but all and every point of the whole Area of the Circle; this mut necearily happen if the Diameter AIC be moved parallel to it elf: But if whilet it be thus moved with an equal progreion, it be likewie moved with an equal circulation, the cae will be altered. For then, firt, each point will by this compound motion decribe on the Plain or Medium either a perfect Cyclorid, as when the Wheel makes one perfect revolution, whilet the whole is progreively moved from I to L; or ome Piece, as when the Wheel has not perfected its revolution; or more then a whole one, as when the Circle has made more then one whole revolution whilet it is moved in its determinate length. I hall here onely conider the firt, as pertaining more epecially to my preent purpoe, and in regard the two later on occaion may be eaily explicated by it. Next, each point of this Circle acquires from its compounded motion various degrees of Celerity as to its progreion, according to its various poition to a point which is alwayes found in ome part of the line drawn through the Centre of the circular motion perpendicular to the progreive. And it is found thus, as the Circumference to the Radius, o is the line of the progreive motion to the ditance of the point from the Centre. And this happens becaue the line of Progreion is equal to the Circle decribed on that ditance as Radius; each point therefore of this maller Circle, when it comes to touch the Perpendicular, mut, as to its progreive motion, tand till: This point therefore will be the Centre of this compounded motion. Now becaue for
the explication of the Rota Aritotelica we need not conider any other then thoe Points which are tranient through or cros the Perpendicular line, we hall onely examine them. Let then in our Example A be the Centre or immoveable point, the Circumference therefore ABCD will be equal to IL or AK by our Hypotheis. Now becaue the point I, which is the Centre of the Rotation, has onely one motion, viz. that of Lation, its celerity will be equal to the ingle celerity of the Lation; we will therefore put it to have one degree. C, becaue it is moved with two motions, both tending the ame way, and each equal to the velocity of I, mut needs have two degrees of velocity. The point F, becaue moved with two motions, both tending the ame way, the one (viz. its Lation) being equal to that of I, and the other (becaue it is but half as far ditant from the Centre of Rotation as C, and therefore is moved but with half the celerity of C, which was equal to that of I) but half as quick, we will put to have one degree and an half. By the like method we might find the velocity of all the points in the Perpendicular, viz. uch as we have there marked ome of them; but it would be too tedious, we needing not to conider more then the two points A and E. The point at E being moved forward by its progreion with the ame velocity that I, but by its rotation (which is but half as wift as that of the Circle ABCD, that is double the Circle EFGH) being moved the contrary way or backwards with half the velocity, loeth half of its progreion forwards. The point in A being by its progreion moved forwards equally wift with I, and by its rotation (the Circle ABCD being equal to the line IL) being carried backwards with equal velocity, mut necearily tand till as to its progreion. Now having hewn that the point A (being by reaon of its two equal oppoite motions at ret) does onely touch a point of the line AK, and is not at all moved on it; and that the point E (being carried forward twice as fat by its progreion as it is carried backward by its rotation, and thereby moved half as fat as the point I) does not onely touch the line EK, but whilet it touches it is moved on it with a
progreive motion half as wift as that of I: It will necearily follow, that each point ituate in E mut necearily decribe a mall line, which is a part of the whole EC. Now both the contact of the former, and the contact and progreion of the later, being performed by an infinite ucceion of points in the pace of an infinite ucceion of Intants; I ee not any one difficulty of this Problem but may atisfactorily be given an account of by it, without having recoure to the Hypotheis of the determinate number of indiviibles of pace and time; which at bet will onely come to this, that In uch a determinate moment or minute pace of time, (which conits of an infinite conecution of Intants, and has prius and poterius in it; though yet he will call it an Intant, and have it to have the ame proprieties with an Intant ued in the common Philoophical ene) uch a determinate minute Corpucle (which, though it have extenion in length, breadth and thicknes, yet will he not admit it to be diviible or have parts, no not though, according to his Hypotheis, the indiviible of one body may be rarefied to be as big in bulk as a million of the indiviibles of another, but will have it to be called and to be a real indiviible) will uccesively pas over uch a determinate pace or length (which yet he will not admit to be diviible, though according to his Principles it may equalize the length of millions of his other Indiviibles, nor admit a ucceive motion, but intantaneous, though that does necearily put a body into two, three, ten, a hundred, &c. places at once; but will have thee alo to be indiviible.) Hate makes me pas over the aburdities about the contact of a Circle and a Line, and to comprie in hort all that great Explication he has given of this and other intricate (as he calls them) Problems, which is this, That the reaon of the celerity of the motion of ome one of thee indiviibles above another is, that it paes through a greater part of an indiviible in the ame intant then the lower; that is in plain ene no more then this, One body is wifter then another becaue it is moved fater, From whence he draws everal Corollaries, as that
Hence may be given a reaon why an Eagle is wifter then a Tortoie, viz. becaue it moves fater. I hould have olved everal Objections which may be brought againt the diviibility of Quantity in infinitum; but that as all the Scholatick Writers are full of them, o it is a Subject which we are leat able to dipute of, having very little information of the nature of Infinity from the Senes.

div.head: The Citations Englih'd.
div.p: CHap. 2. Pag. 4. Cum tota vis, &c. Being the whole power of the Spring of the Air depends upon the Aequilibrium of its weight with twenty nine Inches and an half of Quickilver, o that this Spring doth neither more nor les in a hut place, then is done by that Aequilibrium in an open place: it is manifet, eeing we have hewed the Aequilibrium to be plainly fictitious and imaginary, that the Spring acribed to the Air is o likewie.

Ibid. Nam i Tubus, &c. For if a Tube but twenty Inches long (uch as we ued in our firt Argument) be not quite filled with Quickilver, as before, but a little pace be left betwixt the Mercury and the Finger on the top of the Tube, in which Air onely may abide: We hall find that the Finger below being removed, the Finger on the top will not onely be drawn downwards, as before, but the Quickilver hall decend alo, and that notably, viz. as much as o mall a parcel of Air can be extended by uch a decending weight. So that if intead of Air, Water or any other Liquor which is not o eaily extended be put in its place, there will be no decent at all.

Hence, I ay, againt this Opinion an Argument is framed: For if the external Air cannot keep up thoe twenty Inches of Quickilver from decending, as we have proved; how hall it keep up twenty nine Inches and an half? Auredly thee can no way be reconciled.
p. 5. Dices fortè, &c. You will perchance ay, that the Quickilver therefore doth in the alledged cae decend, becaue it is thrut down by that parcel of Air which dilates it elf by its own Spring.
Ibid. Sic deberet, &c. So hould the Finger be rather thrut from the top of the Tube, then thereby fatned to it; becaue this Dilatation mut be made as well upwards as downwards.

p. 6. Concipi, &c. It cannot be conceived how that Air hould dilate it elf, or thrut down the Mercury, unles by taking up a greater place; which thing thee Authors are much againt, aerting that Rarefaction can be made no other wayes then by Corpucles or Vacuities.

Chap. 3. p. 7. Si, &c. If you take a Tube open at both ends of a good length, uppoe forty Inches long, and fill it with Mercury, and place your Finger on the top as before, taking away your lower Finger you will find the Mercury to decend even to its wonted tation, and your Finger on the top to be trongly drawn within the Tube, and to tick cloe
unto it. Whence again it is evidently concluded that the Mercury placed in its own tation is not there upheld by the external Air, but upended by a certain internal Cord, whoe upper end being fatned to the Finger draws and fatens it after this manner into the Tube.

Chap. 4. p. 8, 9. Sumatur, &c. Take a Tube horter then twenty nine Inches and an half, for intance of twenty Digits, not hut, as hitherto, at one end, but with both ends open: let this Tube, its Orifice being immers'd in retagnant Mercury, and one Finger being plac'd underneath, that the Mercury to be poured in run not through, be filled with Mercury; and then another Finger be applied to its Orifice, to cloe it well: Which being done, if you draw away your lower Finger, the upper will be found to be trongly drawn and uck'd into the Tube, and o tifly to adhere to it, (or rather to the Quickilver, as I hall hereafter hew) that it will elevate the Tube it elf with all the Quickilver, and make it continue to hang pendulous in the Veel.

From which Experiment this Opinion is mot clearly refuted: For, eeing according to it the Quickilver in uch a Tube but twenty Inches long mut be thrut upwards by the preponderating Air; it will never by it be explained how this Finger is o drawn downwards, and made o trongly to tick to the Tube. For it cannot by the Air thruting upwards be thus drawn downwards.

p. 11. Quod vel, &c. Which is thence confirmed, Becaue if that preponderating Air ucceeds, as is aerted, in the place of the lower Finger which was withdrawn, that is, if it uphold the Quickilver after the ame manner which it was upheld by the lower Finger applied under it; it is manifet, according to this Opinion, that the Finger on the top ought not to be more drawn downwards after the lower Finger is removed then before. Seeing then that Experience teacheth the contrary, it is manifet that Opinion mut be fale.

Chap. 5. p. 12. Quarto, &c. In the fourth place it is impugn'd, Becaue thence it would follow that Quickilver through a like Tube might be uck'd with the ame eaines out of a Veel that Water is uck'd out of the ame. Which not withtanding is contrary to Experience, by which we are taught that Water is eaily drawn into the mouth of him that ucks, whereas Quickilver cannot be drawn thither by his utmot endeavour, nay, carce unto the middle of the Tube.

The equel I thus manifet: Becaue eeing, according to this Opinion, that the Liquor underneath, whether it be Water or Mercury, may o acend, no more is requir'd but that the Air hut in the Tube may be drawn upwards by ucking; which being drawn up, the Liquor underneath will
immediately acend, being thrut thither by the external Air now preponderating, (as Pecquet declares in his Anatomical Dicoure, p. 63.) It is manifet that the Mercury may be uck'd out with the ame eaines that Water is uck'd out with. Which being o evidently againt Experience, the Opinion from whence it is deduced mut needs be fale.

p. 14. Ne
que hoc, &c. And not onely this, but over and above, if a Glas Diabetes or Syringe be made of a ufficient length, and after that the Sucker is thrut into the utmot Orifice, it be placed according to ue in the Mercury underneath; he finds that as oon as the Sucker is drawn out, the Mercury follows, and acends to the ame height of two Feet and three Inches and an half. And when afterwards, although no greater force be added, the Sucker is drawn higher, he finds that the Mercury tands, and follows no further, and o that pace is made empty which remains between the Mercury and the Sucker.

p. 16. Maneat igitur, &c. Be it therefore confirm'd by o many Arguments, of which every one is ufficient in it elf, that Quickilver (the Experiment being made in an open place) is not upheld from falling by the weight of the external Air.
Cap. 6. p. 16. Argentum, &c. That Quickilver in a cloe place is not upheld from falling by the Elater or Spring of the Air.

Ibid. Cum tota, &c. Seeing the whole power of this Spring depends upon the already-confured Aequilibrium of the Air with 29. Inches and an half of Quickilver, o that this Spring does neither more nor les in a cloe place then is done by that Aequilibrium in an open place; it is manifet, eeing this Aequilibrium is already hewn to be plainly fictitious and imaginary, that the Spring of the Air is o likewie.
Ibid. Nec plus, &c. And that this Spring doth neither more nor les in a cloe place, then is done by that Aequilibrium in an open place.

p. 17. Adde, &c. Adde, that eeing the Experiments brought in the Chapter above of the adheion of the Finger, &c. are alike in a cloe and an open place; it is neceary and certain that the ame Arguments made againt the Aequilibrium have force againt the Spring of the Air.

Ibid. Et profecto, &c. And really if thee Authors would conider how great a difficulty there is in explaining this Spring of the Air, unle; the ame Air by it elf alone may take up a greater place, I believe they would readily alter their Opinion.

Part 2. Chap. 1. p. 20. Contat hoc, &c. This appears from what has been already poken in the preceding Chapter: For the Quickilver decending cannot o draw the Finger downwards, and faten it unto the Tube, unles it be hung upon the Finger by uch a Cord, which by its
weight it vehemently tretches, as is manifet by it elf.
Ibid. Repondeo, &c. I anwer, That this comes to pas that there may be no Vacuity, eeing there is nothing ele there that can ucceed into the place of the decending Quickilver.
p. 21. And hence is confirm'd that common Axiom ued in the Schools for o many Ages pat, that Nature doth abhor a Vacuum.

Ibid. Nam licet, &c. For though the immediate caue why water (for intance) doth not decend from a Gardeners Watering-pot (for that Example they ue) topt on the top, is not the fear of a Vacuum, but the reaon now mentioned, namely, That there is not weight ufficient to looe that conjuncture by which the water doth adhere to the top of the cloed Water-pot: Nevertheles in the end we mut of neceity come to that Caue.

Ibid. Quae quidem, &c. Which traction and adheion when it cannot proceed but from ome real body placed between the Finger and the Mercury, it is manifet that that pace is not empty, but filled with ome true ubtance.
Ibid. Eo quod, &c. Becaue no viual pecies's could proceed either from it, or through it, unto the eye.
p. 22. Vera, &c. To be filled with any true ubtance.

p. 25. Huc etiam, &c. And to this purpoe make thoe coniderable Vibrations with which Quickilver is tirred in its decent: For the ame thing happens here that befalls other Pendula in their fall from on high.

p. 29. Argentum dum, &c. Quickilver while it fills the whole Tube doth not onely touch its top, (as you would think at the firt ight) but doth firmly tick unto it alo; as it is manifet from the Experiment mentioned in the first Argument of the third Chapter, concerning the Tube open at both ends.
Ibid. Licet illud, &c. Though that Orifice of the Tube be anointed with Oyle, or any other matter that will hinder adheion, nevertheles the Finger will no les firmly tick then before.

Ibid. Partes, &c. That the parts of Air it elf o hut up in the Tube (which otherwie are o eaily evered) are now o firmly glued to one another, that they make (as we ee) a trong Chain, by which not onely Water but even weighty Quickilver is drawn on high.

Ibid. Rarefactionem, &c. That the Rarefaction or Extenion of a body o as to make it take up more pace is not onely made by Heat, but by ditenion or a certain disjoyning power; as on the contrary Condenation is not onely made by Cold, but alo by Compreion, as infinite Examples hear us witnes.

p. 30. Cum per, &c. Seeing by the firt Note 'tis manifet that the Quickilver doth o tick to the top of the Tube, and by the econd Note the Rarefaction is made onely by the meer ditenion of the body; it o comes to pas that the decending Quickilver leaves its external or upper uperficies fixed unto the top of the Tube, and by its weight doth o tretch and extenuate it, untill it becomes eaier to leave another uperficies in like manner, then to extend that any further. It leaves therefore a econd, and doth by its decent extend that a little further, untill it becomes eaier to eparate a third then to extend that any further: And o forwards, untill at length it hath no power to eparate or extend any more uperficies, namely, untill it comes unto the heighth of 29. Inches and an half; where it acquieces, as we have declared in the firt Chapter.

p. 31. Thee Surfaces eem to be eparated from the Quickilver, and to be extended into a mot lender tring by the weight that falls down, after the ame manner that in a lighted Candle urfaces of like ort are eparated from the Wax or Tallow underneath by the heat above, and are extenuated into a mot ubtil flame. In which it is worth obervation, that as that flame doth doubtles take up more then a thouand times a greater pace then the part of the Wax of which the flame was made took up: So is it here to be thought, that that tring doth take up a pace more then a thouand times as big as that which the mall particle of Mercury, from whence it aroe, did before take up. As alo it doubtles happens when uch a particle by a fire underneath is turned into a vapour.
