p. 37. Corpore, &c. A body taking up a place, for intance, twice as big as it elf; it is of neceity that every part of it mut likewie take up a place twice as big as it elf.
p. 42. Juxta, &c. According to the more probable Opinion uch a virtual extenion of a corporeal Being is not to be granted, as being onely proper to uch as are Spiritual.

p. 43. Praetat, &c. It is better to continue in the common Opinion, which hath been hitherto received in the Schools: which although it doth not clearly reolve all difficulties, yet it doth not openly lye under them.

Ibid. Neceario, &c. We mut needs confes that one and the ame part mut be in two places adequately. For eeing it is indiviible, and takes up a greater place then before, it mut of neceity be all in every point of that place, or that be virtually extended through all that pace.
p. 45. Cum tempus, &c. Seeing Time is a Being eentially ucceive, o that neither by divine power can two of its parts exit together.

p. 46. Repondeo, &c. I anwer, that all thee things happen becaue the Gun-powder o kindled and turned into flame takes up a much greater pace then before. Whence it comes to pas that eeing the Chamber was before quite full, by this means the walls are broken that there may be no penetration of bodies.
p. 50. Partim, &c. Sometimes within the Chappel, ometimes in the open Air; the wind ometimes blowing, and ometimes being till.

p. 54. Sed d'ci, &c. But it may be aid, that on the top of the Mountain it therefore decended after that manner, becaue the Air was more cold there, or of ome other temperature, uch as might caue this decent.
p. 71. Hoc ee, &c. That this is the difference between Preion and Suction, that Suction makes uch an adheion, and Preion doth not.

Ibid. Hoc quo
que , &c. And even this Experiment doth very well agree with our Principles: For eeing by this depreion of the Sucker, the Air hut up in the cavity of the Cylinder is eparated from the Cylinder, and doth decend together with the Sucker, (as we have, Chap. 13. oberved of water decending together with Quickilver) it comes to pas that in that whole depreion new urfaces are taken from that decending Air, and tretched out, as we have there explained it in the cae of decending water. Since therefore uch Sufaces are as eaily lipt off and extended in the end of the depreion as in the beginning; it is no wonder that there is found the ame difficulty of depreing it at both times.
p. 72. Eo magis, &c. That the Air is o much the more extended and rarefied, by how much the more is thence exhauted, and o doth acquire a greater force of contracting it elf.
p. 74. At profecto, &c. But truly it eems not credible that this mot oft Air hould o vehemently compres a Glas on all ides (epecially one of that thicknes there mention'd) as to break it.

Ibid. Verius, &c. It is therefore more truly anwered, that the Glas is therefore o broken, becaue by that exuction its ides are more vehemently drawn inwards then (by reaon of the figure unfit for reitency) they were able to reit. For eeing the included Air doth mot firmly tick to the ides of the Glas, to draw out the Air will be nothing ele but to endeavour to bend the ides of the Glas inwards.

p. 75. Sed profecto, &c. But truly this eems too far remov'd from Truth, and may be by this alone ufficiently refuted. Becaue if the preure of the Air which decends by that Tube into the Vial be o great as to break the Vial it elf, it ought certainly, before the breaking of the Vial, very much to move the water in which the Tube is immers'd, and to
excite bubbles in it, &c. as appears, if any one blowing through that Tube doth make but an ordinary preure upon the water. But it is ure that the water before the Vial is broken doth not move at all: as the Experimenter will find.
Ibid. Licet, &c. Though the Tube had been hut at the top, the Vial had doubtles been broken after the ame manner.
p. 77. Sed rectius, &c. But it is more rightly thence inferr'd, that that Cylinder did nothing there before.

Ibid. Dico, &c. I ay then that the Quickilver doth by that exhaution o decend in the Tube, becaue it is drawn downwards by the Air incumbent upon the retagnant Quickilver. For that incumbent Air, being by its exhaution greatly rarefied and extended, vehemently contracts it elf, and by this contraction doth endeavour to lift the retagnant Mercury out of its Veel; whence it comes to pas that (the retagnant Mercury now les gravitating upon the bottom of its Veel) the Quickilver in the Tube mut decend, as is manifet in it elf: So that it is no wonder that, the external Air afterwards entring, the Quickilver again acends, eeing by that ingres the force which elevates the retagnant Quickilver is weakned.

p. 78. At
que hinc, &c. And hence is a reaon alo given of another thing which is there noted, namely, that by the violent intruion of the external Air into the Receiver the Quickilver acended coniderably above 29. Inches and an half. For as by the extraction of the Air the Quickilver is depret below its tation, o by the intruion of new Air it is elevated above it.

p. 80. Nam i, &c. For if it were kept up by that, it ought rather to acend then decend in colder weather, becaue the Air then would be more dene and heavy. Therefore the Quickilver is not upheld by the Aequilibrium of Air, as is aerted.
Ibid. Hinc fit, &c. Hence it comes to pas, that this Funicle being contracted by the cold, the water doth acend in cold weather; but doth decend in hot, becaue by heat the Funicle is dilated.

p. 81. Ego certè, &c. I truly do not doubt but there are ome uch occult caues, by which the lender Eunicle that upends (as we mentioned in the 10. Chapter) the Quickilver in the Tube is ometimes lengthned, ometimes hortned, and o doth ometimes let down, and ometimes lift up the Quickilver.

Ibid. In decimo nono, &c. In the 19. he hews that water doth in the ame manner decend upon the exhauting the Receiver, as he had hewn Quickilver in the foregoing Chapter to decend. Of both which eeing
there is the ame caue, there is no reaon we hould any longer init on this.

p. 82. Nam i, &c. For if it were done o, thee bubbles ought not o to have acended from the bottom of the Veel, (as it is aerted they did, both in this and the following Experiments that treat of bubbles) but from the upper part of the water, where they are les compret; as it is apparently manifet.

p. 83. Repondeo, &c. I anwer that the water, upon that exhaution of the Air, doth not o acend of its own accord, but is violently drawn or lifted upwards by that rarefied Air contracting it elf. For as water doth uffer ome compreion (as appears by experience) o here alo it uffers ome ditenion. And hence it is clearly manifet why thee bubbles hould arie rather from the bottom of the Veel, then from the upper part of the water. For when that vehement uction doth endeavour to elevate the water from the bottom of the Vial, there aries there a certain ubtil matter, which being turned into bubbles doth o acend as is mentioned in the 15. Chapter and the 4. Experiment.
p. 84. Certum ee, &c. It is certain that that Opinion is ufficiently refuted by this ingle Experiment.
p. 85. Necee, &c. It mut needs be that that tone could not otherwie decend, then by leaving behind it uch a thin ubtance as is left by Quickilver or Water decending in like manner.
p. 86. Unde, &c. Whence I plainly conceive that if two perfectlypolih'd Marbles were o joyned that no Air at all were left between them, they could not be drawn aunder by all the power of Man.

Ibid. Uti etiam, &c. Which alo is confirmed by the Example the Author there brings of a Bras Plate ticking o cloe to a Marble Table, that by a luty Youth, who boated of his own trength, it could not be lifted off by a Ring fixed to its Centre.

p. 87. Eodem, &c. Almot the ame manner as we ee in Cupping-glaes applied to a Patients back, in which the flame being extinct, the rarefied Air contracting it elf doth o vehemently (as we ee) lift up, and draw the fleh within the Glas.
Ibid. In his, &c. In thee three there is nothing occurs to be peculiarly here explicated, the account of which is not eaie from what is already delivered.

p. 88. Existimo, &c. But I think that Whitenes hould be rather called a reflex then an innate light, becaue, as the Author bears witnes, it appears not in the dark, but onely in the day, or by Candlelight.
Ibid. Verum, &c. But it eems impoible that uch Animals hould dye o oon onely for want of a thicker Air.
p. 89. Quia per, &c. Becaue by the elf-contraction of the rarefied Air their breath is drawn out of their bodies.

p. 90. At
que hinc, &c. And thence alo aroe thoe vehement Convulions, which the Author there mentions certain mall Birds to have endured before their death.
p. 92. In mala, &c. In a bad Caue they can do no other; but who compell'd them to undertake a bad Caue?

div.head: A Summary of the Contents of the everal Chapters.

list.head: PART I.
list.item: WHerein the Adveraries Objections againt the Elaterits are examined.

Chap. 1. The occaion of this Writing, pag. 1. Francicus Linus his civility in writing obliges the Author to the like, p. 2. Books concerning the Torrecellian Experiment wherewith the Author was formerly unacquainted, ibid. The Inconvenience of Linus's Principles, ibid. The diviion of the enuing Treatie into three Parts.

Chap. 2. A repetition of the Adverary's Opinion and Arguments. His Arguments againt the Weight of the Air examined, p. 4. An Experiment of his to prove that the external Air cannot keep up twenty Inches of Quickilver from decending in a Tube twenty Inches long, ibid. The Authors anwer and reconciliation of the Experiment to his own Hypotheis, p. 5. and the relation of an Experiment of the Authors, wherein onely water being employed intead of Quickilver, without other alteration of the Adveraries Experiment, it agrees well with and confirms the Authors Hypotheis, and his Explication of the mentioned Experiments, ibid. That Water hath no Spring at all, or a very weak one, p. 6. The econd Argument examined, ibid. Whether the ame quantity of Air can adequately fill a greater pace, p. 7. The conceivablenes of both Hypothees compared, ibid.

Chap. 3. Another Argument of the Adveraries, from an Experiment wherein the Mercury inking draws the Finger into the Tube, examined. Q. Whether the Mercury placed in its own tation is upheld by the external Air, or uspended there by an internal Cord? p. 7, 8.

Chap. 4. A repetition of Francicus Linus his principal Experiment, wherein in a Tube of twenty Inches long the Finger on the top is uppoed to be trongly drawn and uck'd into the Tube, p. 9. The Experiment explicated without the aitance of Suction, by the preure of the external Air upon the outide of the Finger, thrut, not uck'd in, p. 10. Francicus Linus his argumentation conidered, p. 11.

Chap. 5. The Examiners lat Experiment conidered, in which he argues againt the Authors Hypotheis, becaue Mercury is not uck'd out of a Veel through a Tube o eaily as Water is, p. 12, 13. An Experiment of Monieur Pachall hewing, that if the upper part of a Tube could be freed from the preure of all internal Air, the Mercury would by the preure of the outward Air be carried up into the Tube as well as Water, till it had attained a height great enough to make its weight equal to that of the Atmosphere, p. 14. Why in a more forcible respiration the Mercurial Cylinder is raied higher then in a more languid, p. 14, 15. A Remark by the bie, That the contraction of the Adveraries uppoed Funiculus is not felt upon the Lungs, p. 15.

Chap. 6. The examination of the Adveraries 4. Chapter, p. 16. That the Spring of the Air may have ome advantage in point of force above the Weight of it, p. 17. That it is unintelligible how the ame Air can adequately fill more space at one time then at another, p. 18.

list.head: PART II.
list.item: Wherein the Adveraries Funicular Hypotheis is examined.
Chap. 1. Wherein what is alledged to prove the Funiculus is conidered; and ome Difficulties are propoed againt the Hypotheis.

The nature of this uppoed Funiculus decribed, p. 19. That according to the Adveraries Opinion this Funiculus is produced by Nature onely to hinder a Vacuum, p. 20, 21. The Adveraries proofs that there is no Vacuum examined, p. 21, 22. That where no enible part is un-enlightned, the place may not be full of light, p. 22. The ame true in Odours, ibid. That there may be matter enough to tranmit the impule of Light, though betwixt the Particles of that matter there hould be tore of Vacuities intercepted, p. 23. That a olid Body hath no coniderable ene of preure from fluid bodies, p. 25. Of the caues of the Vibrations of Quickilver in its decent, p. 26, 27.

Chap. 2. Wherein divers other Difficulties are objected againt the Funicular Hypotheis. As that in Liquors of divers weights and natures, as Water, Wine and Quickilver, there hould be jut the ame weight or trength to extend them into a Funiculus, p. 27. That whereas the Weight and Spring of the Air is inferr'd from unquetioned Experiments, the account of that Hypotheis is trange and unatisfactory. As that the Quickilver doth not onely
touch the top of the Glas, but tick to it; That Nature wreaths a little rarefied Air into a trong rope even able to draw up Quickilver, p. 28, 29. That Rarefaction is performed by a certain unknown force, or vis divuliva, p. 30. That thin Surfaces are left ucceively one after another, that thee Surfaces are contrived into trings, that may be tretch'd without being made more lender, &c. p. 31. The illutration of the manner how his Funiculus is made, from the rarefaction of Wax or Tallow in a lighted Candle, is conidered, p. 32. and hewed not to be appoite, ibid. Divers other difficulties and improbabilities manifeted in the Funicular Hypotheis, p. 33. Of the inward Spring neceary to the contraction of his Funiculus, p. 33, 34. An Argument from a Pendulum's moving freely in an exhauted Receiver, that the medium it moves in doth not conit of an innumerable exceedinglytretch'd trings, p. 35.

Chap. 3. The Aritotelean Rarefaction propoed by the Adverary examined. What Rarefaction and Condenation is, p. 36. Three wayes of explicating how Rarefaction is made, p. 36, 37. Aburdities in reolving the Magdeburg Experiment by the Aritotelean way of Rarefaction, p. 38. The inconveniences of the everal Hypothees compared, p. 39. The difficulties in the Adveraries explaining Rarefaction by Bodies infinitely diviible, p. 41. The difficulties of explaining it by uppoing Bodies made up of parts indiviible, p. 43, 44. The difficulties wherewith his Condenation is incumbred, as that it infers Penetration of Dimenions, &c. p. 46.

Chap. 4. A Conideration pertinent to the preent Controverie, of what happens in trying the Torrecellian and other Experiments at the top and feet of Hills. That the Funicular Hypotheis is but an Inverion of the Elatical, one uppoing a Spring inwards, the other outwards; one performing its effects by Pulion, the other by Traction, p. 48. That thee tryals on the tops and feet of Hills determine the cae for the Authors Hypotheis, p. 49. The truth of the Obervation of Monieur Pachall confirmed, p. 50. and the everal tryals that have been made of it related, ibid. A tryal of the Authors from the Leads of the Abbey-Church at Wetminter, p. 51, 52, 53. That the ubidence of the Mercury at the top of a Hill proceeds from the lightnes of the Atmospherical Cylinder there, p. 54. The relation of an Experiment lately made at Hallifax Hill in confirmation of the former, p. 56.

Chap. 5. Two new Experiments touching the meaure of the force of the Spring of the Air compres'd and dilated. That it is capable of doing far more then the neceity of the Authors Hypotheis requires, p. 57. The firt Experiment,
of compreing Air by pouring Mercury into a crooked Tube, related, p. 58. Wherein the ame Air being brought to a degree of denity twice as great, obtains a Spring twice as trong as before, p. 59. A Table of the Condenation of the Air according to this Experiment, p. 60. Particular Circumtances oberved in the making the Experiment, p. 61. How far the Spring of the Air may be increaed, p. 62. Of the decrement of the force of dilated Air, p. 63. A Table of the Rarefaction of the Air, p. 64. Particular Circumtances in making the Experiment whence this Table was drawn, p. 65, 66. That the free Air here below appears to be near as trongly compret by the weight of the incumbent Air as it would be by the weight of a Mercurial Cylinder of 28. or 30. Inches, p. 67.

list.head: PART III.
list.item: Wherein what is objected againt Mr. Boyle's Explications of particular Experiments is anwered.

The entrance into this Part of the Dicoure, with an advertiement how far onely it will be requiite to examine the Adveraries aertions and explications, the Hypothees on both ides being before conidered, p. 69, 70.
A defence of the firt and econd Experiments, concerning the intruion of the Finger into the Orifice of the Valve of the evacuated Receiver, p. 70.
A defence of the third Experiment, why the Sucker being drawn down there is no greater difficulty in the end then in the beginnin of the gdepreion, p. 71, 72.

Of the fourth Experiment, touching the welling of a Bladder upon the exhaustion of the ambient Air, and proportionably to that exhaution, p. 72, 73. The Authors and the Funicular Hypotheis in the explication of this Phaenomenon compared, ibid.
Of the fifth Experiment, p. 73.

Of the eighth Experiment, about the breaking of a Glas-Receiver which was not globular upon the exhaution of the inward Air, p. 74. Whether it were more likely to be broken by the preure of the Atmosphere without, or a contraction of a tring of Air within, ibid.
Of the ninth Experiment, p. 75. Whether the breaking of the Vial outwards in the exhauted Receiver, was caued by the preure of the Atmosphere through the Tube which was open to the ambient Air, ibid.

Of the 17. Experiment, p. 76, 77, 78, 79. The Torrecellian Experiment being made within the Receiver, whether the decent and acent of the Mercury in the Tube, under and above its wonted tation, be caued by the debilitated and trengthned Spring of the Air, ibid.

Of the 18. Experiment, p. 79, 80. Whether the Authors or the Funicular Hypotheis aign the more probable caue why a Cylinder of Mercury did in Winter rie and fall in the Tube, ometimes as water in a weather-glas according to the laws of Heat and Cold, and ometimes contrary thereunto, ibid.
Of the 19. Experiment, p. 81.
Of the 20. Experiment, p. 82, 83. Some mitakes in the Adverary of the Authors meaning about the Spring of the Water, and the places whence the bubbles aroe, ibid. The Hypothees compared, ibid.

Of the 31. Experiment, p. 84, 85, 86. Of the caue why the Marbles fell not aunder in the exhauted Receiver, though a weight of four Ounces were hung at the lower tone, ibid. Whether the account of the Author or Adverary be more atisfactory, ibid.
